It’s a fact that we all need clothes. Not just for function but as a way to express ourselves and build connections. Fashion shapes culture, identity and adds to our sense of community ✨ But if what we wear comes at the expense of underpaid garment workers or environmental destruction, is it really worth it?

Sustainable fashion isn’t just about eco-friendly fabrics or thrifting (though we love both! 💕); it’s also about ensuring that the people who make our clothes, work in safe conditions and are paid fairly. It’s about making mindful decisions and knowing the impact of our shopping habits.

Because no outfit should come at the cost of someone else’s well-being. When we choose better and invest our money in fashion that respects both people and the planet, we’re not just dressing ourselves - we’re shaping a future where fashion benefits everyone, not just a few.

#SustainableFashion #EthicalStyle #WearTheChange #whomademyclothes #FashionRevolution

Sustainability is NOT about buying eco-friendly products, but it’s about reducing overall consumption and waste. By making intentional choices about what you buy, what we wear and the companies we give our hard earned money to, you can make a big impact on both the industry and the environment 🌿✨🤍

#sustainablefashion #consciousconsumerism #sustainableliving #ethicalfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #ecofriendly

As we step into 2025, how about making a collective New Year’s resolution to embrace more mindful shopping habits and the impact our clothes have on the planet, the people who made it, and even your own sense of fulfilment 🖤 Here are some easy steps to support sustainable fashion, that won’t affect your budget:

1. Think Before You Buy: Before making a purchase, pause and reflect. Does this item truly add value beyond the initial excitement?

2. Take Good Care of Your Clothes: Extend the lifespan of your wardrobe by learning proper care techniques for different fabrics and considering repair services when needed.

3. Think Circular: Embrace a circular economy by shopping secondhand, upcycling, or repairing items instead of discarding them. This approach reduces waste and conserves resources. 

4. Shop Consciously: Support brands dedicated to sustainability and slow fashion. Seek out quality materials, zero-waste policies, and efforts to reduce environmental impact.

5. Shop Less, But Better: Resist the allure of fast fashion bargains. Invest in pieces that align with your values and are designed to last beyond a single season.

6. Donate or Resell: Give your pre-loved items a new life by donating to charity or selling them through resale platforms.

Remember, low prices often come with hidden ethical costs. Be mindful of the human and environmental impact behind steep discounts. Choose ethical brands that prioritize fair labor practices and sustainability.

What’s your top sustainable fashion resolution for 2025? Share below - I’d love to hear your thoughts! ✨
 
📸 Aaron Weiss

🏷️ #SustainableFashion #MindfulShopping #NewYearsResolution #SlowFashion #EthicalConsumer #CircularEconomy #EcoFriendly #ConsciousLiving #2025Goals

Fortunately we recovered from our Christmas colds and we went down to London to spend a couple of days with Rosa, Josh and Rufus…which was so lovely and I’m missing them already.
On Monday we had a trip to @londonmuseumofwaterandsteam in Brentford which was fabulous. I am a huge fan of the grandeur of Victorian engineering and this place did not disappoint. It is also really geared up for kids too with lots of children’s activities including a miniature steam railway. 
I finally got round to wear my Christmas frock which I think is going to get a lot of wear. It is a jazzed up version of a @cottonandchalk pattern made from several different fabrics from my stash. The jacket and sweater were both my own  patterns made from thrifted yarns.
You will be seeing a lot of these red shoes, they were a Christmas present and I really love them, they are @fly.london and cute and so comfy.

Saturday preloved browsing 🤸‍♂️ As promised some of my favourite places to shop pre-loved in Glasgow’s Westend.  From @mariecurieuk in Hyndland where I picked up new, never worn Max Mara shoes for £40!! 
Designer fabulousness in @twicelovedglasgowfashion where I always love their range of designer shoes and bags 🤩 

Then onto Retro in Kelvinbridge where I’ve been shopping since my teens.  You’ll find vintage beauties like the 1940s velvet jacket as well as modern clothing and shoes. 

Onto @isabellaswardrobe in Broomhill who sell special Designer finds.. This Gucci skirt was so stunning and I love all Miu Miu shoes.  The knitted sweater is a brand I’ve not heard of,  love pre-loved for finding pieces like this.
Finally ‘Authentic’ in Kelvinbridge next to Retro… it’s run by a lovely couple who have such a good eye for vintage homeware as well as a large selection of vintage suede shearlings and knitwear. 

Pre-loved shopping does take a bit of patience but it’s often really exciting when you find goodies like my Max Mara shoes or designer items you couldn’t afford new.  It’s also great for adding unique style to outfits.

I’ve enjoyed seeing more people feel confident wearing pre-loved since I began on here 7 years ago.. There’s more vintage pre-loved shops saved n my highlights and I’ll put some of my tips on stories today. 

Do you buy pre-loved?

Coming up to Christmas the shop gets pretty busy, on top of that I had a cold so I needed to pace myself and to me this means curling up on the sofa in the evenings with hand stitching. 
This latest little frock is something I’ve been meaning to make for a while since I found this lovely denim remnant in a charity shop a couple of years ago. I used one of my favourite patterns from the Japanese Sweet Dress Book. Since I discovered this book I have made several versions in many different fabrics. The only adjustment I made this time was to the armholes.
I decorated the tucks with feather stitch, one of my favourite embroidery stitches. Due to the lack of fabric I had to have a seam down the back so I made this into a faux button back with appliqué and running stitches. The pockets were also decorated with appliqué and running stitches.
The neck and armholes are bound in black gingham (from a thrifted shirt)
The tartan slacks were thrifted many years ago.
The shoes are by Fly London…a Christmas present from Pete

Greetings from my sewing room…it’s my birthday but sadly we changed our plans due to the weather but every cloud has a silver lining so it’s meant a bit more time stitching. 
As it’s also the new year I thought I’d show you what I will be working on over the next few months…but as you know these plans might change depending on what ideas or fabrics I come across. 
I had two wonderful new books as gifts, Soulful Stitch by @deenabeverley and @casholmestextiles and Forage & Stitch by @artistcaz I can’t wait to delve into these over the next few weeks.
I am also starting on a jacket transformation project…more of that later.
On the knitting front I am knitting an Outlander style shawl from a free pattern from @regnmia 
On the sewing front I found these two wonderful old Sanderson curtains last year, they will probably end up as frocks but I haven’t got any farther with that yet. The other fabric is a very soft brushed cotton that is being made into a cosy winter petticoat which will be embellished with lace and embroidery.
Today’s pinafore is made from a 1960s curtain, worn over embroidered jeans and a thrifted cashmere sweater I dyed yellow.
Whatever your creative plans are for 2025 I hope you have a lot of fun.
#sewover50 #sewover50jan #sewingplans #curtainstocouture #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #sustainablefashion #sewinginspiration #newyearplans #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyoulove #mysewingroom #handstitching #handknitting #ageismisneverinstyle

In support of @curtainstocouture I thought I would show you a pinafore, my own pattern,  that I made from a vintage Sanderson loose cover that I persuaded @justjillrosalind to let me have. Secondly I wanted to share the joy of embellishing thrifted items, in this case a pair of denim jeans. You can turn a very basic utilitarian garment into something really rather nice that you will enjoy for many years.
One of the things about making clothes from used textiles is that you often have to piece bits together, it is not as simple as cutting out from a large piece of fabric…but in my opinion much more satisfying. The bindings on the pinafore are made from a thrifted cotton shirt.
As you may have noticed I love embroidering and applying appliqué to my clothes, I love both the results and the process. Denim is a really lovely fabric to embroider as it is nice and firm…but don’t choose one with a lot of Lycra in it. I have included a couple of closeups of the embroidery.
The necklaces I made from old broken beads and trinkets collected over the years.
I bought the cardigan from my friend…thank you Jill.
Thank you for posting your pictures of what you are making from upcycled textiles. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #curtainstocouturejanuary so we can find your posts for #followerfriday and also enter you into our fabric giveaway.
#sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #fastfashionsucks #slowfashionmovement #slowfashion #upcycledfashion #sewover50 #sewover50january #ageismisneverinstyle #ilookmyage #grannychic #oldladystyle

Sustainability Sunday. In spite of the name, here at Curtains to Couture HQ we don’t only sew with old curtains, so I thought I would show you some of the clothes we have made from various other old textiles.
This is just a selection and I have marked each picture with what it is made of.
We all love a cotton tablecloth, particularly gingham or embroidered, they make such pretty summer frocks and because they have been laundered regularly they are generally lovely and soft.
Another great source of fabric is the duvet cover. These days many of these are made of poly cotton but if you can hunt down the cotton or brushed cotton ones I would recommend you snap them up. As well as these making cosy frocks and jackets I personally use the brushed cotton or flannelette ones to make petticoats and line winter clothes. If you can find king size there is just so much fabric.
I know there are some people who think old quilts should not be cut up but in my opinion giving them a new life is a brilliant idea… otherwise these can just be stored away in cupboards which is such a waste.
Another beautiful fabric is old ticking, this is generally striped and was used to cover mattresses or pillows, it has a tight weave so the feathers would not poke through. This is really nice for frocks and summer coats.
Lisa @vintage_dahling also made an amazing garment, made from a feed sack…just remember nothing is off limits.
There are also a number of makers on IG doing amazing things with vintage tea towels.
Apart from all of these amazing soft furnishings there are always remnants to be found, large and small which can be incorporated into our wardrobes. Another way to reuse old fabrics is rework garments you find in charity shops…if it’s nice fabric you can always find a use for it.
In the next couple of days we will be launching our January challenge so stay tuned and thank you for your continued support
Marcia xxxx
@justjillrosalind @slowsewmo @vintage_dahling @marcialoisriddington

I’ve now finished in the shop after a brilliant week and my cold is clearing up so I’m currently in a good place. 
Today I wanted to show you a couple of winter clothes I’ve made from thrifted brushed cotton duvet sets. Back in the day we would buy sheets and blankets and they would be used until they fell apart. Now it seems that duvet covers are replaced quite frequently resulting in many sets turning up in charity shops. Unfortunately many of them are poly cotton but there are still many good quality ones out there waiting to be upcycled.
I made this frock several years ago from a king size brushed cotton duvet cover and pillow cases, there was even enough left to make a little coat. The pattern is a vintage McCalls 7917 designed by Laura Ashley.
The coat I made last year again from a couple of duvet covers, one for the lining and one for the main fabric. Again it was a vintage pattern, Style 2410.
Both of these garments are so cosy and perfect now it’s turned a bit cooler.
We had a bracing walk in Woodbridge today, which apparently is the happiest place to live in the UK…not entirely sure how they decide this. Anyway it was looking beautiful today so I have included a few pictures.

As you have probably gathered I love red and I also love the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book #stylishwraps by #yoshikotsukiori 
I have used this pattern many times in all kinds of different fabrics, lined and unlined, and I love them all.
This version I made from red needle cord over one of the lockdowns, and it is lined with old flannelette sheets making it quite a cosy coat.
I have many of these Japanese books, the styling is superb and they all come with the patterns to trace in the back of the book. The downside is they are are for the smaller woman.
Today’s frock is patchwork made from tartans  and florals. 
The petticoat is made from red flannel.
The sweater is knitted from thrifted yarn to my own pattern with appliqué heart.
We had a morning out in Ely today, one of my favourite places to go. As the weather was so nice we had a picnic by the river…I have included a couple of pictures as it was looking so beautiful today.
I am now looking through the book again thinking I might try some of the other patterns…watch this space. We obviously had a creep around the antique centre and I bought a cracking pair of Aesthetic style brass candlesticks and several other nice things for the shop.

Feeling like you have nothing to wear isn’t a wardrobe issue - it’s a mindset issue. Trends exist only and exclusively to make you feel like what you already own is outdated, so you keep on buying more. 

Sis, your style doesn’t need to be dictated by someone else’s marketing strategy! Instead of chasing what’s ‘in,’ enjoy what you already have 🖤✨

#slowfashion #styleinspiration #sustainablefashion #timelessfashion #capsulewardrobe

Ridiculous really is the operative word here. 🤡 The tired argument that “poor people need fast fashion” just doesn’t hold up anymore. So many privileged folks in my comments are bending over backward to justify their shopping habits, trying to excuse their role in supporting unethical and highly polluting clothing - and it’s deeply worrying. 

Fast fashion is a major driver of climate change and the global clothing industry produces more emissions than international air travel and shipping combined! A lot of this is fueled by online shopping and the endless push for new trends. 

Social media only makes it worse, amplifying the pressure to keep up. One in three young women now consider clothes “old” after being worn just once or twice. Let that sink in… 😔

#sustainablefashion #slowfashion #sustainableliving #timelessfashion #fashionrevolution

There has been a flurry of new followers recently asking about my shop…so here it is. 
I had wanted an antique shop for many years and eight years ago, after retiring from my proper sensible job, I threw caution to the wind and opened Smoking Monkey Antiques in my adopted town of Bury St Edmunds. I wanted to create the kind of shop that was not predictable, somewhere that would always surprise…the kind of shop I enjoy finding when on my travels.
We are lucky to have some very loyal customers as well as many visitors from all over the world. Now it is established I can never imagine it closing so I will continue to work until I physically can’t…hopefully at least another ten years.
Todays outfit
Red flannel petticoat and blue linen pinafore both hand made by me.
Tartan shirt is a recent charity shop find.
The sweater I knit a couple of years ago from thrifted yarn.

@slowfashionchallenge Day 9, lace details, so for me today is all about showing your petticoats…or “Charlie’s dead” as people used to shout at me.
As you may have noticed there is generally a petticoat or a pair of embroidered jeans showing under my frocks. I have petticoats in different weights of fabric from fine cotton to flannelette depending on the weather…but they must always have a lace trim.
Today’s petticoat is made from two old heavy cotton pillowcases, I dyed them yellow together with some broderie anglaise lace. Basically the skirt is one pillowcase and the frill is made from the other. I ran elastic through the top, added a bit of feather stitch, a few appropriate words and some narrow ribbon…and you have a winter weight petticoat.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewiver50november #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #upcycledfashion #petticoat #petticoatlove #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyouwant #grannychic #oldladystyle

About a month ago I posted with my Christmas frock plans…well it’s finished. My inspiration was a frock I found on Pinterest but being a practical kind of girl I wanted something that can be worn all year round for any occasion.
I wanted fullness without the bulk so I chose this beautiful shaped pattern from @cottonandchalk and cut the skirt into strips then stitched together so you get the layered look without the bulk. I then hand stitched cotton lace onto the seams. I added patch pockets and a little button detail to the front bodice.
Fabric wise, this is all from my stash, the gingham is an old tablecloth, a piece of vintage Laura Ashley cotton left over from a project, and the bindings are an old shirt.
The petticoat is a piece of lace I found in a charity shop many years ago. As it’s cold I wore it over my usual flannel one. 
#sewover50 #sewover50december24 #curtainstocouturechristmas #curtainstocouture #dopaminedressing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyoulove #wearwhatyouwant #sustainablefashion #sustainablechristmas #slowsewing #slowfashion #ilookmyage #ageismisneverinstyle #grannychic #oldladystyle #christmasfrock #christmastartan

Today seemed an appropriate day to talk about rainwear again. I am now in the shop and I can confirm this mac really does keep you dry all over.
A few years ago I decided I needed a really nice big raincoat and the only one I could find that I liked was £600. 
I was lucky to find some deadstock red waxed cotton on EBay for very little money and I used this vintage Style 2410 pattern. I deliberately made it very roomy to accommodate winter layers.
I was very nervous about using waxed cotton but I took my time and it was nowhere near as tricky as I thought it would be.
I recently washed it using a special solution I found in Seasalt and it cleaned well and it retained its waterproof qualities.
I am not expecting many customers today so I have brought my Christmas cards to write.
#sewover50 #sewover50december24 #imakemyclothes #dopaminedressing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #makeamac #ilookmyage #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #ageismisneverinstyle #oldladystyle

The weather is now turning chillier so I made another waistcoat, this time from a piece of vintage needlecord that I think was perhaps Laura Ashley. I lined it with an old flannelette sheet and the binding is cut from an old cotton shirt. This is the second one I’ve made from a pattern a friend gave me and there will definitely be more, they are such a cosy extra layer.
The coat dress is from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps, made from several old cafe tablecloths.
The slacks I made recently from a brown corduroy remnant, the pattern is from Lotta Jansdotta Everyday Style. This is not a glamorous pattern but if you want a comfortable pair of slacks it’s ideal.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #sewoverageism #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #imakemyclothes #japanesesewingbooks #reusereducerecycle #ilookmyage #kawaii #oldladystyle #grannycore

@slowfashionchallenge Day 8 Fabric Focus
I love fabric and my sewing really is fabric led. As I very seldom buy new fabric I can’t be fussy about the sizes of the pieces I buy so I have developed ways of squeezing pinafores out of the smallest of pieces. I mainly buy old curtains, bed linen or old remnants. These I find in charity shops, vintage fairs and I have a friend called @justjillrosalind if you know you know. 
However you are often left with lots of small pieces and as they are far too pretty to waste the answer has to be a patchwork frock. Some of the pieces in this frock I have had for many years. The bodice was made from a linen frock that no longer fit.
As you can see it is an all weather pinafore, the left hand picture was taken today at Petworth and the warmer looking one was taken over the summer. The second picture shows all three of my patchwork frocks…I haven’t ruled out another one.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #slowfashionchallengenov24 #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashionmovement #slowfashion #patchworkdress #patchworkfrock #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #donttellmehowtodress #oldladystyle #grannycore #ilookmyage

@slowfashionchallenge Day 12, Shopping Advice
As you know I make most of my clothes from old fabrics, often from existing garments I find in charity shops. 
When I am in charity shops or vintage markets I tend to look at the fabrics rather than the actual garments. An example of this is my green needlecord jacket. I fell in love with the soft green fabric but was not keen on the style of the tunic.
The answer was to cut down the front, shorten just below the pockets and use the excess to create the front bands…and you end up with a jacket that has already had several outings.
Another bit of advice is don’t go charity shopping for specific things, keep an open mind and you never know what treasures you might find. Everyone is a winner…you have something lovely, the charity gets much needed funds and you have saved something from landfill.
#slowfashionchallengenov24 #curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #upcycledfashion #upcycledclothing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #sustainablestyle #dopaminedressing #dopaminestyle #ageismisneverinstyle #ilookmyage #grannychic #oldladystyle #kawaii

This is a simple pinafore I made earlier this year and as you can see it really is a frock for all seasons. It is made from an old gingham tablecloth and a couple of remnants from my stash. It is one of those frocks I just made up as I went along.
One of the reasons I make pinafores is because they are so easy to adapt to any weather. In the summer you just add a tee shirt and cotton petticoat and in the winter a sweater and flannel petticoat keep out the chills.
As you probably guessed the middle picture was yesterday morning. Yesterday I teamed it with a thrifted black cashmere polo neck sweater, red flannel petticoat, secondhand tweed jacket and the shawl I knit several years ago…and of course a red beret.
I think red is just one of those colours that feels good  in any weather, and I think it is particularly good on cold dull days.
#sewover50 #sewover50december24 #ageismisneverinstyle #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #dopaminedressing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #curtainstocouture slow fashion #kawaii #grannychicstyle

@slowfashionchallenge Day 14, sustainable quote.
OK, so you might be wondering why this concept would affect sustainability. 
Particularly since the rise of social media which can really play on our insecurities, we are continually being told we would be happier if we looked different or wore different clothes. As a result of this we spend a lot of money on beauty products, treatments and fashionable clothes, and this is an ongoing thing producing a lot of waste and pollution. The sad thing is this will not result in happiness just depleted bank accounts. 
The sustainable way forward is to accept yourself, develop your own style and look, don’t be a poor imitation of someone else…just be yourself.
Self love and self acceptance is definitely the way forward. I so wished I’d learned this lesson earlier in my life.
A huge thank you to the organisers of the Slow Fashion Challenge, I’ve learnt stuff, met new people and had fun.
I knit the cardigan from a bag of thrifted yarn…and it’s so cosy.
I made the frock many years ago from vintage Laura Ashley fabric. 
Petticoat is made from red flannelette 
#slowfashionchallengenov24 #curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #handknitted #knittedcardigan #slowfashion #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #grannychic #oldladystyle #kawaii #ilookmyage #imakemyclothes

@slowfashionchallenge Day 11 National Recycling Week. It’s not just fast fashion that causes a lot of textile waste, it is also bedding, sheets and duvet covers. When I was young everyone bought white linen or cotton sheets and pillowcases and these were used until they completely wore out…often being mended along the way. However in the 1960s, coinciding with the increasing popularity of the duvet, bedding became a fashion thing. Nowadays most people change their sheets and duvet covers very frequently and as a consequence of this you will always find bedding in charity shops. Unfortunately a lot of this is polyester and frankly not very nice.
So, why am I standing here in my winter coat?
I often buy cotton duvet covers in charity shops, they are generally very cheap and there is loads of fabric waiting to be recycled. My winter coat was made from two flannelette duvet covers, one for the outside and another one for the lining…you would not believe how cosy it is.
The other pictures are a coat and dress both made from a king size duvet cover and pillow cases.
We hear a lot about fast fashion textile waste but this change in the way we buy bedding is very rarely mentioned yet it produces a lot of waste that ends up in landfill.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #upcycledclothing #upcycledfabric #slowfashionchallengenov24 #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #iwearwhatisew #oldladystyle #grannychic

I wanted to show you the jacket I found in a charity shop last week. I was really excited to find this jacket and even more excited when it fit me! Looking at the label I would say it’s probably 1970s, a beautiful woollen fabric with velvet trim…just perfect…It had even been dry cleaned. I haven’t actually made a fitted jacket since I did my O level needlework in 1967, I keep finding nice secondhand ones so I don’t have to although I do have a pattern and fabric somewhere.
Today’s frock is something I made about four years ago from some linen gingham. Fortunately my friend @justjillrosalind was too tall for this beautiful cardigan so I bought it from her…thank you Jill, I absolutely love it.
As you can see from the picture it’s quite blowy today, but compared to many parts of the country we have been very lucky. I was also very lucky at the antique fair where I found a big box of my favourite Collier Campbell fabric for a very nice price.

No greenwashing bulls***t here 

Here’s part 2 of a popular reel I did a few weeks ago sharing some of my favourite small, sustainable, slow fashion brands. There’s so much greenwashing going on at the moment with high street and fast fashion brands so I wanted to continue to shine a light on some brands who do things a bit differently. These brands reuse existing materials, source them sustainably and offer customers made to order on their products to reduce waste (I always think that good things are worth the wait!). I think ‘made to order’ is the theme of this part 2 as pretty much all of these brands work on this system. 

A quick brand summary: @kindredofireland is quite a new brand to me, they make the most incredible locally sourced linen pieces, this amazing rainbow stripe set was created specific to my measurements and I couldn’t be happier with it.

I absolutely adore Maria at @gingham_palace we met last year at her London pop up and she’s such a lovely, incredible lady. The brand is Spanish and makes iconic cotton PJ sets (which you can absolutely wear out too) and her new bow shirts and summer sets look amazing too.

@stalf.studio I adore Paris and her brand Stalf. Think easy, comfy basics which go with everything in your wardrobe. The designs are simple, materials luxurious  and made to such high quality.  I love the little design details like the flutes sleeves on this top which gives it a touch of something special. 

@upfromadream_ Olivia creates the most beautiful, girly, floral, floaty dresses of my dreams and I’m so happy I got one of these in one of her recent drops. She uses deadstock/vintage materials and I love the puffy sleeves and it has pockets of course!

#slowfashionchallengenov2024 day 2, 30 wears. I enjoyed scrolling through the introductions yesterday, it was good to see familiar faces and many new to me. 
I don’t tend to make clothes for specific occasions, I find this puts me under pressure and the fun goes out of the window. Often these special frocks are worn once then languish in the wardrobe. However, this frock was made for an occasion, the reopening of the shop after the first Covid lockdown and as you can see it has not languished in my closet. This is the frock I reach for on so many mornings, it lifts my spirits and makes me feel good.
As you can see it’s an all round year frock which I find very satisfactory.
It was made from a pair of 1970s curtains and some thrifted gingham. You have no idea how many people tell me their mum used to have these curtains. There isn’t a pattern for this frock, like many of my clothes I made it up as I went along.
Today I am wearing it with a thrifted tweed jacket that I bought about twenty years ago…again I must have worn this a lot over the years. 
@slowfashionchallenge #sewover50 #sewover50november #so50reworn #upcycledfashion #slowfashion #sustainablefashion #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #curtainstocouture #kawaii #oldladystyle #ageismisneverinstyle

#slowfashionchallengenov24 Days 2&3, life cycle check and the art of layering. As I was very busy yesterday spending time with family I am combining them both in one post.
As the majority of things I wear are not new when I find them I am never quite sure what their story is. I try to buy natural fibres, these are nicer to wear and better for the environment but often, you cannot be certain as labels are missing…I like to think that I am rescuing unwanted garments and fabrics and giving them another chance. As there are already so many unwanted textiles languishing out there it just seems the right thing to do.
I love layering…some may call it an obsession but I get a great deal of pleasure getting dressed every day…playing with colours, textures and patterns. I appreciate that living in the UK is probably the ideal climate for this type of dressing…not too hot and not too cold.
The boots are a recent secondhand buy from EBay.
Petticoat is made from two thrifted pillowcases, dyed yellow and embroidered.
Pinafore is from a piece of vintage brushed cotton.
Sweater is made from a thrifted remnant of a printed knitted fabric.
The coat is made from a piece of 1960s cotton velvet…definitely one of my most worn pieces.
The scarf is made from a worn out tee shirt.
I see no reason why these garments will not continue to be worn and enjoyed by me.
@slowfashionchallenge #sewover50 #sewover50reworn #sewover50november24 #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #secondhandisnotsecondbest #curtainstocouture #layeringclothing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic #grannycore #imakemyclothes

#sewover50 #sewover50october24 #curtainstocouture #upcycledclothing #upcycledfabric #slowfashion #sustainablefashion #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #dopaminedressing #lagenlookclothing #kawaii #oldladystyle #ilookmyage

Just thought I’d show you what I will be working on for the next few weeks. There are some wonderful tartan creations to be found on Pinterest and Instagram so I thought I’d make myself one for Christmas…and beyond.
I really like the way tartans can be mixed with ginghams and other fabrics, so inspired I thought I’d put my own slant on that idea and make a festive pinafore.
I wanted fullness without lots of gathers so I’m using Cotton & chalk pattern no.10 which gives you width at the bottom and a great flare…over 3 metres at the hem. The skirt is in five horizontal panels and the bodice will be tartan with some kind of frill and button band down the front. All of the seams will be covered in narrow cream cotton lace which I will stitch on by hand.
This is a work in progress and I am not completely sure how it will end up…but I know I will have fun and hopefully it will be ready for Christmas.
All of the fabrics are secondhand and were in my stash so it’s a nice economical make.
#sewover50 #sewover50october24 #sewingplans #workinprogress #recreatethelook #christmasfrock #tartandress #christmasdress #slowsewing #kawaii #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyoulove

Following on from yesterday’s autumn beret we have even more pom-poms, this time it’s the seasonal wreath I made for the shop.
I love making pom-poms, it is very satisfying and it is something to do with all those odd bits of yarn we seem to end up with. I use a plastic pom-pom maker which is significantly quicker than the old fashioned cardboard method. I bought several of these metal frames many years ago but you can always use an old metal coat hanger formed into a circle.
When you have cut your yarn after you have finished winding, leave several inches of yarn when you tie around the middle as you will use this to tie them onto your frame. You can then add whatever takes your fancy, I used a big bow and a few foraged acorn cups.
This one will now stay up until I get the Christmas pom-pom wreath out.
Today’s frock is my autumn patchwork one, worn with thrifted striped sweater and cardigan.
#curtainstocoutureautumn #curtainstocouture #sewover50 #autumncolours #autumnwreath #fallcolors #fallwreath #autumndecorations #autumndecor #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #pompom #pompomwreath #autumnvibes #sewover50october24 #patchworkdress

A couple of years ago I bought a lovely big cardigan in a charity shop (last picture), then I found a big bag of green flecked yarn, some in balls and some knitted up, it’s surprisingly satisfying unraveling knitting and making it into balls. I enjoyed wearing the cardigan so much I decided recreate it using the green yarn and this is the result. I know this is going to get a lot of wear once it turns colder…plenty of room for layering!
It is an Aran weight yarn and I used 5.5mm needles, and if I am sensible I will keep the pattern safe. 
The slacks are old bark cloth curtains lined with a flannelette sheet, pattern is New Look 6354.
The pinafore is an old brown velvet curtain.
The striped sweater is some thrifted knitted fabric.
The boots I recently found on EBay…and I love them.

Supporting the ethos of @curtainstocouture challenge #curtainstocoutureautumn I thought I would show you the beret I embellished last year. As you know I love a bit of appliqué, so when I found this yellow wool beret in a charity shop I had a very strong urge to cover it in autumn oak leaves…and this is the result. The leaves are made from scraps of felt from my stash and are stitched on with matching blanket stitch, and it was all finished off with a Pom-pom.

The pinafore is made from an old brown velvet curtain and there is even more appliqué on the thrifted jeans.

Welcome to our @curtainstocouture second Sustainable Sunday.
Over the years there have been two non fiction books that have had a lasting effect on me. One of them is the 1984 book Seeing Green by Jonathon Porritt, the first book on environmental issues I had ever read.
The other is Finery by Maria Da Conceicao which was published in 1979…this is the one I am talking about today. I was rather hard up in those days but I saved up £7.95 and bought a copy. It really had  a profound effect on the way I saw clothes…and still does. This remains my most treasured book, it is as relevant today as when it was written, the absolute antithesis of fast fashion.
This was clothes as wearable art, not throwaway items, it explains that by using your sewing and knitting skills you can give personal character to your clothes and have that sense of pride that goes with wearing a work of art. These are clothes that you are going to want to keep for many years, not just for a season. 
The garments Maria made did not need expensive fabrics, she made them from old tablecloths, old lace or thrifted clothes…you just needed basic sewing skills and imagination.
This is the philosophy of Curtains to Couture, we can still have beautiful clothes and homes by creating items using resources that are already in the system…we do not continually need to be buying new. 
I have included some of my favourite images from the book and the final picture is a skirt I made from scrap fabrics and lace not long after I discovered this book. The photo was taken in the early 1980s.
#curtainstocouture #sustainability #sustainabilitysunday #clothesasart #wearableart #slowfashion #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #mariadaconceição #reducereuserecycle

Fast fashion and sustainability can never go hand in hand. Brands like H&M, Zara, Gucci and Louis Vuitton and many more, may boast “sustainable” products but many still harm the planet and exploit workers behind the scenes. True sustainability means transparency and ethical practices at every step - not just clever marketing.

The takeaway? Don’t just take their word for it. Let’s dig deeper, demand better and support brands that genuinely care. Look for brands that prioritize transparency and sustainability across their entire process—not just in their ads. 

🌍💚 #ThinkBeforeYouBuy #SustainableFashion #Greenwashing #Sustainableliving

I know it’s not just me! And here’s the thing: a badly made garment from low-quality fabric is never a good addition to any wardrobe. And no one wants seams that unravel, buttons that pop, or colours that fade after just a few washes 🙃

A long-lasting wardrobe isn’t just about beautiful clothing; it’s about the full package: thoughtful tailoring, strong seams, sturdy buttons, linings that last, and high-quality fabric composition.

What’s your go-to trick for spotting high-quality clothing? Share your tips below! 👇 

#SustainableStyle #BuyBetter #StylingTips #FashionWithPurpose #slowfashion #sustainablefashion

I’m a hand luggage only girl and here’s how I do it! 

I’m currently travelling from Colombia to Peru and Bolivia with a 50L backpack. The weather is mostly sunny and up to 30 degrees, but the high altitude stops can get as cold as 1 degree at night. 

Whether you’re travelling for a weekend away or an extended trip, packing with carry-on only can reduce costs and friction for your journey. If you’re into your fashion, however, it can feel like a challenge to fit your outfit opportunities in, whilst adhering to the climate. With that in mind, here’s some tips on how I maximise my outfits with hand luggage only:

1. Pack according to a complimentary colour pallet that works for you. For me, that means picking two matching colours and one pop (greens, blues, and reds) and sticking to neutral bases for the rest.

2. Pack outfits not items. Don’t just pack your favourite individual items; pack items that form a mini capsule wardrobe to mix and match, and test it out in advance. I try to make sure every item can be relayed with at least two others in my bag.

3. Pack with a strong foundation. Base your outfits around wearable basics that perform day to night. For this trip, I’ve packed comfortable and breathable cotton, linen and wool basics that will regulate my temperature in different climates and will last a few wears without a wash.

4. Maximise variety with accessories. I’ve packed a few hats, a silk scarf, and patterned scrunchies to switch up my outfits without taking up tons of space.

5. Maintain your clothes whilst your away. Hang up items at the end of the day to air them out and spot clean any spillages straight away, which will help to get an additional wear before a wash. Clothes made with natural fibres like cotton and linen will stay fresher for longer. If you’re planning an extended trip, book accomodation that has a washing machine or pack some hand wash (easier on flight-free trips without liquid restrictions) to wash and rewear your clothes.
Are you a hand luggage fan? Would love to hear your thoughts on how you maximise your hand luggage below!👇

Patience pays off in the world of slow fashion 🦋💚

Fashion is becoming increasingly circular thanks to the number of people embracing resale, and it’s great to see. Last year I spotted this Cos jumpsuit new on the high street, but I’ll always shop #secondhandfirst, especially for pieces I don’t truly “need”. After keeping my eyes out on resale apps, consignment stores, and in charity shops, I finally came across it on @vinted. It’s in my favourite colour, a very adaptable shape with drawstrings at the waist and neck, and even better for being second-hand. 

The main message of this post is to remind everyone that you can very often, with a bit of effort, find high street fashion popping up on the second-hand market if you wait long enough. This jumpsuit was cheaper than the new version, and I got to play my part in keeping fashion circular. 

As a side note, however, it feels uncomfortable to celebrate how fast new items are let go of. I think the ideal is somewhere in between: everyone to play their part in making considered choices when buying new, whilst planning to look after their clothes for years to come, and ultimately sharing them back into the secondary market when the time is right.

#secondhand #vintedfinds #secondhandfind #preloved #circularfashion #fashionblog #fashionblogger #slowfashionblogger

I’ve entered the wedding guest season of my life and have been reminded of that feeling of not having something to wear 👗👔

Here’s some options on how to take a slower approach to formalwear:

⭐️ Wear something you already own: once you own a formal outfit for a particular season, keep repeating it. It’s so refreshing looking forward to an event without worrying about what to wear, when you’ve already tested an outfit before. You can switch up accessories to keep it feeling fresh. 

⭐️ Borrow: find some friends or family to borrow from. The same goes for lending. If anyone knows me in person and wants to borrow a formal outfit I’ve worn before, let me know and we can keep it circular!

⭐️ Try renting: with enough planning time in advance, you can rent formalwear smoothly from places like @rites.co @byrotation and @hurr. Think about how many other people have outfits they’ve only worn a few times for an event!

⭐️ Buy second-hand: if the above hasn’t worked, buy something second-hand and then set out to repeat it. There’s so many lightly worn formalwear pieces on second-hand apps waiting to be worn again.

For my wedding guest outfit in this picture, I planned to borrow this same dress from my Mum. When it didn’t fit as well as I’d hoped, I bought the next size second-hand on @vinted knowing it was an option I’d feel happy in. I’m determined to rewear this and lend it out too 👗

How do you approach formalwear in a slower way? 

Finally, congratulations to Steven and Serena. It was a beautiful wedding 💚

Curtains on the Catwalk
I’ve just had quite an adventure, I went down to London on my own and attended the very splendid @londonfrocktails and what an evening I had. It was fabulous to meet so many women I’d previously only spoken to on line.
Part of the evening was the catwalk where we all showed off our home made frocks, and believe me there were some amazing creations. In keeping with the ethos of @curtainstocouture I thought I should wear an old curtain…so it really was curtains on the catwalk. This was a frock I made several years ago from a vintage Sanderson curtain, but I did add more froth to my red net petticoat to give it a bit more body.
I was far too busy having fun and talking but unfortunately I failed miserably at taking pictures. Fortunately a lot of women did and I have really enjoyed looking at their instagram posts. Thank you @judithrosalind for my catwalk pictures.
A huge thank you to the organisers @susanyoungsewing @sewthreadbear @ooobop @thatlenaking 
Thank you for @what_lizzie_made and @lou_lou_seamsodd for joining me on the catwalk.
Finally thank you @katys9296 for sharing the weekend with me, I feel I’ve made a new friend.

We just wanted to remind you that @curtainstocouture will be launching Tuesday 1st October.
This venture is a collaboration of five friends who love to make clothes from old household linens, and we want to share our enthusiasm with you. The plan is to have fun, help save the planet one curtain at a time…and have more fun.
These little squares are all garments I have made from old curtains, tablecloths and bedding…as you can see it’s not just pretty frocks, although I do love a pretty frock. 
We do hope you will join us. 
@justjillrosalind @vintage_dahling @slowsewmo @clare.burnage

#septembertextilelove24  day 3 is sustainable. Sustainability has always been important to me, I think growing up in the 1950s and 1960s it was not an optional extra, it was a way of life, mainly for economic reasons but also there was not that much stuff around.
Sustainability is such a huge topic but I will concentrate on the part that is pertinent to this challenge and talk about  textiles. Currently making my clothes is a huge part of my stitching life. I love clothes but I am very aware of the environmental impact of fast fashion, so making my clothes out of secondhand fabrics, fabrics that are already in the system, seemed to be an answer to this quandary.
Since starting on this journey I have discovered that my dressmaking is going into a new direction. Many of these old fabrics are of a wonderful quality and the colours and designs are beautiful. These are fabrics that you want to take your time with, you want to embellish and you know the garments will last for many years.
It is surprising to me how often people change their household linens which means there is a constant flow of old bed linens, tablecloths and curtains into charity shops or sadly just sent straight to landfill.
The yellow frock is made up of two different old tablecloths. The green and pink is a duvet cover…there is so much fabric in a double duvet cover!
The dark green is a vintage Sanderson curtain and the jacket is a thrifted tunic reworked into a shirt.
It is important to me that I can enjoy my stitching and not be over consuming new and valuable resources unnecessarily.

I’m really loving the current weather, really feels like September should be, warm and sunny but not hot. Perfect weather for autumn layers.
With this in mind I found this green needlecord tunic in a local charity shop. I wasn’t too fussed about the style but I thought it would make a lovely jacket. Basically I cut down the front,  shortened it to just under the pockets and used this piece to make the front bands. I was intending to add some kind of fastening but it seems to work very well without. As you can see I added a bit of top stitching…because I love doing it. I’ve worn it twice now and I think it’s going to be a really useful layering piece.
In the spirit of #secondhandseptember everything I am wearing, apart from socks and undies are secondhand. They have this really lovely slogan which is “Dress For The World You Want”, it’s really nice that you can have so much fun with your wardrobe and know that you are doing the right thing.
I made the frock several years ago out of a 1960s glazed cotton, the pattern is from the Japanese Sweet Dress Book.
The thrifted jeans I embroidered over lockdown.
Everything else have been bought secondhand

�Continuing with the introductory posts for @curtainstocouture 
My name is Marcia @marcialoisriddington and I love old stuff, by day I run my antique shop Smoking Monkey Antiques, and by night I make my clothes using vintage or thrifted fabrics.
One of the wonderful things about Instagram is that I have found friends with a similar passion and this is how curtains to couture came about. I started buying old fabric from Jill several years ago never thinking that this would lead to a real life friendship. It was really through her that I met the other amazing women.
Sustainability in fashion is such a huge and important topic but in my mind that is no reason why working towards a sustainable wardrobe should not be fun. I personally think turning a pair of vintage curtains into a frock is a great deal more fun than buying a new one. The other rather good thing is that you tend to develop your own style rather than follow trends, and you never meet anyone wearing the same frock.
I have been sewing all my life and growing up in the 1950s and 1960s make do and mend was a way of life, so making stuff from second hand fabric is nothing new to me. 
These pictures are a selection of my wardrobe made from old curtains, bed linen and soft furnishings. I also have a passion for patchwork which is a wonderful way to use up all of those tiny pieces of fabric you’ve had for years. With the exception of socks and undies what I wear now is made by me or secondhand…and I like it that way.
I hope you will join me and my friends on our mission, they are @justjillrosalind @vintage_dahling @slowsewmo and @clare.burnage 
If we all do our bit we can make a difference.

Two people told me in the last week that they'd shopped on a resale app for the first time, and it absolutely made my day. There's an ever-growing community online of people encouraging slower and more sustainable approaches to fashion, but hearing people try it out for the first time (and it going well) is even more exciting. 

More people are buying second hand every year, and it's pretty cool to think that talking about second hand online, wearing it to the office, and sharing pictures of preloved outfits, might contribute towards that. 

If you're someone that hasn't shopped second hand before, and are slightly apprehensive to give it a go, here's a rough list of things that you could get out of making your next clothing purchase preloved: 

💛 Contribute to a more circular economy: as soon as you see the vast quantities of clothes already available in the preloved market, it's pretty scary to think how many we continue to produce. The next clothing item you want probably already exists, and someone else is waiting to give or sell it to you.

💛 Save money: When you buy second hand, you'll pay a fraction of the cost of buying it brand new. A lot of clothing on the second hand market has only been lightly worn, or might even still have the tags on. It's sad to see, but it's a good entry-level way into second hand shopping.

💛 Support good causes: the charity retail sector has excellent stock, but you can also know that, when you shop, you're donating your money to a good cause. 

💛 Look after people and the planet: the fashion industry is currently one of the most damaging on the planet. It's resource intensive, has a huge waste problem, and the garment workers within it are very often overworked and underpaid in dangerous conditions. Switching a few purchases to second hand is a good way to lower your consumption in that industry. 

💛 Find some gems: shopping second hand opens you up to an abundance of clothing, that doesn't just come off the shop floor because it's not trendy anymore. Last season's piece out of stock? See if it's being resold. Want to find a 70s inspired dress? Why not buy the real thing!

What are we going to wear? Something we already have! 👕

Replacing that worry of "What am I going to wear for X event" with the feeling of knowing you can just wear something you've enjoyed before is pretty liberating. 

Here's a quick reminder I put together of some of the wonderful things you can get out of wearing what you already have, instead of shopping for a new wardrobe. 

I'd love to hear if you've got any ideas to add ♻️

Spring is in the air, and it's making me want to do a bit of spring cleaning this weekend. My wardrobe feels like a good place to start 🧹

This time of year, I'm usually starting to switch over my wardrobe from winter to summer. It's a valuable time to consider what was worn this winter, if my summer pieces still work for me, and whether they belong in my wardrobe.

The natural next step is a bit of a declutter - but how can I do this responsibly? 

It might be easy to think "Out of sight, out of mind" when decluttering. The reality is that our old clothes, homewares, and general knick knacks are probably all out there somewhere, and it's important to take responsibility for the stuff we decide to get rid of.

Here's five quick tips on how I try to approach a more considerate clear out. Let me know if you've got any tips to add, and save this for your next spring clean!

Same skirt, 6 outfits 📈

Once you start limiting your wardrobe to only clothes you absolutely LOVE (and not just like), it becomes pretty easy to rewear what you've already got, instead of scrambling for the next thing. The #75hardstylechallenge absolutely put this into perspective for me. The more I wore the clothes I loved, the less interested I became in shopping for something else.

A key reflection from the challenge was that there were a few clothes I wore A LOT, and a lot that I wore only a small amount. Aside from the pieces that were more occasion or season specific, it's made me want to figure out what's in those few clothes that I should be applying to everything I add to my wardrobe in the future.

What's one of your standout pieces that you wear all the time? What is it that you like about it? 

#sustainablefashion #slowfashion #rewear #outfitrepeater #outfitinspiration #ootd #oootd #fashion #thrifting #thrift #secondhand #secondhandstyle #vinted #eBay #vintedfinds

A day in the Underbanks, Stockport 🌼🌈👗🏫🏭🌸☂️

I've been up in Manchester, visiting my family, and yesterday we headed to Stockport for a day out in the Underbanks area. It was such an enjoyable trip and everyone we came across was up for a chat. Here's what we did:

We started off at the Stockport Hat Museum for a guided tour. Stockport was a centre for the felt hatting industry in the 19th century and the tour took us through the history, from the cottage industries to the industrial revolution, and the grim realities along the way. A highlight was the hat gallery at the end, showcasing hundreds of hats, historical, cultural, contemporary. I obviously wore a beret for the occasion.

Next, we walked into the Underbanks area. There's lots of colourful street art - one piece has recently popped up made out of discarded bottle caps. The 'Rediscovering the Underbanks' initiative seems to have heritage at its centre and it's great to see history being preserved alongside new businesses here. The ornate Winter's clock was restored a few years back and the market hall was bustling with traditional businesses: bakeries, veg shops, a fishmongers, a hardware store, a bottle shop. I needed a carabiner to clip onto a bottle and I could buy a single one for 35p. Loved that.

There's an impressive selection of independent businesses. Highlights for me: (1) @emikostudios for workwear inspired clothes made right there in Stockport. They felt beautifully made and I loved that you could see the name of the seamstresses that crafted them. I bought the turmeric coloured jacket. One thing I learnt about my style during the #75hardstylechallenge was that I enjoy wearing boxy shapes and earthy colours and this ticks those boxes. (2) @topofthetownvintage for true vintage pieces. I bought a blouse here but even just being in the shop to browse and chat was a delight. Highly recommend visiting if you like bright and bold vintage clothing. (3) @still.life.story for beautiful lifestyle bits - dried flowers, handmade scrunchies, soaps, candles and more. (4) @squound and (5) @20thcenturystores for eclectic homewares. 

I've run out of space, but I could go on! ❤️

Slow fashion is so much more than how and where we buy our clothes. It's about: 

(1) slowing down the pace of our fashion consumption altogether; 

(2) respecting the clothes we already own by wearing them frequently, maintaining them for longevity, and repairing them when they need it;

(3) building an understanding of where our clothes come from, how they are made, who makes them, and what the environmental and social impact of that process might be; and 

(4) letting go of clothes we no longer want in a responsible way. 

What does slow fashion mean to you?

Introducing a new member of my wardrobe: a @hades_wool alphabet scarf 🎀

This was a lovely surprise birthday gift, but I'd seen Hades' striking designs before. Hades Wool is a British knitwear brand recognisable by their bold heritage knitwear designs that are inspired by counter-culture. Beyond design aesthetics, Hades Wool is known to prioritise quality and responsible craft. The brand's scarves are made in Hawick in Scotland and they embody everything I like in a sustainable business - unique, timeless designs that are made to last, and give you confidence in where and how the products are made. Finally, the scarf is reversible. What more could I want! 

Sustainable businesses are great and I'm always looking to learn about more. If there's a small sustainable business that you love, let me know in the comments ❤️

#knitwear #wool #sustainable #sustainablebrand #sustainablefashion #slowfashion #knitted #craft #sustainability

Excitement is mounting, only two days till the launch of @curtainstocouture on 1st October.
The pictures today are taken in Abbey Gardens, our local park, I think you will agree the flower beds are looking rather beautiful.
I have decided that I needed a few plainer garments to wear with my floral coats and frocks. Over the last couple of years I seem to have acquired some nice old velvet curtains so I decided to make a little pinafore out of a small brown one. Although I made this coat dress several years out of a wonderful vintage Collier Campbell curtain I really haven’t had much to wear it with. The pattern is the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps…one of my favourite patterns.
I used my usual pinafore pattern and bound the neck and armholes with some striped cotton from my stash. I really enjoyed working with this old cotton velvet, it is a little bit faded and beautifully soft so I will definitely be making some more of my winter wardrobe from these old curtains.
The sweater is my own pattern made from a thrifted remnant.
The jeans are my usual thrifted and embroidered ones.

I took the day off today and we had a lovely trip…we started off in Beccles then continued to Bungay. Today was @blackshuckfestivalbungay and the town was buzzing, some really wonderful exhibitions and all kind of weird black dogs roaming the streets.
There were also some very nice vintage and antique shops where I found a few nice bits for the shop…good coffee and nice lunch…what’s not to like!
Today’s frock, photographed in the picturesque graveyard, is made from an old Sanderson curtain and is a pattern from the Japanese Sweet Dress Book…one of my favourite patterns.
The jacket is a recent reworking of a thrifted gingham shirt.

Today was rather exciting as it was the first time I’d been down to the South Bank for about five years, this was made even better by spending the day with Rosa and Rufus.
As you can see from the pictures we walked along by the Thames and had fun at the Tate Modern.
Sewing bit…I found a long lime green linen tunic in a charity shop several years ago, I loved the colour and fabric but it just didn’t fit into my wardrobe. I shortened it, reduced the length of the pin tucks and added some hand feather stitching in cream…it is now rather a useful little jacket that I know will get plenty of wear.
Today’s frock is a simple self drafted pinafore I recently made from some rather groovy 1960s fabric, worn over a turmeric coloured broderie anglaise petticoat.

Sadly a day late with #septembertextilelove24 but yesterday just got so busy…so I will cover introductions and colour combinations in one post.
So…my name is Marcia and I’ve been sewing and knitting since I was very young. I am a complete amateur but what I lack in technique I make up for with enthusiasm. 
My day job is antique dealer and I have a shop in Bury St Edmunds called @smokingmonkeyantiques. I love old stuff, I love things that have had a life and come with a story. This passion carries over into my textile life and I generally buy my fabrics, yarns and haberdashery secondhand. 
My current passion is for making clothes out of vintage or old fabrics which are often embellished with appliqué and embroidery…I like to see clothing as wearable art.
Sustainability is currently at the forefront of my current thinking…the statistics for fabric and clothes going into landfill are truly horrific.
Colour is something that makes me very excited, I think it’s probably got something to do with
 being brought up in the 1950s where vibrant colours were not encouraged round our way!
In this rather wind blown picture I am wearing one of my patchwork frocks, mixing colour and pattern in patchwork is such a delight as you never really know how colours will go together until you have tried.
Piecing small bits of fabric is also a great way to use some of those treasured scraps you have kept for many years.
I love the autumn and this year I am getting very excited about incorporating some of these autumnal colours into my winter wardrobe 
@seam_collective #septembertextilelove #meetthemaker #textilelove #sewover50september #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #sustainablesewing #sustainableliving #patchworkdress #handstitching

I love making frocks but to be honest I really have plenty of them, so this summer I have been making accessories to wear with them…mainly light weight jackets to wear on cooler days. So far I have made three of them and they are proving to be very useful as well as rather fun to make.
This is a frock I made several years ago from a pair of vintage Sanderson curtains, not only is the fabric very pretty, the quality is superb so it should last me for many years. 
The jacket is one I recently made from a thrifted gingham tunic, I rather like the gingham and floral mix.
I am also wearing my current favourite shoes, black patent with a big bow…a very lucky secondhand find on EBay. 
I currently have so many ideas for my autumn and winter sewing I can’t wait to start…watch this space…

I’m not sure why but I only wear pink on hot sunny days so this frock had not come out of the wardrobe this year. However today it’s going to be like summer so here’s my pink frock. I am off to the shop so I am hoping the sunshine will bring people flocking down St John’s Street.
This is some pink seersucker I found in a charity shop years ago, it is quite narrow so I think it’s got some age. The pattern is from the Sweet Dress Book by #yoshikotsukiori one of my favourite and most used patterns. I decorated the pin tucks with feather stitch and lazy daisy stitch.
The jacket is a thrifted 1980s shirt I reworked into a jacket. I love those blousy florals from the 80s and 90s.
The necklace someone made for me a few years ago and for those interested the shoes are Oxygen brand.

Yesterday was all about old yellow Sanderson curtain fabric and great company. @justjillrosalind found this yellow floral fabric and set the challenge. The first picture is @slowsewmo ,Jill and I showing off our creations. 
@clare.burnage invited us for a beautiful lunch in her Norfolk garden and a beautiful day was had by all. 
A lot of old fabric was stroked, admired and discussed…
Sadly Lisa @vintage_dahling was meant to join us but was poorly…do check out her recent post and the amazing garment she made.
My frock was based on McCall’s M8320. I mixed the floral fabric with an old yellow gingham tablecloth, a thrifted yellow shirt, two dyed doilies and stranded embroidery thread. I embroidered over the seams where two different fabrics were used to help blend the different patterns together. I wanted to make something that I thought would fit into my wardrobe well. Bring on next year’s #curtainstocouture challenge!!!

I love making patchwork and as you can see from a few of these old pictures it is not a recent passion. Apart from the frugal appeal of using up all of your odd bits of fabric, I love mixing colours and patterns.
Three unloved and unworn frocks in my wardrobe provided the main fabric for the three patchwork frocks hanging on my wardrobe. They are all basically the same pattern but each one has its own colour palette. It’s always good to use up existing fabrics in your wardrobe or stash and they are such fun to make. These can be worn all year round but as I’ve mentioned before I always feel the pink one is my summer patchwork frock.
The jacket is made from antique ticking and is a variation of the coat dress pattern in the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps…possibly my favourite and most worn jacket.
The shoes are a recent Ebay bargain…and I love them! The petticoat is a thrifted 1990s skirt.

If you’ve been hanging out here for a while (love you, btw 💕), you already know the fashion industry’s got some serious ethical and environmental baggage. But here’s the thing: fast fashion isn’t just bad for the planet, it’s hustling YOU too! These brands are cranking out rebranded trends faster than you can say “add to cart.”

And then they pay influencers and mags to convince you that the clothes you just bought *two weeks ago* are old news. So you gotta keep up, right? and give them more money 💸. This FOMO is the fast fashion trap, and the excitement fades right after you rip open that package, then it’s right back to scrolling for more. That’s a LOT of energy spent on shopping!

Here’s the truth: your can look amazing, stay true to your style, and be sustainable—all while spending way less. Forget chasing every new 15-minute trend. Wear what you love, and free your mind for way more important things!

#minimalstyle #slowfashion #sustainableliving #capsulewardrobe #sustainablefashion #secondhand #thriftedstyle 🌿

Here are some common misconceptions about sustainable fashion that I hear time and time again. Let’s clear them up, shall we?⁣

▪️“It’s too expensive”
Sure, ethical fashion is pricier compared to fast fashion, which uses cheap, low-quality materials and exploits labor to keep costs down. But affordable, sustainable options are becoming more accessible, and here’s a tip: buy fewer, high-quality pieces and care for them properly. In the long run, you’ll likely save more than you would on constant fast fashion replacements.⁣ This outfit for example is made of mostly preloved finds from @oxfamgb and @ebay_uk, mixed with new trousers from @the.revivas and @jlrlondon handbag - I guarantee that the final price tag would be very similar to most fast fashion brands.

▪️ “It’s hard to find.”
Maybe that was true years ago, but today there are countless sustainable brands worldwide. If you’re not sure where to start, follow sustainable fashion influencers like @besmacc, @andreacheong_, @saint.thrifty, @twinbrett, @izzy_manuel and @rosieokotcha. They do the research for you and offer plenty of inspiration to help you make thoughtful purchases.⁣

▪️ “One T-shirt or pair of jeans won’t make a difference” 
No one expects perfection. The idea isn’t to overhaul your wardrobe overnight but to make thoughtful changes over time. Whether that’s buying second-hand, supporting eco-friendly brands, or simply buying less, every little step helps reduce your fashion footprint.
 
▪️”Fast fashion creates jobs” 
It’s true that the fashion industry employs millions, but fast fashion thrives on unsafe, underpaid and overworked labor. If consumers shift toward ethical brands, the demand for better practices will grow, and the industry will adapt. Ethical and sustainable fashion can still provide jobs, just with better conditions and fair wages.

Now, let’s keep the conversation going: What misconceptions about sustainable fashion are you tired of hearing?

Gave my new frock an outing in Wisbech. I believe this amazing fabric is either 1960s or 1970s and it was a gift from @margaretgethin , not entirely sure why but every time I look at it I think of the Beatles Yellow Submarine. After washing it didn’t have much body so I lined it with an old cotton sheet. I wanted a nice simple pattern as this is really all about the fabric. The binding is made from a thrifted gingham shirt, the sides are a faux button fastening as this just pops over your head. There isn’t a pattern for this frock, just my usual pinafore shape. 
The petticoat is made from green cotton broderie anglaise.
We had a lovely day in Wisbech today, the church was beautiful, really elegant buildings and the garden at Peckover House was just perfect. We met some really friendly people too and on top of that the sun shone.

@sewover50 did a wonderful post about gingham makes a few days ago so I thought I’d show you a gingham frock I made a few years ago. You will probably not be surprised to know it was made from a couple of tablecloths, the pattern is from The Sweet Dress book by #yoshikotsukiori . 
I lengthened the pattern and used the brown gingham to add length and to bind the neck and armholes. The bodice tucks were embellished with feather stitch and lazy daisy stitch…I also apliqued and embroidered the pockets.
The necklaces I made from a collection of odd pearl beads.
The weather today was glorious, we started off at an antique fair at Glenham Hall, went on to have lunch and coffee at Snape Maltings…followed by a walk along the promenade at Aldeburgh…not a bad day!

3 things I'm enjoying about doing a #nobuy challenge 🫡

1. Less buying = more rewearing. Reducing the amount I'm adding to my wardrobe means the amount of wears per item is naturally going up. I feel like I'm building a more recognisable style this season, rewearing key pieces more than I might otherwise have done.

2. More experimenting with what I already have. I'm enjoying coming up with new ways to wear the same items. This skirt has made regular appearances in my daily outfits, and I'm enjoying working out all the different ways I can dress it up.

3. Resetting my consumption habits. I'd lost the power of waiting in my purchasing behaviour. I love a secondhand resale app, but the barriers to buying something have become so low recently - you can buy a cheap top secondhand almost as fast as an online fast fashion purchase. It's brilliant to see the secondhand market booming, but I lost the appreciation for waiting, planning, and thinking hard about my buys. After the challenge is up, I'm looking to build in more of these barriers going forward - maybe a low annual limit to force me to really think carefully about adding something to my wardrobe. 

Five weeks down and five weeks to go! #75hardstylechallenge

Have you ever done a #nobuy challenge? I've seen lots popping up recently and I'd love to hear what you're enjoying about it, or finding challenging.

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 7 DIY Love. As you’ve probably guessed the majority of my wardrobe is DIY so this prompt seemed a good time to show you my latest project.
I recently found this old linen shirt on the £1 rail in a local charity shop, a couple of little holes and marks but the fabric was so soft and buttery…it was probably on its way to landfill. 
I shortened it, removed the collar and cuffs and neatened all of the edges by hand. Then the fun really started. I love hand stitching, I find it very therapeutic and a very pleasant way to spend my evenings. I did the swirls around the neckline and added a patch in the middle of the back, then did a couple of apliqued swirls on the sides. I finished by changing the buttons…I just know this is going to get a lot of wear over the summers for many years. The  scraps of printed cotton, threads and buttons were all in my stash. 
The pinafore I made from a small pair of old curtains. This magnificent fabric is a 1970s Sanderson interpretation of a William Morris fabric.
There is no doubt that hand stitched garments become loved garments.
#slowfashionchallenge #sewover50 #sewover50june24 #sustainablewardrobe #sustainablesewing #upcycledclothing #upcycledfabric #embroidery #handembroidery #handstitched #secondhandstyle #secondhandisnotsecondbest #williammorrisfabric #sandersonfabric #oldladystyle #grannychic

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 13 Inspired by nature.
The coat and frocks are all made from old curtains, I think they are all Sandersons and they are all inspired by beautiful blooms. These fabrics are so beautiful with so much detail in the flowers and so many colours they would look great in a picture frame if you have any left.
The green fabric in the first picture is lined with an old flannelette sheet so it is really cosy…so you can wear your florals all year round. 
These fabrics really inspire me and I know they will remain in my wardrobe for many years.
#sewover50 #sewover50june24 # #vintagefabricaddict #vintagefabric #reusereducerecycle #upcycledfabric #slowfashion #sustainablefashion #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #imakemyclothes #vintagesanderson #sandersonfabric #floralfabric #oldladystyle #grannychic

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 14 Slow Fashion Solutions.
Well, this is a big one! Although I am an optimist by nature I am not naive and I realise there are so many different things to be done by Governments, industry and us. I can only speak for myself but I personally think the answer to adopting slow fashion is to have the confidence to develop your own personal style. This way there is no need to follow seasonal trends, whether they suit you or not. This does not mean that your wardrobe never changes, we are constantly seeing ideas that we want to incorporate into our dress, often using things we already own. If we only buy or make clothes that we love and we feel good in, we will want to keep them longer. I think the key is dressing to suit ourselves and not to impress others, it is how we feel about ourselves not what others think…I hope this makes sense.
A huge thank you to @readorn.london and @blesseddesignsco for hosting this challenge again.
Today’s photo is taken outside my shop this morning. The gingham frock is my first attempt at smocking…which was a fun project. The linen slacks are from the Lotta Jansdotter Everyday Style book. The cardigan and shoes are thrifted

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 9 Mend
This is my favourite mend on my favourite pair of jeans. I embroidered these thrifted jeans over lockdown when I had a lot of time on my hands, they took a long time to do but it was fun. Then on my first trip out after Covid I tripped down the steps at Ickworth House and took the knee out of them. The sun is coving the hole and when the other knee goes it will be a moon patch.
It might sound daft but I only wear jeans that are embellished and these are definitely one of my favourite garments. 
When I was younger mends were always discreet and the aim  was to make them invisible. I am embracing this current trend to display your repairs…as repairing your clothes is definitely something we should be proud of.

This jacket is my entry for the @sewover50 June challenge #sewwhatyouneedjune24 . During May it was still quite cool and I was looking for little unlined jackets to wear over summer frocks. Whilst foraging in the charity shops I came across an embroidered black and white gingham shirt, an awful shape but gorgeous fabric…so I turned it into this jacket. I think this gingham will look nice over summer frocks.
The pattern is a variation of the coat dress pattern from Stylish Wraps by Yoshiko Tsukiori. I had to piece together the sleeves and the frill, but this doesn’t really matter and I bound the edges with the remains of a vintage pinny. I was so pleased with the contrast that I added a couple of little patches.
Today’s frock I made several years ago and is made from a remnant of vintage cotton and the pattern is also from the 70s, Butterick 4317 but with an added frill.
