It's my third winter in this coat ❄️ 

This coat is a piece I always look forward to unearthing in the colder months, and it's a welcome reminder that rewearing my own clothes is the best way to practice slow fashion, and hone a personal style. I'm sure there'll be many more winters in it.

In case you missed it, I'm doing the #75hardstylechallenge, which involves not buying any clothes (including secondhand) for 75 days, along with some other rules. Like many slow fashion enthusiasts that discover the endless possibility of buying old clothes, I've gone from once buying new, to hardly buying any clothes, to buying only secondhand, to then seeing my consumption slowing tick up again. In part, I attribute this to enjoying the journey of searching for, finding and curating a secondhand wardrobe, socialising through fun secondhand fashion events and markets, and having so much secondhand fashion available at my fingertips through resale apps. On the other hand, I definitely open up a resale app if I've had a stressful day, or for no reason at all, except to search for something and buy it - the barriers are much lower when secondhand clothes can be quite cheap.

In recent months the result has been that I've found myself less interested in styling what I already own, instead focused on finding new (old) stuff for the sake of it. I've found less joy in fashion, and have been inching further away from my goal of enjoying fashion in a slow and sustainable way.

I'm hoping this challenge is the kick up the bum I need to stop gathering new clothes, becoming reinspired with creating new outfits and getting more wear out of what I already own. Meanwhile, I want to practice what I preach by enjoying slow fashion in the ways I know how, without buying stuff. This might be learning new skills to look after my clothes, helping other to find secondhand clothes who want to reduce buying new, and engaging with slow fashion advocates.

I'd love to hear if you have goals of your own this year 👂

Today was when of those days that I stood in front of my wardrobe and didn't know what I wanted to wear. One rule in the #75hardstylechallenge is to minimise the use of external resources to get outfit inspiration (for example, looking up outfit ideas on Pinterest) to encourage more consideration for your own personal style. 

I took a leaf out of @oldloserinbrooklyn 's book and looked back through my own outfit photos for inspiration. This denim jacket caught me eye - around this time last year I was in Budapest, wearing it as a layering piece (swipe to see!). I love how it breaks up an outfit and sits comfortably under a winter coat. I  imagine it'll make it into lots of outfits over the next couple of months of the challenge.

Outfit details ~
Jacket: @ebay 
Top, coat and scarf: @vinted 
Trousers: 6 months old, bought new

On day 16 of the #75hardstylechallenge, I've reflected on the fact that, over the past year or two, I've started to prioritise buying and wearing clothes that are durable and made of natural materials, and that will keep me properly warm/cool as needed. A few years ago, I'd get some good eye rolls over Christmas when I'd go out for a hike with my family in a faux fur leopard print coat. I've since learnt from enough cold and wet days and blistered feet that it's worth investing in a suitable rain jacket and some shoes I can actually walk a few miles in.

Today's outfit was a wool skirt, wool jumper and wool scarf to keep me warm, paired with my very light coloured trench coat that has it's ups and downs in terms of practicality. It has a wool button-in lining that means I can wear it all year round, but the back of the coat gets dirty pretty quickly if it's puddly outside (which seems to be most of the time). Surprisingly though, it does pretty well being thrown in the washing machine for a quick spin, and it's survived 4 years of that now!

I'm interested to hear if you have any priorities when you buy new clothes.

Outfit details~
Jumper and skirt: @vinted 
Coat: @asosmarketplace 
Bag: 2 years old

The secondhand market is set for remarkable growth, projected to nearly double in value by 2027, reaching an impressive $350 billion globally.

I’d like to think that the driving force behind this boost is a much-needed shift in consumer behaviours, where sustainability takes the lead and the timeless allure of secondhand and vintage is attracting younger audiences. However, if we’re being realistic, fast fashion is set to double in size by 2029 and is forecasted to reach a value of $80 billion. That’s quite a contrast.

This video, captured by the brilliant @chemiteijanet at the Gikomba Market in Nairobi, shows the reality of what happens with the unwanted clothes donated by the global north. The used, and very often brand new, clothes found at the market come from fast, ultra-fast, and even sustainable brands. Many still have tags from charity shops like Oxfam, Value Village, Goodwill, etc. There’s no proper waste collection or management system, so most of the waste is left lying around. Tailors situated close to the river dump this waste on the banks, which often ends up in the river.

🌿 So my take is: keep buying secondhand! That’s not where the problem lies, and anyone pointing fingers elsewhere but at fast fashion is wrong. They’re deflecting and trying to justify their own unethical shopping behaviour. However, I’d love to know your thoughts – should we also be conscious and not overconsume secondhand items either?

When asked why do you make upcycled clothing, sustainable, recycled, thrift flipped, vintage garments, there’s lots of good reasons, in fact there are lots of facts about how bad fast fashion is but also I make them because I love vintage textiles and I think the outfits I make look cute. Style without contributing to the global impact of textile waste, winner. 💫🌿🧡#vintagefinds #thriftedfashion #vintageclothing #thriftfinds #vintagestyle #summerfashion2023 #sustainablefashion #upcycledclothing #fashionfinds #upcycledfashion #reusereducerecycle

Returns from fast fashion purchases contribute to a shocking 5 billion pounds of waste every year, but the environmental toll doesn’t stop there. Every return involves transportation, packaging, and processing, all of which require resources and contribute to carbon emissions. When items are ultimately discarded, they often contain synthetic fibers like polyester that take hundreds of years to break down. 

So what can we do? By making more thoughtful decisions about what we buy - buying secondhand, choosing quality over quantity, supporting sustainable brands or simply asking ourselves if we really need that extra pair of jeans, we can reduce the demand for fast fashion and its wasteful returns cycle 💕✨

#SecondHandStyle #ThriftShopping #SustainableFashion

That’s exactly what fast fashion wants you to believe. They rake in billions by convincing you that you need to speed up your shopping habits, constantly increasing the frequency of your purchases.

But here’s the kicker: trying to keep up with slow fashion at the same pace as fast fashion is downright impossible. Slow fashion lies in shifting your mindset from QUANTITY to QUALITY ✨ It’s not just about buying clothes; it’s about valuing the process and the product.

Here are some tips to switch from fast to slow fashion without spending a penny:

🌿 Delete Shopping Apps: If this idea worries you, ask yourself why. Are you really in control of your shopping habits, or are they controlling you?

🌿 Unfollow Fast Fashion Influencers: Don’t forget that influencers are businesses too, they also make money by selling you stuff you don’t need. Surround yourself with inspiration that aligns with your values.

🌿 Be Mindful of New Purchases: Don’t give your money away to companies that don’t align with your values. Consider who made who made your clothes, how much they were paid, and who benefits for your dough!

And even though the algorithm will still tempt you with clever marketing, once you go slow, you’ll see the difference on how you react to it 💕

A few days in Poole ☀️🐚 It’s absolutely no secret that @lush is one of my favourite brands all around, and I’m beyond honoured to be included in their press trip. Last week, we had the chance to visit one of their suppliers to learn even more about the behind-the-scenes of their production chain and the company’s philosophy 🌿 |gifted press trip| 

🫐 Visiting the UK’s oldest blueberry farm, where LUSH sources the blueberries for many of their products, including the Catastrophe Cosmetic face mask - a personal fave. This farm isn’t just historic; it’s also Soil Association certified Organic, maintaining high standards for environmental stewardship.

🪶 Birdwatching wasn’t really on my bingo card for things I’d thoroughly enjoy doing, but here we are! We took a boat ride with @birdsofpooleharbour, a charity completely dedicated educating people on the stunning variety of bird life in one of the country’s most picturesque locations, helping you make the most of this truly breathtaking natural harbour.

🌿 Sustainable OOTD: a rare non-thrifted combo with @organicbasics tee, @elwinstudio skirt from @percy.langley and @veja trainers.

💄The Fresh department at the factory that looks more like a kitchen than anything else - and I’m so here for it!

🍉 The Watermelon soap!! 100% of the profits will be donated solely to projects providing urgently-needed professional mental health support and trauma counselling for children in Gaza and the West Bank. 

#veganbeauty #lush #ecofriendly #slowliving #sustainability

This time last year I made a video about how bad my shopping habits were despite shopping secondhand. I kind of made a pledge to myself that I would change and not buy as much.

Did it work? The amount I've been spending on Vinted and in charity shops has certainly changed and I'm still cherishing the pieces in my wardrobe I was loving from previous years.

I've had this coat for 2 years and I still get so much joy from rewearing it.

 Black Friday can throw all these sparkly shiny deals at you, but realistically you don't neeeeeed a brand new coat. The one you already have is just fine. If it's not why not try shopping one secondhand. There are tonnes on Vinted and other reselling platforms and I got this one for £1 at a charity shop so you more than likely will find bigger bargains than the Black Friday "deals" if you look in your local ones.

Happy Halloween! Some things I tried on and liked this month, mostly small independent, a few high street, secondhand and duty free airport too, a real mixed bag! A few I’ve purchased but all so great and worth sharing with you 😊 

1. @howlinknitwear via @mercantilelondon - I’m not the biggest cat fan but a HUGE fan of this wool knit, lovely quality and such a fun design 
2. @louisemisha via @mercantilelondon - the collar on this is so sweet, a fairly new brand to me but I’m liking their current selection
3. @lfmarkey via @mercantilelondon - I love LF Markey pieces and this top is gives that colour hit we all need right now, the tones are quite different too, comes as a dress and has matching trousers 
4. @louisemisha via @mercantilelondon - Louise Misha seem to be experts at cute collars 
5. @stellanovacopenhagen via @mercantilelondon - another quirky, fun, collector’s Stella piece, great layered or on its own
6. cos denim top - on sale and the last one in store, a UK 16 but it kind of works super oversize I think 
7. cos navy knitted waistcoat - this is so much like the one my grandad wears so I had to give it a try 
8. @aligne via @anthropologie - I’ve seen these online before and liked the concept and it didn’t disappoint IRL, the shape is super flattering and a nice change to my go to oversize fits
9. @anthropologieeu faux leather trousers - great shape and very warm for winter
10. Taking a break to show you the OOTD from this try on session! 
11. @americanvintage_officiel fleece gilet - a classic piece from this brand and very versatile too, I tried on about four different colours, worn here with my @kindredofireland linen dress
12. @ganni x @barbour via @pavement_store_london - one of the new jackets from the collab, I love the colour and wax jackets are just an absolute classic 
13. The newer cropped version of last year’s Ganni x Barbour collab 
14. @cosstores via @sheltershops - best charity shop find in a while! 100% wool and in excellent condition 
15. @desigual coat - spotted this at the airport, denim trench is an interesting concept! 

#londonclothing #sustainablefashion #smallfashionbrand #independentfashion #secondhandstyle #scandifashion

I hope you love my @themarconcourtproject blouse design as much as I do! I’ve been wearing it non stop and can certify it’s the comfiest cutest blouse 🥰🎀

Our Handmade oversized wrap peplum blouses are available in white and pink with a cute red ricrac trim. Made from 100% cotton poplin which makes this comfortable and airy to wear ❤️🙌🏽

The wrap design with adjustable ties means you can wear the blouse to fit as you like. Made with love in London, Laura and I really put our heart into perfecting the fit, proportions and shape 🥹

These blouses are designed to be forever pieces, we think it’s a timeless design to see us through all seasons of life and the ever uniquely changing shapes of our bodies as women. This would easily work as a maternity top for example! Available in UK sizes 4-30 🧵🪡 

Available to shop from tomorrow (3rd August) on @themarconcourtproject website and worldwide shipping is available.

Where has the time gone?! There's hardly any pictures in my camera roll for the second half of 2023 and it's probably been the year I've posted the least since I started this account. Looking back though, there's been some wonderful real-life moments in the world of slow fashion and sustainability. Here's part 1/2 of 10 pictures that reflected my year in slow fashion:

1. Another year of asking my friends and family to 'please take a photo of my outfit': this was my favourite outfit picture of the year. I felt thrifty and fashionable with my layered jacket and overcoat 🤠

2. A lunch with eBay: it was such a pleasure to be invited to a lunch with @ebay_uk to learn more about the preloved partnership with Love Island. It's been so exciting seeing secondhand fashion blend even more into the mainstream. This event was also special though because it was one of the first times I met lots of other fashion bloggers and content creators in person cc @easypeasysustainability @izzy_manuel @anishakalsi @the_oluwaseun @bethlucyblogs and others 💚

3. A little bit of crafting: an afternoon spent making a crochet bag with @kimranacrochet. This was such a fun workshop and it reminded me how much joy I get from making something with my own hands and learning a new skill. More crafting and creativity in 2024 🤞

4. Finding new ways to shop secondhand with friends: this year I explored new modes of secondhand shopping, and made some lovely days out from it. One of the highlights was two visits to @the.reloved.club with @thethriftyedit_ 😊

5. Interrailing: in May I embarked on a flight free trip around Europe, half solo and half with friends and family. It reminded me how easy it can be to get about by train when you've got enough time. I loved mapping out the journey and seeing how far I could get without boarding a plane 🚂

The aim was to spotlight this charity shop mac, but it's been slightly overshadowed by the backdrop behind me 🌸💙

I wanted to reshare this collarless mac that I bought for a few quid from the Scope in Hackney Central four years ago, around the time I started posting my outfits online. I didn't recognise the label at the time, and it's since fallen off from how much I've worn this. It's one of those pieces I get into a rapid rewearing cycle with and then retire for a few months. It's currently back in circulation and it makes any basic outfit feel a little more interesting, with its wide cropped sleeves and big buttons. For all the ease of searching for secondhand clothes on a resale app, it can never beat the feeling of finding a gem in a good chazza shop.

What's your favourite charity shop? Let's take a moment to celebrate them below!! 

Outfit~
Jacket: @scopecharityshops
Blouse and jeans: @vinted

#secondhandstyle #slowfashionstyle #slowfashion #slowfashionblogger #slowfashionfind #chazzashop #chazzashopfind #charityshop #charityshopfind #thriftstore #scopestyle

Grinning because I think I've found my autumn uniform - and it's all secondhand 🍂🍁

Do you know the feeling when you wear an outfit that makes you feel like 'you'? I think I tie a lot of self-expression to the clothes I wear, so when I wore this outfit and it felt just right, I made a mental note to rewear it again and again. 

There's something about developing a 'uniform' like wardrobe that I think helps to develop a recognisable personal style. It felt like a win for me when my Dad once pointed to a woman wearing a beret and said, 'that's you!' Besides feeling stylish, I think developing a seasonal uniform helps me to slow down my consumption. If I know I've got a reliable base outfit to fall back on that I know makes me feel good, my wardrobe doesn't feel 'empty' or lacking when a surprise event pops up or there's a seasonal change. I've fallen back on this outfit a few times in different variations over the past two weeks and I can keep going.

I'd love to hear if you've developed a uniform, and how you feel about 'personal style'? It's something I'm still working on! 

Outfit~
Coat: @scopecharityshops
Denim shirt: from my friend Eliza ♻️
Skirt and bag: @vinted

#slowfashion #slowfashionmovement #slowfashionstyle #oootd #discoverunder10k #fashionblog #slowfashionblog #minimalist #minimalistwardrobe #minimalism #charityshops #charityshopfind #vinted #vintedfinds

Closing out 2023 with part 2/2 of 10 highlights for me in slow fashion and sustainability for 2023. It's been a quiet year on my account, but it's been sweet to look back on some small moments that I hope to do more of in 2024: 

1. Finally cracking capsule dressing: living out of a small suitcase for 5 weeks on my interrail trip gave me a renewed appreciation for having less stuff. I had to think hard about how to pack a small wardrobe that would be both practical and interesting enough to keep me going for 5 weeks, and it inspired me to keep practising having less when I returned back to my full wardrobe at home. More rewearing and not buying new in 2024 🤞

2. Tackling 'outfit panic': I went to the Henley Regatta for the first time in 2023, and pulled together an outfit slowly and thoughtfully, rather than collapsing into last minute outfit panic and buying new. A themed or dress coded event usually tests my slow fashion strength, but thinking ahead and focusing on what I already had meant I could avoid that stress. I'd like to lean on this outfit again in 2024 💚

3. The rise of charity retail: I attended a panel discussion hosted by @the_bhf on the rise of charity retail this year. It's incredible to see the growth of preloved shopping against mainstream retail, and events like these always leave me feeling inspired and motivated to keep spotlighting the sector ❤️

4. New ways to wear secondhand: my focus has always been on secondhand fashion clothing, and I don't usually mention other ways in which I wear secondhand. This year I completed a 3-day cycling tour from Lille to Brussels, and needed a few more pieces of kit to wear over the trip. I found this jersey from Rapha (with tags!) on @vinted for a fraction of the price. Always worth checking secondhand first before buying new 🚲

5. The Thriftify Thrift-Off: the last event of the year I attended was the @thriftify Thrift-Off final. There was a panel discussion, a catwalk, a mini pop-up shop and more. It was an absolute blast and another opportunity to be surrounded by other content creators, bloggers, thrifters and slow fashion advocates for an evening 💜 Looking forward to more of this in 2024 🤞

Saying goodbye to summer by sharing the secondhand outfits that didn't make it to the grid this season 👋⛅️👒

The summer to autumn wardrobe switchover might be my favourite time of year for fashion...anyone else!? I'm so ready to 'shop my own wardrobe' and rediscover what I thrifted last year 🤪

#slowfashion #slowfashionfits #slowfashionoutfits #slowfashionseptember #secondhandseptember #secondhandfashion #fashionblogger #discoverunder10k
#charityshopfind #thriftshopping

How to get reinspired by your own wardrobe:

1. Download Pinterest and force yourself to recreate outfits you fancy with clothes you've already got. Ignore when the outfit isn't an exact replica (you've made it your own).

2. Lend out your lesser worn clothes to your mates and get jealous when they make a jazzy outfit from them and then politely ask for them back (immediately wear yourself).

3. Store away your out of season clothes so every time the weather changes you feel like a youtuber unboxing your summer haul.

All jokes aside, we're so encouraged to buy more, that we forget about the abundance of clothes we already have. The above actually help me to keep interested in my own wardrobe and keep the inspiration flowing when the *I have nothing to wear* kicks in. 

Outfit~
Shirt: Piazza Agosto VIII market, Bologna
Jeans: @vinted 

#alowfashion #slowfashionblogger #slowerliving #slow-moving #consciousfashion #rewearingiscaring #Pinterest #pinterestoutfit

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 3 World Environment Day….this is such a vast topic but today I am restricting myself to one aspect of sustainable or slow fashion. 
In case you are wondering this is me in 2018 rummaging for pre loved textiles to make into clothes. The picture was taken several years ago @vintagemischief in Beccles, Suffolk. Those of you who know me will know this is my favourite way to find fabric, there is already a vast amount of fabric out there, both already made into items and some that has just been languishing in storage for years. Please don’t think I am suggesting you shouldn’t buy new this is just my preferred way of doing things. 
There are many things I like about old fabrics, some of the designs and patterns are really out there but it’s the feel of a fabric that has been laundered many times that I love…often so soft and buttery. If there are little stains or flaws it is a great excuse for a spot of embellishment.
The environmental impact of fast fashion is staggering and using fabric that is already in the system is just one way to reduce our impact…plus it is enormous fun to hunt down and sew with. From a financial point of view it can also be easy on the pocket.
#slowfashionchallenge #sewover50 #sewover50june24 #sustainablesewing #slowsewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #upcycledfashion #upcycledfabric #vintagefabricaddict #vintagefabric

caption:
Well it’s Day 1 of @slowfashionchallenge hosted by @readorn.london and @blesseddesignsco and its introductions today.
My name is Marcia, I’m 72 and by day I am an antique dealer. This is the job I have always wanted, but until I retired 10 years ago I always did sensible jobs so now is my time to have fun. My shop, @smokingmonkeyantiques is in Bury St Edmunds and it feels like my second home.
Something I feel passionately about is the importance of the High Street. For centuries the high street has been an important place for social interaction and in times of rising mental health issues and loneliness I think that it is critical that we support  our local shops if we want them to survive.
Although I love sewing, in particular making clothes, I am aware of the environmental impact of fast fashion. The vast majority of my clothes are made from thrifted or vintage fabrics…not only is this far more fun but I prefer to use fabrics that are already in the system and that otherwise could end up in landfill. I really enjoy hand stitching and decorating my clothes with appliqué and embroidery.
Other things I love are cafes that serve good coffee, going to antique fairs, playing with my old doll houses and days out with family and friends.
This is me outside my shop wearing clothes all made from thrifted fabrics, the coat is made from old tablecloths.
#slowfashionchallenge2024 #slowfashionchallenge #sustainablefashion #sustainability #sustainabilitymatters #supportthehighstreet #sewover50 #sewover50june24 #imakemyclothes

Almost the end of #memademay2024 and this is my memade selection for the month, there’s a couple of days missing…but you’ll get a general idea of my sartorial style.
What I don’t make I generally buy secondhand and the majority of my clothes are made from secondhand fabrics…mainly old soft furnishings. As much as I love clothes I do try and mainly use fabrics that are already in the system.
As always it is an absolute joy to see what everyone is making and wearing, and taking inspiration from some fabulous outfits.
Thank you so much @sozoblog for hosting #memademay 
#sewover50 #sewover50may #lovedclotheslastlonger #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #sustainablesewist #upcycledclothing #upcycledfabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic #oldladystyle

#memademay2024 day 3 and the weather has reverted to dull and wet but decent coffee and a day at the shop sounds good to me.
There are so many good things about sewing your own clothes and one of these benefits is that you build up a stash of bits of fabric. These can be left over from other projects over the years, bits found in charity shops and bits that friends give you. One of my favourite things to do with these is make patchwork garments…you will probably see several of these over the next month. They really are such fun to make and a great way to use up small bits of fabric.
I made this frock several years ago from tartans and florals, it’s a simple pinafore shape with front button fastening to flaunt your petticoats.
The cardigan is from the 1980s, I found this in a charity shop about 25 years ago…and I still love it.
The coatigan was made many years ago from a cabled knit fabric using New Look 6514…a really useful garment.
The petticoat is made from some wide broderie anglaise found on EBay.
#memademay #sewover50 #sewover50may #patchwork #patchworkdress #slowsewing #fairislefriday #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #dopaminedressing #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #secondhandisnotsecondbest #lovedclotheslastlonger #grannycore #oldladystyle #tartan

#memademay2024 day 9 and I’m road testing my new gingham frock at Stowe Gardens near Buckingham. As you may have gathered we have spent a few days in the Cotswolds and we dropped by Stowe on our drive home…just check out this amazing shell grotto.
This frock started with an old gingham table cloth and a couple of remnants from my stash. This is a shape I’ve made many times but I really like it and they are so comfortable and easy to wear all year round. Great for winter layering or nice and cool in warmer weather.
The only shaped pattern pieces are the bodice, the skirt can be made as long or as full as you like. It doesn’t need to have buttons down the front, but I think if you are wearing it over slacks or petticoats a button fastening is nice.
The armholes, neck and fronts are all neatened with binding, I generally prefer binding to facings.
The aplique and embroidery is to hide red wine stains I didn’t notice till I’d attached the skirt!
I just know I will get lots of wear out of this frock.
#memademay #ginghamdress #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #imakemyclothes #upcycledfabric #handmadewardrobe #ilookmyage #grannycore #recycledfabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #nothingwasted #oldladystyle

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 5 Summer Style.
For me personally I love a big frock and a nice basket and if the sun is shining a sun hat and parasol.
This photo was taken yesterday at Flatford Mill and as you can see it wasn’t a bright sunny day and further layers were required. I find unlined jackets and coats made from cotton or linen really useful for the British summer…so this is probably how I will be dressed for most of June and beyond.
I do love a pretty basket and they are so useful for carrying what you need for a day out. This one I’ve had for years and it was really looking sorry for itself. I relined it, added new handles and pimped it up a bit including pom-poms…as you do.
The pinafore frock is made from a vintage remnant and a huge gingham tablecloth. I tend to wear pinafores as they can be used all year round and are great layering garments.
The coat is an old mattress cover and the pattern is the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps.
The petticoat, shoes and tee shirt were all thrifted.

I was really taken with this ivy covered derelict shed in Winchcombe, and everywhere is just so lush and green.

It is worn with my usual embroidered jeans and thrifted tea shirt.
The sun is shining again today and we are off to Cheltenham…can’t wait.

#memademay2024 day 18 and this is me looking pleased with myself after a good few days in the shop. I’ve sold enough to warrant going to an antique fair tomorrow…and yes I am excited.
Believe it or not this is my entry for #magamsewalong Minimal May, and the reason is this is just made from one fabric with no embellishment. 
These thin coats are really useful in an English summer, they give a bit of warmth and seem to finish an outfit off nicely.
This fabric started out as five thrifted cafe tablecloths, washed many times so they are beautifully soft. The pattern is my old favourite, the coat dress pattern from Stylish Wraps by Yoshiko Tsukiori.
As you can see I cut the button bands and pockets on the bias, and I’m quite pleased with the result. To add a bit of weight and structure to the skirt I added three rows of tucks. The buttons are from my stash.
This is worn over a thrifted tee shirt and simple linen pinafore I made many years ago.
Thank you to @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @lizhaywood3754 for hosting this challenge

#memademay2024 day 12 and the sun is still shining. In my opinion one of the nicest way to spend a sunny Sunday is walking round a field finding stock for @smokingmonkeyantiques …so today we went to Woodbridge where @debenevents we’re organising a vintage market. Apart from the opportunity to find stock, and a few little things for me, these events are such lovely social occasions.
Today’s frock is one I made several years ago from a wonderful piece of vintage Sanderson fabric, sadly it was only a small piece but I fell in love with the colours and patterns. The pattern is from the Sweet Dress Book by Yoshiko Tsukiori. Idyed some old cotton lace and used this to help lengthen the frock, I have included some pictures to show you how I did this.
This first picture is taken with Vicky and Andy of @debenevents , Vicky is a very good upholsterer and her cushions are beautiful and definitely worth checking out.

#memademay2024 and I’m trying to wear things from my wardrobe I haven’t worn for a while.
This coat is one of those garments. I made it a couple of years ago and like many of us I don’t just sew to make clothes, I sew because I love the process. This started off with part of a sample book a friend gave me, they were all so pretty that I had to use them. 
The pattern is yet another Lotta Jansdotta Pilvi coat made from a piece of thrifted ticking. As you can see I had a lot of fun with the appliqué and hand stitching. If you are interested in the embroidery I have included some closeups of the coat.
This gingham frock I made many years ago from an old tablecloth. The scarf is recently thrifted.

Unbox & try on 3 new @kindredofireland pieces with me 

The most exciting, most beautiful delivery ever 💕 my favourite Irish linen brand has delivered once again, after visiting their London pop up earlier this summer I had a long wishlist and these were my top 3. The two dresses are bespoke one of a kind, I had a couple of ideas about a variation/different colourway to two of the brand’s existing styles and Kindred made my dreams come true and have absolutely exceeded all my expectations. 

Also a moment please for their ingenious designs - many of their pieces can be worn both ways round and hopefully you can appreciate this clever design detail in the dresses in this reel. 

All my Kindred clothing pieces are wear forever, high quality, sustainable, beautifully crafted investment pieces I will treasure for a lifetime. Now I need to know which one is your favourite? I don’t think I can choose, I am totally head over heels in love with them all ❤️

Our Handmade leopard print forever dress is open for orders! 100% cotton poplin. The wrap design with adjustable ties means you can wear the dress to fit as you like. 👗🐆💕

These are designed to be forever dresses, we think it’s a timeless design to see us through all seasons of life and the ever uniquely changing shapes of our bodies as women. This would easily work as a maternity dress for example! Available in UK dress sizes 4-30 🧵🪡 

The pink and yellow stripe maxi dresses and our new mini length floral and leopard print dresses are available to shop now on @themarconcourtproject website and worldwide shipping is available.

Three twinning looks in @fifiandthefleas 

(AD/PR) How beautiful are these patchwork floral jackets?! When I first met Emilie, founder of Fifi & the Fleas, earlier this year I think the first thing I said to her was how much I would LOVE an adult version of these incredible children’s jackets she hand makes. Fast forward a few months and she’s done exactly that and now I’m twinning with my littlest love. Emilie uses preloved, vintage and deadstock materials on all her creations making these pieces even more special and the patchwork florals and scalloping on these are just so intricate and detailed. You can shop ready to wear on childrens and adult sizes or go bespoke and let Emilie work her magic and create you something one of a kind and truly beautiful 🥰 

#sustainablefashion #smallfashionbrand #handmadejacket #handquilting #upcycledclothing #recycledfashion #twinningoutfits #mumstyle

Styling the perfect white tee

(AD/PR) @ivy_thebrand is THE brand for all your staple tees and tops. Whether it’s fitted, loose, cropped, cuffed, light/mid/heavyweight, whatever you’re looking for they have got it and they have PERFECTED it. The quality of these organic cotton pieces is incredible too and they are built to last in your wardrobe. 

In this reel I’m styling three different white tees and showing how you how you can take a plain white top and incorporate it with your existing pieces to create some fun looks. Ivy also make my favourite Breton striped tops, as well as dresses and sweatshirts too, I’m so happy to know I will never need to look anywhere else for staples like these.

Rewear, restyle, repeat all year round 🙌 

I’m not a believer in a seasonal wardrobe, I keep all my pieces in my wardrobe all the time and I don’t rotate pieces in and out each season. Anything I buy needs to have all year round wearability and the potential to be styled in lots of different ways. For me it has been a really good rule to help me make better choices about what I include into my wardrobe and to really ensure that it is something I will wear and reach for lots. 2 days in Paris 🇫🇷🖼👗🥐

The last destination on my interrail trip was Paris. It was my third time visiting and an inevitable pitstop before getting my Eurostar home, so I wasn't necessarily expecting it to be one of my favourite solo trips - but it absolutely was!  Two full days of art galleries, tasty food, cracking the metro and a lot of thrifting was just what I needed to round off a wonderful five weeks.

The thrifting was outstanding, so this list comes first. My favourite spots (with thanks to @easypeasysustainability for sharing some of these in a Paris guide!) were:
Troc en Stock - 6 rue Clauzel
Preloved by CrushOn - Carrousel du Louvre
Vintage Dèsir - 32 Rue des Rosiers
Mamz'Elle Swing - 35 bis Rue du Roi de Sicile
Free 'P' Star - 93 Rue de la Verrerie
Bobby - 89 Rue Réaumur
BIS Boutique Solidaire - 7 Bd du Temple
Celia Darling - 5 Rue Henry Monnier
Debardeuse - 16 Rue la Bruyère

Alongside the thrifting, I loved wandering Le Merais, with a well recommended lunch stop at Las du Falafel and Fulvio for dinner (thank you @elizaperi for the tip and for many more for future Paris trips). I also visited Musee d'Orsay and Musee de l'orangerie, which were perfect to wander as a solo traveller. 

I'll be back!

Thrifty formal wear 👗🚣‍♀️ 

I dressed up for the Henley Regatta this weekend and here's how I put together a fully thrifted outfit! 

I went interrailing last month and in Paris I went to this vintage shop in Le Merais that was full of so many gems. I was very taken with this light green tailored dress and whilst I don't go to dressy events very often, I thought this would be a gorgeous piece to add to my wardrobe ready for an occasion where I wanted to feel a bit chic. It wasn't a perfect fit but for 10 euros I thought I'd get it professionally tailored. I've got some sewing machine skills but I was worried I'd mess this one up.

I finished off the outfit with a bag I got for 2 euros from the same shop and for shoes I wore these secondhand Russell and Bromley fisherman sandals. These retail for £195 but I got a nearly new pair from Vinted for £35.

This was the full outfit. I felt comfy and dressed up, but most of all pleased to do a dressy event in full secondhand. I'd love to know what you think about it!!

#bologna #bolognatravel #secondomano #vintage #vintagemarket #vintagevibes #thrifted #thriftfinds #sustainablefashion #sustainability #vintagemarket #fleamarket #fleamarkets #fleamarketfinds #fleamarketfind #vintagemarketdays #vintagemarkets #slowfashionblogger #ecofriendly #slowfashionfinds #slowfashionoutfit #slowfashionstyle #Italytravel #summervibes #italyfashion #italia #italiabella #italianfashion

Here’s the thing: Fast fashion thrives on making you believe you need to keep buying more, faster. But sustainable fashion isn’t just about swapping brands - it’s about shifting how we think. It’s about quality over quantity.

Yes, ethical fashion can cost more upfront, but here’s the key: buying fewer, well-made pieces and taking care of them. Over time, this approach not only saves money but also reduces waste and supports a more responsible fashion industry. 

Affordable, sustainable brands are popping up everywhere and it’s so easy to make the switch without breaking the bank. Let’s normalize choosing pieces that last, tell a story, and make us proud of what we wear 💚

What’s your go-to tip for shopping more sustainably?

 #SustainableFashion #EthicalStyle #SlowFashionMovement #QualityOverFastFashion #ConsciousConsumer #AffordableSustainability

La Rossa, La Dotta, La Grassa ❤️👩‍🎓🍽 (the red one, the learned one, the fat one)

On my second return to Bologna post Erasmus, I connected less with La Dotta element and spent most of my time exploring the terracotta streets and eating the rich food. Italian food might be my favourite and I think Bologna comes out on top for me. If you've never visited, I'd recommend adding this Emilia-Romanian gem to your travel list. Here's some highlights from my trip and a few bonus tips:

Where to eat and drink:
☕️🥐 I don't think I've ever had a bad coffee in Italy, but some personal favourites are @bottegaportici for a coffee and pastry with a view of the famous due torri, @scuderialivinglab for a cool coffee and @principebologna for somewhere outside the walls with the best pistachio brioche.
🍽 🍕Osteria Broccaindosso for tasty food and warm service, @osteria_dellorsa for a quick and casual lunch in a bustling space (be prepared to queue at peak times, but it'll go quick) and @osteriaal15 for traditional cuisine with a familial feel (recommended to book ahead). For quick and cheap takeaway pizza slices, see Pizzeria Due Torri. Salumeria Simone is a great stop if wine, cheese and cured meats are your thing. 
🫒🍷 For aperitivo drinks and snacks paired with a bit of people watching, explore the bars around Santo Stefano (for non-drinkers, these bars also did some of the best non-alcoholic cocktails I'd had for a while!). For a more animated vibe and some apericena (more substantial snacks with your drinks) I'd recommend the bars on Via Pratello.
🍨🍦For gelato, try Cremeria Cavour and La Sorbetteria Castiglione.

👣⛪️👗Things to do: I promise there's plenty to do that isn't eating! For thrifting, head to the market in Piazza VIII Agosto on Friday's and Saturday's (with smaller pop-ups throughout the week). Walk outside the walls (or take the tourist train) up to the Santuario Madonna di San Luca - the walk is around 3 miles long through the longest portico from Porta Saragozza - see views of the countryside, the city and the stadium along the way. Wander the portici in the streets and visit Piazza Maggiore and Neptune's fountain. Climb Asinelli tower for a bird's view.

2 days in Turin 🍝👗🚊

By the penultimate stop on my interrail trip I fancied doing something a bit more organised. The highlight of my stay in Turin became my experience taking part in a cookery class with Le Cesarine. I've always wanted to do an Italian cookery class (if I love to eat it, why not learn how to make it?) but I'd always been put off by slightly more technical culinary courses. I fancied learning a recipe or two in a casual setting and came across this program on Air BnB (though I believe it's available on other platforms too).

The Cesarine program was founded in 2004 in collaboration with the Association for the Guardianship and Protection of the Traditional Culinary-Gastronomic Heritage of Italy and sees passionate Italian cooks opening up their homes and kitchens to visitors to learn about local foods and cooking techniques. Along with 3 other visitors, we learnt how to prepare focaccia for an aperitivo, tagliarini ai ragu and agnolotti con burro e salvia for mains, and tirimasu for dessert. A scheduled 3 hour class went on for over 6 hours, ending late with us happy, stuffed with good food we'd prepared together and full of knowledge on how to bring those recipes back with us. I'd recommend looking it up if you want to learn more about preparing Italian food whilst on your travels, especially if you are travelling solo like me and fancy a different interaction for your evening.

After such a rich evening, the rest of my time in Turin was pretty slow going, but other highlights for me were the following:

👗Usato Firmato Turino Centro: A highly curated secondhand store and one of the best I've visited in a while, featuring vintage, Ganni, Ralph Lauren and more. I spent ages scanning through the racks, though I didn't take anything away with me.

🍽Fiori e Caffè: A bustling spot for a set menu lunch amongst locals.

🌳Giardini Reali di Torino: A pleasant place to sit in a deckchair in the palace gardens and recover from the food coma from the night before.

#interrail #interraileu #interrailtips #interrailplan #interrail2023 #italy #italia #italiansummer #turin #torino #Italytravel #flightfree #lecesarine #italianfood #ciboitaliano #slowtravel

What’s better than a head to toe @lebonshoppe outfit?

(AD/PR) I’m so happy and honoured to be repping my favourite sustainable brand from across the pond. Le Bon Shoppe has become a firm favourite of mine, you know how much I love their colourful socks but I have also become the biggest fan of their clothing too and they are now absolute classics which will always have a place in my wardrobe. 

Le Bon Shoppe pieces are a range of simple, easy to wear basics which have been perfected to become the piece you reach for time and time again. Those everyday pieces you’re always trying to find? This is the place to find them! They defy fast fashion trends instead focussing on timeless clothing without the pressure of keeping up with constant new season crazes. 

I could go on about all the things I love about this brand but finally I wanted to mention their refreshing approach to production and marketing, their honesty and authenticity is so distinctive and charming in an age of pressured fashion sales. They believe that ‘those who love us will find us’ which is a concept I love and I’m so honoured they have trusted me with this and given me the opportunity to share their incredible products with you. 

You can find @lebonshoppe at some excellent independent stores in the UK including @mercantilelondon @cissywears @wordstoreldn @bristolgeneralstore

It’s all about the back 🙌 

I love clothing which has something interesting happening on the back, it’s not that often you see it and also to see it done well so here’s a few of my faves :

1. @dreamersrebels this knit is made to order and so cute, it’s made in the softest non-itchy mohair and if you’re a cat lover there’s a 🐈 version too. This brand also makes lots of reworked one of a kind pieces, think frills, lace, bows and the prettiest two pieces. 

Worn with @emikostudios trousers

2. @second_stories__ * still loving this t-shirt which doubles as a short dress for me too. The weight and quality is amazing and in my fave colour combination. I’m hoping for more designs 🙏 

Worn with @ganni dress

3. @studio.spokes how these vintage tea towel tops look at the back is very much a part of the design process which Tash talks you through when making these bespoke. They are also available in limited ready to wear drops and each time I see them I find another I love. 

Worn with @lebonshoppe via @mercantilelondon skirt 

4. @stellanovacopenhagen definitely one of my favourite Scandi brands, they make a piece in this kind of style almost ever collection and it’s not just fun to look at and impressive at the back but the motifs are all over, they’re so unique. Up close you can appreciate the embroidery, beading, sequins used on each item too. 

Worn with @stalf.studio * dress

5. @theslowlove my faves 🫶 I could have picked almost any of my Slow Love knits for this reel as most have something happening at the back. It’s one of the many qualities that drew me to this brand and they do it so well. I went for the wool tiger cardi in this reel as it’s one I don’t wear and share quite as often as my cotton knits. 

Worn with @adidasoriginals skirt

6. @picante these tees are the perfect fit, another high quality heavyweight cotton, I spent ages on the waitlist for this one last year and when I finally got one it was worth the wait. It looks like pretty much all the brand’s t- shirts have something on the back too which I love. I will definitely be back for more of these. 

Worn with @lebonshoppe via @mercantilelondon trousers

I was determined to finish this frock in March as it’s my entry to #magamsewalong #mucklemarch 
I wanted to try a patchwork project with added appliqué so it was important that it was a tried and tested and also relatively simple shape. I decided a while ago to collect old check shirts to make a quilt but some of the fabric has been used here. The base is a rescued curtain lining, some of the shirts were a bit worn so needed to be attached to something firm. I’ve shown pictures of the reverse so you can see how I attached them…basically made strips of pieces then attached from the top downwards. 
The appliqué is an old frock that just wore out many years ago. I cut out the bits I wanted, attached to lightweight iron on interfacing and used blanket stitch to attach.
The binding is another thrifted shirt and the faux button fastenings are also reclaimed shirt buttons…nothing is wasted in this project!
I think this also qualifies for #wearhappycolor2024 week 4 rainbow week.
I have had such fun making this pinafore and it’s cost me very little to make and it’s used a lot of stuff that could have ended in landfill.
Thank you @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @judithrosalind for #magamsewalong 
#sewover50 #sewover50march #ilookmyage #lovedclotheslast #donttellmehowtodress #patchworkdress #upcycledfabric #reuserecycle #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #slowfashion #slowsewing #handstitching #aplique #patchwork #nothingwasted #oldladystyle #fashiononthesofafriday

I made this frock over the winter but when I’d finished it felt like a warm weather frock…so today was the day as the sun was shining in Ely. This is McCall’s 7969, I’ve seen so many lovely versions of this that I thought I would give it a go. The fabric is a pair of old cotton curtains and the binding is an old striped shirt. I more or less stuck to the pattern but decided to stitch the front up as I found it kept a better shape, this is decorated with assorted mother of pearl buttons. I also ruched the sides…just because I felt like it.
Overall I’m rather pleased with it and will probably use the pattern again.
#sewover50 #sewover50april #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledfabric #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #mccalls7969 #imakemyclothes #handmadewardobe #oldladystyle #ilookmyage #grannychic

Well it’s still pretty nippy here in East Anglia but I am  determined to wear summer clothes so it’s just a matter of wearing lots of them. 
When I was at secondary school in dressmaking classes in the 1960s there were rules about the length of your layers, your petticoat was definitely shorter than your frock and your coat was a bit longer than your frock…and slacks under your frock were unheard of. Anyway times change and it’s so nice rules aren’t as rigid anymore.
I had a lovely day in Ely with @nancyvoak strolling, eating and lots of sewing chat. Check out that amazing zero waste patchwork jacket.
My coat is old French ticking, it’s the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps…one of my favourite patterns. 
This is worn over linen slacks, gingham frock and fairisle sweater…although it was cold I was really quite toasty.
#sewover50 #sewover50april #sew50reworn #japanesesewingbook #yoshikotsukiori #upcycledfabric #sustainablesewing #sustainablefashion #ageismisneverinstyle #sewingfriends #donttellmehowtodress #grannychic #layeringfashion #lagenlookclothing

For those of you who don’t know, when I’m not sewing I am a shop keeper, I am the proud owner of Smoking Monkey Antiques. This is my retirement project that I set up eight years ago. 
Over three last couple of months I have been working with a website designer and this week www.smokingmonkey.co.uk has gone live. I wanted the site to reflect the shop and I really think it does.
When you run a small business or shop it becomes far more than just a job, it’s a huge part of your life, almost part of who you are. 
Apart from a place of work the shop is somewhere that I have made new friends and old friends come to visit…I’ve even had buskers and a Morris dancing side passing through.
You may recognise @justjillrosalind @slowsewmo @judithrosalind  @nancyvoak and @ladynorfolkandlordrust_ and there have been many more.
Yesterday’s outfit was my autumnal patchwork frock, with a self drafted sweater made from a thrifted remnant. The coatigan is New Look 6514 made from a poly viscose fabric…such a useful garment.
#sewover50 #sewover50april #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #donttellmehowtodress #supportsmallbusinesses #supportthehighstreet #supportsmallbusiness #shoplocal #smalltownshopping #antiqueshop #antiqueshopping #grannychic

As you probably know I love knitwear, and I’ve always loved a cardigan with a ruched satin trim, then when I saw the scrumptious one by Molly Goddard recently I thought I might give it a go…and if you are interested this is how I did it.
This one started with a striped cotton sweater from the £1 rail in the charity shop and a length of ribbon. I shortened the body and the sleeves and cut up the middle of the front then neatened with a couple of rows of zigzag stitching.
I measured the length of the front opening and cut double the length, folded it in two and slip-stitched the one side together. Then with the fold at the top I clipped this to the front and using running stitches I stitched it in place. Using the same method I bound the bottom edge as well.
The cuffs I just turned a small hem and secured with herringbone stitch, and I used a large fabric coloured hook and eye to fasten the front.
If this doesn’t make sense I took pictures of the process which I have included in the post. I was pleased with the result and I think it will be a useful summer layering piece.
The frock was my mother of the bride outfit several years ago that just wasn’t getting worn so as I loved the fabric I turned it into a pinafore that I am getting a lot of wear out of it.

So it’s #memademay2024 , I always enjoy seeing everyone’s me mades and getting an insight into the thoughts behind your choices and makes…and also being inspired.
Quick introduction…I’m Marcia, I’m 72 and I’ve been sewing all my life but it’s over the last ten years that I’ve become totally addicted to making clothes. Wherever possible I now make my clothes from secondhand fabrics and this is mixed in with mainly thrifted items. I continue to be shocked by the impact that fast fashion has on the environment and strive towards a sustainable wardrobe and at the same time having fun.
When I’m not sewing I have an antique shop @smokingmonkeyantiques and I collect old doll houses.
It seemed appropriate to have this first picture in my sewing room, and as you will notice the sun is shining! 
I made today’s frock several years ago and it is made from a vintage Collier Campbell curtain. The pattern is from Sweet Dress Book by Yoshiko Tsukiori. I have used this pattern many times.
The sweater is also several years old and is self drafted.
The linen culottes and tea shirt are both secondhand.
Thank you Zoe @sozoblog for continuing to host this challenge 
#memademay #sewover50 #sewover50may #sewover50reworn #sewingchallenge #sustainablewardrobe #sustainablesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #upcycledclothing #dressyourstyle #imakemyclothes #secondhandisnotsecondbest #ageismisneverinstyle #grannycore #japanesesewingbooks

Not just ten but TWENTY outfits for you to swipe through 😍 Featuring all the end of summer/early autumn outfit styling inspo including a few from our beach staycation last month. As usual tell me your faves 😘 

(Contains some PR/gifted items) 

#outfitoftheday #autumnoutfits #styleinspo #dopaminedressing #whatiwore #sustainablefashion

Well it was actually warm yesterday and I feel quite justified in having put my winter clothes away. Since I’ve been making my own clothes I really enjoy getting reacquainted with seasonal clothes when the weather changes.
I made this pinafore in December, mainly because I’d found this ticking remnant and I fancied an embroidery project for those long winter evenings. It is just a simple pinafore pattern and I just managed to get the two main pieces and three pockets out of the ticking. The appliqué is scraps from my stash and the binding is made from Pete’s old pyjama slacks.
The shoes are a pair of patent Mary Jane’s bought many years ago that I addded a bow to…and now I feel the need to add bows to all my shoes!
The slacks are red linen and the pattern is from Everyday Style by Lotta Jansdotter.
The tea shirt and cardigan are both thrifted.
#sewover50 #sewover50april #sewoverageism2024 #handembroidery #apliquedress #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #handmadewardrobe #imademyclothes #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyoulove #slowsewing #slowstitching #oldladystyle #secondhandisnotsecondbest #grannychic #lottajansdottereverydaystyle

I just wanted to show you what you can make from a double duvet cover and pillow cases. I found this brushed cotton set in a charity shop a couple of years ago, it was £5. 
I started by making this huge smock frock from vintage Laura Ashley pattern 7917, then I had enough to make a Pilvi coat from the Lotta Jansdotta Everyday Style book. I lined the coat with brushed cotton making it very cosy. I still have some bits left which I am intending to piece together to make a winter petticoat.
Both of these pictures were taken this week, cold but sunny…my favourite weather.
I knit the tank top and shawl a few years ago…both patterns I made up as I went along…but fortunately I wrote them down so I can repeat them.
In the second picture I am wearing the coat over a frock made from vintage Laura Ashley cotton twill, the pattern is Cotton + Chalk Zoe dress. The sweater is a thrifted and shortened fair isle bought several years ago. 
I rather like the combination of fair isle, floral, tartan and stripes…it’s such fun mixing patterns.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #sewoverageism #reuserevolution #reusereducerecycle #recycledfabric #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #secondhandisnotsecondbest #patternmixing #ilookmyage #kawaii #oldladystyle #grannycore

This is my entry for #magamsewalong Around April, and I’m creating around an inspiration photo. My inspiration is the second picture, I’m pretty certain it’s from Pinterest but I’m not sure who the maker is.
I thought it would be nice to have a little layering piece to wear over summer frocks and pinafores. The fabric is a thrifted white cotton/linen shirt that I dyed yellow, together with some old cotton lace. I used the bucket method and a Dylon dye…the colour took beautifully.
I made the pattern myself and I reused the original buttonholes and buttons which saved a bit of buttonhole stress! I am hoping to make a couple more for the summer as I think they will be rather useful.
I made the pinafore last year from a piece of 1960s fabric I had in my stash.
Thanks to @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @_tallerdelili_ for hosting the challenge.

#memademay2024 day 2, early morning picture in the garden before I’m off for coffee and a day at the shop.
One of the exciting things about your sewing journey is when you get to that stage when you see a picture of a garment and you think “I could make that”. This jacket was one of those times, so this is a combination of a random Pinterest post and a piece of thrifted old ticking. I hacked the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps and this is the result. Probably one of my most worn summer makes.
The frock was something I made a couple of years ago for a prairie style sewing challenge. It is based on a 1970s sewing pattern but with added frills and layers made from lace and curtain lining dyed to match.
The sweater is made from a small piece of thrifted knit fabric, possibly 1970s…I don’t think there was a pattern.
The scarf was made from an old tee shirt.

In the spirit of #75hardstylechallenge and #imperfectsustyfashion30 and wearing what I already own, I altered something that I’ve had for some time. This Cath Kidston frock was a second hand find from last year, I knew it was too small but I fell in love with the fabric…barkcloth with clocks…what’s not to like!
I think the frock was a size 12/14 which is clearly too small, with a fitted bodice. I undid the side and the waist seams, added a panel either side of the bodice then reattached the skirt. Rather than take some fabric from the skirt to make the panels I used a piece of linen from my stash. I envisage wearing this in cooler weather, so the chances are I will be wearing a cardigan on top anyway…but to be honest I am happy with the alteration anyway and I am sure this will now be worn regularly.
The ‘new’ frock is worn with my usual embroidered jeans and a cardigan I knit several years ago.

So we have another week of mindfully getting dressed each today, using what I already have rather than buying new. I always enjoy the process of putting daily outfits together but these challenges have encouraged me to look deeper into my wardrobe and I am discovering things I had forgotten I had got.
I am currently trying to get out of the habit of watching Pointless on the telly in the late afternoon as this hour was always my sewing time as I am bursting with ideas of things to make…progress on this is being made.
It’s been a good week for seeing friends, @susanyoungsewing and I went to Ely to see the historic bridal gown exhibition and I returned to North London to catch up with @chris___art . Time with friends is always good.
As usual these clothes are either secondhand or made with old fabrics.
In case you are wondering that wonderful fabric in the first picture is a vintage Collier Campbell curtain.

So it’s March and time for #wearhappycolor2024 brought to us by @katiekortmanart and week 1 is monochromatic. 
I found this harder than it sounded but I’ve had a good go at it and I even managed to find appropriate coloured backgrounds. I must admit it was rather fun putting these colours together as it’s not something I normally think about.
First picture is a patchwork pinafore I made from lots of fabric scraps based on yellows, rusts and browns. It was made as a summer frock but layers up really well for colder weather.
On reflection perhaps two of these outfits are more analogous than monochromatic but I’m sure we can bend the rules a little bit
As usual most of the garments are bought secondhand or made from older fabrics. #sewover50 #sewover50march #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #dopaminedressing #ageismisneverinstyle #oldladystyle #grannychic

I am currently pretty excited as I have a ticket for #londonfrocktails in October and obviously for an event like this a girl needs a nice frock. 
I enjoy getting dressed but I am not good at dressing up I really dress the same way whether I’m going to work or going to a wedding. 
I think we all have a favourite frock, one that whenever we wear it we feel good, it just feels right. For some reason, I’m not entirely sure why this is my favourite frock and looking back at my photos it comes out a lot all year round. It always feels right.
As you can tell it’s made from 1970s curtains and I made it during one of the covid lockdowns. It’s a simple self drafted pattern, one I have used many times. 
So over the next few months I will decide whether to make a posh frock or another frock I know I will wear many many times. To be honest I know it will boil down to what old fabric I happen to come across…watch this space.

So it’s week 2 of #wearhappycolor2024  and this week the theme is analogous, I will confess I had to look this up as I wasn’t absolutely sure what it meant. Apparently it’s groups of colours that are next to each other on the colour wheel so I thought I would work with purple and blue. I don’t have much purple in my wardrobe but I think this may have to be rectified.
The jeans are thrifted with blue appliqué decoration.
The sweater was thrifted and recently shortened.
The purple linen pinafore is just a simple shape I made many years ago…I love old linen.
The beret I’ve had for years and recently embroidered.

musicInfo/song_name: She Moves In Her Own Way

caption:
In response to many messages here is my rather maverick way of shortening a sweater. I am not saying this is a correct way to do it but it works for me and it’s quick and easy. 
Most of my sweaters I find in charity shops and they are generally too long for me, I prefer a cropped one without a ribbed bottom, I personally think they look nicer with frocks. I had been looking for a nice blue one for ages to wear with this pinafore and I found one last week…it was on the reduced rail so I probably saved it from landfill!
1. Decide the strength you want your sweater, add 1 cm. and put in a row of pins.
2. Add a row of running stitches and remove the pins.
3. Cut along the running stitches.
4. Zig zag along the cut edge…I tend to go round 3 or 4 times.
5. Turn up approximately 1 cm and pin.
6. Choose a matching thread and using herringbone stitch secure the hem.
This works well on machine knit sweaters, I think hand knits may be trickier! 
Good luck with your shortening. If it’s a very long sweater you can actually make a little infinity scarf from the bit you chop off.
The coatigan I made many years ago from a poly viscose fabric using New Look 6514.
The pinafore is made from an old Sanderson loose seat cover from the lovely @justjillrosalind 
The jeans are thrifted and decorated with appliqué flowers. 
#sewover50 #sewover50february #sewover50reworn #secondhandisnotsecondbest #makedoandmend #imakemyclothes #clothingalterations #oldladystyle #upcycleclothing #cutandstitch #wearwhatyoulove

Here is another week of #75hardstylechallenge  where we are mindfully getting dressed each day, recording what we wear and slowing down our consumption. 
If you are looking for what @izzy_manuel  describes as a less intense version of this challenge go over to her page and check out  #imperfectsustyfashion30 .
I personally think it is important to remember to be kind to ourselves and not beat our selves up if we occasionally give into temptation…none of us are perfect and these challenges can be fun as well as raising awareness of over consumption.
There is a new frock in here, the yellow pinafore, but I have actually had this fabric in my stash for many years…and I love sewing…what can I say!
Something else I decided to do this week is pimp up my patent mary Jane shoes with a big bow.
As before the majority of these clothes are made from old fabrics, thrifted or have been in my wardrobe for a while.
#sewover50january #sewover50 #sew50reworn #ageismisneverinstyle #personalstyle #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyouhave #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #recycledfashion #recycledfabric #imakemyclothes

You know sometimes you just need to go to your sewing room and make something…well a couple of weeks ago this was the case. I’ve had this lovely fabric for so long I can’t remember where it came from, it was a curtain and I suspect it was made in the 1960s.
This is my racer back pattern and there was just enough fabric for the pinafore and the pockets. All of the seams and edges are bound with binding made from a thrifted green gingham shirt. The sides are faux button fastenings. I made it to wear either over slacks or a petticoat.
The embroidered jeans were one of my lockdown projects and the appliqué beret was a recent make.
#sewover50 #sewover70 #sewover50reworn #sewoverageism #upcycledfabric #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #dopaminedressing #grannychic #imakemyclothes #vintagefabric #handembroidery

As you know I love a bit of patchwork and appliqué so I have decided to combine the two on a racer back pinafore. Apart from being rather fun it is also a very  economical project using a bundle of old shirts, either thrifted or Peter’s castoffs, old curtain lining and old flowered frock for the appliqué. 
I am making it knee length and with split sides so it can be worn with jeans or petticoats.
I was intending to tea dye it once the patchwork was complete but I really love the colours so I’ve decided to leave it. I will bind all of the edges with a solid colour which will bring everything together…not certain what colour yet. 
As many of these fabrics are a bit worn, I felt they needed to be attached to a base fabric…the old curtain lining.
The appliqué flowers will be cut out more carefully and I will be using an iron on interfacing on the them and then attaching by hand, probably using blanket stitch.
As the  #magamsewalong2024 is #mucklemarch and I do think this is a fairly big project plus it’s patchwork this will be my entry…but I am not optimistic that it will be completed this month.
Thank you @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @judithrosalind

Another week of mindfully getting dressed in what we already own brought on by #imperfectsustyfashion30 and #75hardstylechallenge 
I think in order to be able to stick to pledges of not buying new, it is important for the process to be fun. Finding things in your stash or wardrobe that need a little love or change can be a good way of having something different to wear. A little mending can go a long way.
The yellow cashmere sweater was a very good charity shop find a couple of years ago, beautiful quality but  beige…I dyed it yellow…in a bucket…and now I love it. The yellow petticoat was once white too…
For a little while now I have been noticing pictures of cute little girls with bows on their shoes and all it took was a length of satin ribbon threaded though the strap and tied into a bow. I did secure it with a couple of stitches so it won’t come undone.
As ever most of my clothes are either secondhand or made from recycled fabrics.
Something I am noticing with this challenge is that I do seem quite fond of red and yellow on winter days!
#sewover50 #sewover50january #sewover70 #sew50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #recycledfashion♻️ #recycledfabric #ageismisneverinstyle #grannychic #oldladystyle #oldladychic

I wasn’t working yesterday , it didn’t rain and the sun shone most of the day…so we had a day in Southwold. We had a wonderful walk along the beach and up to the harbour followed by lunch at @suziesbeachcafe 
As you know I like to find a beach hut to match my outfit…although this one isn’t a brilliant match l think the colours go quite well…and I really love the colours of this hut.
The coat is the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps by Yoshiko Tsukiori. The fabric is an old Sanderson barkcloth and it’s lined with an old flannelette sheet. 
The jeans are a pair I apliqued last year.
The pink linen pinafore was a thrifted buy from many years ago.
I think these colours would qualify for week three of #wearhappycolor2024  week 3, Complementary and if I’m not the beach hut certainly qualifies
#sewover50 #sewover50march #wearhappycolour #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #japanesesewingbooks #yoshikotsukiori #adayattheseaside #sustainablesewing #slowsewing #oldladystyle #grannychic #dresslikeabeachhut #southwold

I’ve spent many hours this week sorting out pictures and text for a friend who is building a new website for @smokingmonkeyantiques . It’s been rather fun going back looking at lots of old pictures of the shop and what we have sold over the last seven years.
There is no doubt that when you run a shop or small business it becomes more than just your work,  but an extension of you….I always feel like the shop is my second home. 
This picture was taken last week outside the shop…as were the previous ones…but over the last few years.
The coat is a Pilvi from #lottajansdottereverydaystyle made from 1960s cotton velvet, probably my most worn coat. The sweater is a hand me down from Peter that I just shortened. The pinafore is made from a piece of vintage brushed cotton…and of course there is a frilly petticoat.

An entirely secondhand September preloved outfit

This month is secondhand September and it aims to raise awareness of recycled fashion and encourage people to shop preloved over new and/or fast fashion.

I’ve always loved clothes and fashion, as a teenager and in my early 20s I was an absolute Topshop addict but as I’ve got older I’ve developed an inclination and love towards small, sustainable brands and also buying secondhand too. 

My message isn’t to preach about only buying preloved and to guilt trip people into feeling terrible for shopping new season and latest trends. It’s something I do too and I’m just as partial, if not more, to a new clothing purchase than the average person, because apps like Instagram make it so easy for you to be influenced. 

However I will always use this platform to emphasise my fondness for small brands and to shine a spotlight on brands who do sustainability well, to share my secondhand finds and favourite stores to help you find things you love and to tell you about my preloved buying tips because it’s something I really enjoy doing. 

So this month I will be sharing some more entirely secondhand outfits and I hope it helps show you the amazing pieces out there that you can find preloved to help slow down, shop more responsibly and reduce fashion waste ♻️

#secondhandseptember #secondhandfashion #sustainablestyle #slowfashion #recycledfashion #circularfashion

Styling the @orwellausten Poker cardigan 

(AD/PR) I fell in love with this cardigan from the lovely small knitwear brand Orwell & Austen as soon as I saw it 😍 It’s such a fun playful take on a traditional round necked cardi and the materials and composition of the knits from this brand are just incredible. They are an unbelievably soft and luxurious cashmere and wool mix, perfect for autumn and winter styling with the most beautiful mother of pearl buttons. 

These are so versatile and easily to style, they literally go with everything in your wardrobe and hopefully this styling reel gives you some outfit ideas. It’s definitely going to be a staple knit in my wardrobe 💕

For reference I am a UK size 10, 5ft6 and wearing a Small. This also comes in a grey and white colourway in both the cardi and a jumper version. Better yet if you love it like I do you can get 15% off the Poker collection with the code KAT15. 

#knitwearlover #cashmeresweater #sustainablefashion #autumnstyle #fallstyleinspo #cardiganstyle

Styling the @back.by.sundown Phoenix Dress

(AD/PR) How incredible is this handmade linen dress? It’s a new design from small sustainable brand @back.by.sundown whose dresses I have admired for a while now. It’s beautifully made with some really flattering features like the elasticated waist and bonus points for the pockets too! It’s the perfect no-effort throw on dress for summer and so easy to layer for the colder months too; I would 100% wear this to a wedding like in the last outfit, it’s so special! 💙💚

The Phoenix comes in three different colourways and there’s limited numbers left so if you love her like I do don’t sleep on it!

#linendress #sustainablefashion #stylingideas #outfitinspo #stripeddress #smallbrandfashion

Last Sunday at the @kindredofireland and @theslowlove pop up in photos 📸

I had so much fun trying everything on and had some really lovely catch ups and chats. Pop ups are such a great way to meet the people behind the brand and the perfect opportunity to see all the pieces IRL to try before you buy. I have never considered this Parma violet Slow Love cardigan before seeing it in person and realising what an incredible colour it was 💜. And I now also have the longest Kindred of Ireland wishlist including a few bespoke ideas 😍 both are amazing small fashion brands who focus on high quality, beautifully made, sustainable treasures, wear forever pieces for your wardrobe 💕

1 - @lfmarkey tee and @belleroseofficial skirt (both new season) I have been eyeing up this stripey number for a while and it’s just as incredible in real life, I love it paired with this skirt too, I do enjoy a print clash!

2 - @numph_official top (new) and @object skirt (sale), the frilly details on this blouse 😍 and believe it or not this skirt was £10 in the sale, it has pockets (always important!) and with the 20% off extra it’s only £8 😮

4 - @emileetida jumper and @lebonshoppe skirt (both new), how good do these look together, so autumnal! I’m thinking of replacing my Damson Madder skirt with this LBS one as the fit and print is just so good 👌

11 - @stellanovacopenhagen (sale) sequins with this goes-with-everything tartan @belleroseofficial (new) skirt again

@slowfashionchallenge Day 7 Ethical souvenir. You will just have to bear with me on this one. About 40 years ago I visited a graveyard and saw this grave, very sadly it was a young Victorian girl called Rosabella who died aged 15years. I had never seen this name before and thought at the time how wonderful it would be to reinvent myself and become Rosabella. 
However, I never had the courage to do this but I did name my beautiful daughter Rosabella…so the name lives on in my life.
Today we visited Arundel and I found the grave bearing the name that has meant so much to me over the years. Not a souvenir in the accepted sense I grant you, but definitely a gift from somewhere I have visited.
It was a grey autumnal day today but the town looked beautiful and definitely worth a visit.
Today’s outfit
Thrifted embroidered jeans
Pinafore made from vintage curtain
Lotta Jansdotta Pilvi coat made from 1960s cotton velvet.

Every body is a bikini body! 👙

Big, small, fat, slim, wobbly, skinny, textured, smooth. We are all worthy of feeling the sun on our skin and the water surrounding our bodies. ☀️

For so long we have only seen slim bodies on Instagram. We have seen magazines reporting the horrors of a bigger person showing their body on the beach. But enough is enough and hopefully the next generation will know that you don’t have to have a flat tummy to enjoy the sun in a bikini. ❣️

PS all bikinis were either thrifted or swapped with friends! #bikinibody #midsizegals #midsizeblogger #plussize #bodypositive #bodypositivity #fatandfierce #fatgirl

caption:
Dressing for joy to combat the bleak mid winter 💎 

I will continue to buy clothes this year because not doing so feels like dieting and depriving myself of something that brings more than just function into my life. BUT I will do so consciously - shopping vintage, secondhand and from small sustainable ethical businesses. They need us now more than ever has they struggle to survive through the rise of fast fashion. 

I bought this purple vintage dress off vinted. It was £8 and it’s a genuine handmade 30s piece. The treasures are out there if you look. 

The brooch on my hat is handmade by @luxulite 
The walking stick is made by @neowalksticks 
The eff Tories heart bag made by @jademuatdodd 

The shoes are vintage miu miu, the turban vintage 60s and the mint tulle bolero is vintage 50s.

Maxi dresses have my 💚 

Brain dump 🧠💭: 
Having a bigger chest means there are certain styles that I feel like society doesn’t want us to wear. Automatically a dress becomes revealing or “unflattering” when someone with big boobs decides to wear it. 

When searching for holiday fits on Pinterest it seemed that the only phoots I could find were on slim bodies. The fits were 🔥 but I knew they would look completely different on me. But I want to get involved in the cute vacay fits too. So this holiday I’m wearing the clothes I want to wear and not caring what others think. So here are my saggy boobs in a cute dress! ✌🏻

Sharing and rewearing is caring 👭

I'm wondering whether the key to successfully maintaining a minimalist wardrobe is to have full access to someone else's wardrobe when you need it 🤪 Thanks to @sian_popple for lending me this dress for my hand luggage only interrail trip - it's been in her wardrobe for around 5 years but she's let me loan it for a few weeks, because what's more versatile than a cami dress!? Not only that, I also nicked her denim jacket for the day.

On a serious note, there's something to be said for lending out, borrowing and renting clothes! It maximises utility in your own wardrobe and stops you buying new for those one-time occasions. 

Have you ever rented, borrowed or lent out clothes?
