Highlights from a solo trip to Ljubljana 🌿👗🍷

Ljubljana was such a pleasure to visit solo. This was my second time in the city and the fourth destination on my interrail trip. This time I skipped the tourist spots I'd previously visited and instead spent some time enjoying a slow break in the city. Here's how I spent my two days there:

🏘 I stayed at @hostelcelica a former military prison transformed by 80 artists into a creative and lively space to stay. I'll post more on this in a reel, but it was one of the best hostels I've ever stayed in.

🍽🍷 This was the first time I really enjoyed solo dining. I spent the first evening sat outside a wine bar, Ala Pršuterija. This was set along the river and I happily people watched and read my book with a glass of Slovenian wine and some cheeses recommended by the waiter. Another highlight was Abi Falafel for a quick lunch, which is always packed throughout the day.

🌿I wanted to explore more of Tivoli City Park in Ljubljana, which extends into Roznik Hill. The park is huge and there's lots of trails to explore. I planned a run around one of the outer trails and easily made it into a 15km run. Except for the road running parallel, even the outer trails felt removed from the city, with streams, wooden bridges and forests.

👗On Trubarjeva Cesta and the surrounding streets, there's a few secondhand stores worth visiting if you're into your slow fashion. Highlights were 2nd Chance for higher end high street and designer and @textilehouse_secondhand which had a vintage store and a more high street version up the street.

Wheelchair users don’t be scared to wear the big gown, just do the old tuck and roll same when you move, same as folk would do for walking up stairs etc. invest in an old skirt lifter if you need to have it held in place 😁 & brands include more disabled people in fashion to show off your pieces sitting!

3 days in Bruges 🏘🍺🚲🛶

To sum up our time in Bruges in 2 words, I'd say buildings and beer - I loved the architecture and the beers were very good. A couple of people told me it was a bit of a tourist hotspot (I guess me being one of them?), but like most towns, stepping outside the very centre to quieter, local spots was lovely. It was easy to get there by Eurostar from London, changing at Brussels.

I've shared some spots I enjoyed below to save for your future trip to Bruges: 

🏘Where to stay: We stayed on Langerei, beside the canal in the North part of town. It meant we had a 15-20 minute pleasant walk into the centre each morning and could explore some friendly, local spots near the house in the evening.

🍴Where to eat and drink: @bierbrasserie_cambrinus for tasty Flemish food. @Deplachocolatier for Belgium chocolate (we loved the dark chocolate covered orange slices). De Garre for excellent beers and recommendations (our favourite was the Triplel Van De Garre, which you can only drink there) but every cosy looking tavern we walked into was great (I loved trying the Cherry Chouffe fruit beer). @blendwijnbarwijnwinkel for wines and snack foods.

🎨Things to do: Getting lost around the cobbled streets and following the canal North to see the windmills - if it hadn't rained, we might have hired bikes and cycled to Damme. The Groeninge gallery for Flemish art from the Baroque and Renaissance periods to the 20th century - I'm not normally a huge fan of Renaissance art as I always find it hard to engage with, but the gallery offered room-by-room cards that explained the background to each work and so I spent ages taking it all in. 

🛍Where to thrift: I didn't do any (!) but we passed some cool looking antique and secondhand clothes shops and I believe there was an Oxfam there.

POV you're watching me navigate taking pictures on my own whilst solo travelling 📸

Outfit~
Coat: Be Diddy insta sale
Shirt snd jeans: @vinted

caption:
How to pack with hand luggage only 💼

Whether you're travelling for a weekend away or an extended trip, packing with hand luggage/carry-on only can reduce costs and friction for your journey. If you're into your fashion, however, it can feel like a challenge to get your outfit opportunities into one small case and backpack. Here's some tips on how to maximise your outfits with hand luggage only:

1. Pack according to a colour pallette. Pick 2-3 complimentary colours for your outfits and stick to neutrals for the rest. For my interrail trip, I've packed a green and blue colour pallette, with a few bits of red.

2. Pack outfits not items. Don't just pack your favourite individual items, instead you should pack a capsule wardrobe of items that can be mixed and matched together in multiple ways. Test this out in advance by trying your items on and checking that they work together. 

3. Pack with a strong foundation. Base your outfits around wearable basics that perform day to night. For my interrail trip, I've packed comfortable and breathable cotton and linen basics, like black linen trousers, cream coloured jeans and cotton striped t-shirts. 

4. Maximise variety with accessories. Pack hats, silk scarves, coloured socks etc. to add some variety to your outfits, whilst not taking up additional space in your case. 

5. Maintain your clothes whilst your away. Rewear items multiple times by hanging them up at the end of the day and spot cleaning any spillages. Clothes made with natural fibres like cotton and linen will stay fresher for longer. If you're planning an extended trip, book accomodation that has a washing machine or pack some hand wash (easier on flight-free trips without liquid restrictions) to wash and rewear your clothes. I've packed some washing capsules for my interrail trip and have a few stops with access to a washing machine.

Share your thoughts on hand luggage only trips below!

#interrail #interraileu #interraileurope #interrailtravel #interrail2023 #traintravel #railtravel #flightfree #flightfreetravel #flightfreetrip #slowtravel #conscioustravel #slowfashion #ecofriendly #slowfashionblogger #slowfashionstyle #slowfashionmovement #secondhand

A further five days of #75hardstylechallenge and as you can probably tell it’s been pretty chilly recently…but at least we’ve had some sunshine.
One of the challenge intentions is to “find out what is important to you about getting dressed; comfort? self-expression? ease? I must confess that particularly since I have started making my own clothes I really enjoy the daily process of getting dressed. Obviously comfort and ease are vital, as I think it’s important to get dressed and then be able to forget about your clothes and just get on with your day. However, self expression is very important to me, I dress for myself, I really enjoy mixing colour and patterns and I like a bit of whimsy… there is no doubt that the way I dress affects the way I feel.
With the exception of the boots and socks these clothes are all made from secondhand fabrics or thrifted garments. This way I can satisfy my love of nice clothes and keep a sustainable closet.

Another seven days of #75hardstylechallenge and mindfully getting dressed. This time of year keeping warm and dry is obviously of the essence but the cold is no excuse for looking dull!
One of the points raised in this challenge is something that intrigues me, is the whole notion of fitting into an aesthetic or boxing yourself into one style. I am often asked what I call my aesthetic and I will be honest I’m not entirely sure I have one. I am influenced by many styles I see on the streets as  well as on Instagram and Pinterest… #cottagecorefashion  #fairycorefashion #morigirlstyle to name a few. It’s always fun to pick out little details and incorporate them into your wardrobe.
As you can see I am currently into bright colours and mixing patterns and prints. The majority of this selection is made by me from old fabrics or bought secondhand.

I want to tell you all about yesterday, it was the Whittlesey Straw Bear Festival, the sun shone, amazing dancers and crowds of people having fun. Basically a man dressed as a bear heads a procession on the streets, followed by lots of dancers, mainly Morris, Molly and Clog dancers. I believe it happens the first weekend after Plough Monday. The bear is burned on Sunday. Like many customs it died out but was revived in 1980…definitely a good day out… but always very cold.
This is just a random selection of pictures taken on the day. 
I am super pleased with this recent coat I made, it really is so cosy, being very large you can comfortably get so many layers underneath. The pattern is 1970s Style 2410 and the fabric came from a couple of brushed cotton duvet covers.
#strawbearfestival #strawbear #whittleseastrawbear #morrisdancing #mollydancing #clogdancing #folklore #oldcustoms #dayofdance #fens #ploughmonday #whittlesey #sustainablesewing #upcycledfabric #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #dopaminedressing #grannychic #donttellmehowtodress #sewover50 #sewover50january #oldcustoms

Original post had duplicate images…I’m trying again!Well it as a pretty exciting day yesterday as it was the first time we had been to the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge since before Covid. Not entirely sure why it’s taken so long but I think it’s probably taken a a while for many of us to continue where we left off before the lockdowns. Anyway it was wonderful, beautiful paintings and wild ceramics.
 Todays frock is one of my favourites, I generally wear this one on much warmer days…but layered up I think it works well for cold days. It is a pinafore made from a pair of vintage Sanderson curtains, with all of the edgings bound in red gingham. Today it was layered up with polo neck sweater, cashmere waistcoat and tweed jacket…all thrifted. Obviously there was also a frilly petticoat!
One of the many reasons I love a pinafore is that they really lend themselves to being worn in all weathers…ensuring you get plenty of wear out of your frocks.

Last day in the shop till next Saturday…and what a day it’s been. I’m currently collapsed on the sofa with a cup of tea and a KitKat. It’s such fun in the shop this time of year but quite exhausting!

I recently came across #75hardstylechallenge hosted by @oldloserinbrooklyn It’s about many things including mindfully or intentionally getting dressed everyday, being creative with what you already and not buying anything new…it’s definitely worth taking a look.
For me this time of year the biggest challenge is to keep warm but at the same time ensure that my wardrobe remains comfortable and colourful. I don’t tend to keep clothes “for best”, I basically dress the same whether I’m going to work, going for a walk or  going out for dinner…this way your clothes don’t languish in the wardrobe waiting for an occasion.
So this is what I’ve been wearing so far this year. Most of this selection has been in my closet for a while and will continue to come out many times over the winter months and beyond….particularly my big flowered frock made from 1970s curtains which must be my most worn frock. These clothes are all  thrifted or made from fabrics already in the system .

I’m a queen upon my wheel-ed throne 👑 💖

Is there a correct way to sit on a chair or a wheelchair? Is it for good posture? I can never sit still in one position for too long. When I’m using my wheelchair I always seem to sit cross legged. Or sitting in a car or at the cinema. Is that bad? I mean it hurts my knees but everything hurts my knees anyway and I have to keep changing which leg is crossed. And I can never just sit primly with both feet on my footplate it makes me feel weird but I can’t put my finger on why. 

Wearing a secondhand velvet pink maxi dress, pink velvet maxi platforms and a vintage bridal crown I dyed pink & lil vintage beaded bag and secondhand topshop beaded cape that looks very 20s 30s.

caption:
There should be a whole parade for today. I want to wave to adoring masses from a wheelchair throne perched on a floral covered float. Celebrate my disabled life with me 💖 🎺 🎉 

It’s #DisabledPeoplesDay or International day of people with disabilities #IDOPWD as it’s officially known but I think we need to workshop that more. Ideas? 

And the theme this year is “Amplifying the leadership of persons with disabilities for an inclusive and sustainable future”. 

This aligns perfectly with the movement toward sustainable fashion. Disabled individuals often lead by example in making thoughtful, resource-conscious choices out of necessity, such as reusing, adapting, and customizing clothing to suit their unique needs. 

Their lived experiences offer invaluable insights into designing sustainable, accessible clothing that prioritizes comfort, functionality, and longevity. 

By centering disabled voices and leadership, the fashion industry has an opportunity to embrace more inclusive, innovative practices that benefit everyone while supporting a greener, more sustainable future.

The BIG message is DON’T FORGET ABOUT DISABLED PEOPLE COZ WE ARE FUCKING AWESOME TOO! 

ID in comments

Frou frou is my preferred state of being 🐩 

I’m not a natural in the kitchen so why even pretend to be. I’m  a terrible cook, I was an enthusiastic baker in my younger days with grandiose ideas especially for family birthday cakes that were always awful but that’s part of my charm ☺️

But if you want to pop round we can order take out then spend the rest of the time trying on my hats like we are in the snoopy Easter special, eating store bought macarons and wearing three petticoats at a time to see how fluffy we can get. I’ll expect twirls and laughter 💖

I love all things fish related so naturally this one called to me. They use lots of amazing natural stones and plenty of shells here too 

3. @honoura_jewellery the amazing colourful gemstone jewellery, I wear this citrine one all the time, excited to see the opal collection coming soon ✨ 

4. @second_stories__ 
This brand gets mentioned a lot but Nicci really is a jack of all trades and sources the best jewellery, accessories, vintage and made to order pieces

5. @sharlala.jewellery 
Best jeweller in the world and the only person I’ve ever felt inclined to make bespoke jewellery with 💕 our second piece is currently in the making 

6. @saltwater_design 
Lovely Irish brand feat pearls, all picked by Megan herself to make these unique pieces, the earring are 👌too

7. @studiobowe_ 
Love Bertie’s style and her handmade jewellery, the most colourful and happiest pieces I own. Need to go to one of her workshops one day too!

8. @sorrelljewels 
Emily is the absolute queen of vintage treasure rings. These two I have are super unique solid gold but there’s silver, gemstones and sometimes themed collections too 

9. @cultofyouth 
Another fishy favourite, this is one of my every day regular necklaces, I also love the engraved lockets and have had the smiley pinkey ring on my wish list for ages 

10. @inspiredinbrockley 
I don’t normally reach for earrings but these are an exception and the pop of red is just so good. Made from polymer clay and so many other fun bright designs too

11. @peachyandwild 
Happy, smiley, rainbow beads and that bracelet is the one and same Jack Grealish often wears too!

12. @theshelldealer 
This is the summer necklace of my dreams, comes in solid colours, pastels and neutrals, mine’s from @pavement_store_london

2 days in Brussels 🎨🇧🇪🍺🚲

The second leg of my trip was a 2 day stop in Brussels. It'd be rude to do an interrail trip without stopping at the de facto capital of the EU. Less than two hours by the Eurostar from London, it's technically quicker for me to reach Brussels than my family up in Manchester! 

Sharing below some recommendations to save for your future trip to Brussels:

🏘Where to stay: We stayed in an AirBnB in Saint-Gilles, which is not only within walking distance of Brussels Zuid-Midi Station (where international trains depart from), but also some sweet bakeries, restaurants and bars to pop to.

🍽Where to eat and drink: We spent most of our time eating and drinking around Rue Haute and Parvis de Saint-Gilles. Some highlights include Pierre Et Louise for some Belgian specialities, Baba Ganoush for Lebanese food, Le Petit Lion and Brasserie Verschmueren for laid-back beers. 

🎨Things to do: We enjoyed wandering the vibrant streets coming off Rue Haute and there were plenty of secondhand stores in that area. The René Magritte museum was excellent, showcasing the works of the Belgian surrealist. We visited the Parliamentarium, the Visitor's Centre at the European Parliament (as walking tours of the Parliament itself aren't running in 2023) - it had the potential to be really engaging but it was organised largely around audio-guide devices that failed on the day! Similarly, we visited the Comic Arts museum hoping to see some Tintin - it was an interesting journey through the history of comic art, but Tintin wasn't there anymore due to some rights restrictions..(slightly too close home for a media lawyer on holiday).

Have you ever visited Belgium? 🇧🇪

Last day of the Christmas break today so we decided to spend a day by the sea at Southwold. It was a really nice way to end what has been the best of weeks. 
I eventually got back to my sewing room this week and finished my ticking pinafore. This was a small second hand remnant I found recently and I just managed to cut out the pinafore and three pockets. As you know I love appliqué and couldn’t resist a bit of embellishment, I have had these cotton scraps for many years. I use a lightweight iron on interfacing and attach using blanket stitch, I have included some closeups. It is my usual simple pattern. This pinafore is really more suitable for warmer weather but you know what it’s like when you  make something new!
If I’d have removed my coat I would have matched this Southwold beach hut but it was quite nippy on the seafront today. I am getting a lot of wear out of my big tartan coat, this is definitely a very useful make. Details of the coat are a few posts back. Jeans are my favourite embroidered ones. I have found another pair of jeans in a charity shop and I am currently working out an embroidery scheme for them…watch this space.

The frock is my own pattern and it is made from an old cotton tablecloth. I made the coatigan many years ago from a poly viscose mix using New Look pattern 6514.

A slower approach to trends 🔮

Following trends are a way to get inspired, express creativity and find community - it's hard to think of fashion without them. But there's another side to fashion trends. New micro-trends seem to appear (and die) every week on social media. I shudder every time I see a barely worn green House of Sunny Hockney dress washed up on a resale app, when a few summers ago they were everywhere you looked on a day out in London! Around 300,000 tonnes of textile waste ends up in household bins every year in the UK (sent to landfill or incinerators) according to a House of Commons Environmental Audit Committee report and I imagine micro-trends have only fed into that more. 

In a world where we want to embrace certain trends, how can we take a slower approach? Inspired by pictures of the Chopova Lowena pleated skirt and dressed up tartan kilts on my IG feed, I tried this formula recently when I set out to source a tartan style skirt of my own. Swipe for the five tips I put into action.

Let me know what you think in the comments - Can trends ever be sustainable? Have you tried out a new trend recently and did you take a slower approach? Save for the next time you want to embrace a trend!

#vintage #microtrends #ebayfinds #kilt #slowfashion #slowfashionblogger #slowfashionstyle #whomadeyourclothes  #fashrev #ecofriendlyfashion #recycledclothing #slowfashionmovement #responsiblefashion #fashionrevolution #sustainableclothing #sustainablestyle #ecofashion #fashionblogger #slowliving

It’s that time of year when many of us are thinking of coat making, and if you are new to this game I would highly recommend the Pilvi coat from the #lottajansdottereverydaystyle book. Even if you don’t make anything from this book it is an inspirational read. I have included a picture showing the pattern pieces so you can see what a simple pattern it is. All of the patterns are in an envelope at the back of the book and are very simple to trace off. It comes in a reasonable range of sizes and the pieces go together really well. It’s a versatile pattern, I have made them in boucle, velvet, cotton and corduroy. 
This one is made from an old flannelette duvet cover with additional cuffs and patch pockets. For additional warmth I lined this with Austrian brushed cotton.
Todays frock is made from vintage Laura Ashley twill and it’s worn over a flannelette petticoat made from old pillowcases. 
As you will probably notice over the next few weeks is that I love Christmas decorations!
#pilvicoat #sewover50 #sewover50november #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledtextiles #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #coatmaking #winterlayers #winterlayering #sewingisfun #ageismisneverinstyle #grannychic

Today I want to show you my new pinafore and petticoat. 
This wonderful fabric was a small pair of Sanderson curtains in a 1970s version of a William Morris design. I used a skater back pattern that I took from an old pinafore I had in the 1990s. I decided to have faux buttoned sides and bind the edges in a thrifted gingham shirt. I also added large patch pockets. I have added pictures of the pattern pieces I use and then I just extend the length depending on how much fabric I have.
The petticoat or waist slip is a thrifted duvet cover and some old cotton lace from my stash. I dyed it yellow with a Rit hand dye and I was really pleased with the result. It is basically made up of two rectangles with added lace and feather stitch embroidery.

The Charity Supermarket 💖

Last week I visited the charity supermarket pop-up - the first multi-charity shop store in the UK.

The shop's located in the old Topshop store in Brent Cross shopping centre, next to John Lewis and the Apple Store. The shop is divided into different sections for each charity shop, but it's all pretty seamless - with one changing room and one till. 

Some highlights for me included how well curated the shop is - the visual merchandising is great and it was really fun to browse through. I was pleased to see some designer brands alongside good quality high street and vintage. I spotted Shrimps, Carhartt, Missoni, alongside Miss Selfridge, Cos and & Other Stories. I was also pleasantly surprised to see some really stylish and wearable menswear. I often see secondhand menswear not getting much further than denim jackets and lumberjack shirts in charity shops.

I think the overall concept is great, especially having a second hand store with a prime spit in a pretty big shopping centre. It might present people with the opportunity to shop secondhand for the first time. The shop is open here until the 25th February and I'd love to see it pop up in other parts of the UK too.

A (sort of) sustainable guide to Budapest! 

I got so many recommendations from friends and family for Budapest that I'll have to go back to do them all. I've shared below a short list of small, local and/or sustainable leaning spots that I visited that you might want to save for your next trip! 

1) Places to visit:  @dohanystreetsynagogue was a highlight - the ticket got us a tour of the synagogue by a local guide and entry into the Hungarian Jewish Museum and Archives and another exhibition. Budapest is known for its thermal baths and we visited @szechenyithermalbath. I've heard it gets really busy at times, but we visited first thing in the morning mid-week and only used the outdoor baths - it was a lovely experience going from the freezing winter temperatures into the water. For a bit of greenery and a good view we walked up Gellert Hill and over Margaret Island. It was easy to get around the city - we walked everywhere (city bikes and public transport also looked good).

2) Things to eat: Breakfast is my favourite meal of the day and we were very spoilt on that front. Franziska was a lovely little oasis to park ourselves for a bowl of sour cherry porridge and some spiced chai. Freyja Croissant Story did beautiful pastries that didn't compromise on taste. The atmosphere at @mazeltovbudapest was excellent for a sit down meal in the evening with some nice food, but the real highlight was the cocktails, setting and live band.

3) Spots to drink: @zergecoffeeshop did a really impressive oat cappuccino, which stuck with me because we only initially stopped for the loo. We searched out some breweries and loved the selection at @kegsormuvhaz (they had a peanut butter and oatmeal stout on tap which I've been thinking about since) and @madhousebudapest . Twenty Six did brilliant cocktails.

4) Where to thrift: We spent a long time working our way through the beautiful @ludovika.vintage store - see my thrift highlight for some pictures of the shop. Thanks to @mrs.balmaks for the recommendation! Cream and Humana were more 'sift through' vibes. @retrockbudapest had great menswear and some pieces from local designers.

Thrifting rules I try to follow 🌟

I recently thrifted this denim wrap jacket on @ebay_uk and having worn it already multiple times in different ways, it made me think about why it was such a thrift hit. Below are a number of rules I try to follow when thrifting clothes. I don't always abide by these but when I do, my purchases usually end up being long lasting, wearable additions to my wardrobe. When I don't, the item is far more likely to be resold, redonated or gifted to someone else, which isn't great for my pocket or the planet. Here's the five rules I try to follow in case helpful for you too:

⭐️ Build in a buffer period before buying. For online purchases, wait at least 48 hours before pressing buy, and for in-person purchases, leave the store and return after an hour if you can. I find this buffer helps me to question if I really do want the item, if it'll fill a gap in my wardrobe and if i'm just buying something for the sake of a dopamine hit. The only risk of building in time is that the item will be gone when you come back, but in the resell world you'll often come across the same item again if you look for it. 

⭐️ Consider if you can wear the item in three different ways to make sure it's a versatile addition to your wardrobe and won't just gather dust.

⭐️ Check a variety of resell apps to make sure you're getting the best deal and the best size for you. I found this same jacket on both @vinted and @ebay_uk . On this occasion, I got a better deal by bidding on @ebay_uk and waiting a week rather than an instant buy on @vinted . 

⭐️ For online purchases, get measurements or pictures of the seller wearing it if you can to check if it will fit in the desired way. In person, always try on. I've been caught out by items fitting in an unexpected way I didn't like or materials being far less quality than a picture re-used from the original retail site.

⭐️ Evaluate whether you already have something in your wardrobe that fits the same criteria and does the same job. It's different for a quality basic in multiple colours, but it's easy to forget you've already got something similar that you could entirely substitute.

Share your thoughts below!

I started my new winter coat several months ago but covid and life got in the way of my sewing…but it’s now finished and I road tested it today in Cambridge. 
I wanted something roomy to accommodate my winter layers so I used 1970s Style pattern 2410, I’d previously used this for my big red raincoat.
The fabric and the lining were brushed cotton duvet covers so it is quite cosy. I was intending to use leather kilt straps for the fastenings but after sewing them on I discovered they were quite fiddly to use and did not look right so I added button loops and buttons instead.
I’ve included pictures of the inside so you can see how it is constructed.

I had a few hours in my sewing room today and cut out a couple of garments from old curtains. If you sew this way you have no control over the amount of fabric so you just have to adapt what you make to the curtain size.  You also have to take into account signs of wear, holes and fading and work around the faults.
The first one I cut out today was the striped ticking, a small piece of fabric so I used my short pinafore pattern and I was also able to fit in three pockets. I’ve decided to decorate with patchwork and embroidery in reds and greens with a flash of yellow…watch this space.
The brown fabric is a 1970s Sanderson version of a William Morris design. It was formerly a curtain with a few holes and some fading. This is the kind of fabric where pattern placement is key so I had to do some piecing on the back. This is a simple racer back pattern which I thought would show off the fabric well.
The thrill of finding a glorious old 
fabric is well worth the time and effort but you are limited to what you are able to make…unless they are huge curtains.
Apart from the fun, I like the sustainable aspect of using fabrics that are already in the system.
#sewover50 #sewover50november #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledtextiles #secondhand #creativereuse #secondhandtextiles #sewoverageism #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #slowsewing #sewingismysuperpower

@slowfashionchallenge Friday Freebie so I thought I’d talk about something I love and that is hand stitching and embroidery. This is something I have enjoyed for most of my life and not only is it great fun, it’s so relaxing and a lovely way to spend an evening after a hard or stressful day. Plus…you can create a unique wardrobe and every rip or hole becomes an opportunity for more decoration.
My embroidery and appliqué are not complicated, I use very simple techniques and only a handful of basic stitches. If you haven’t already tried I would recommend giving it a go.
There is no doubt if you spend time embroidering your clothes you are inclined to keep them in your wardrobe for longer.
I have included a few pictures of embroidery projects I have worked over the last few years.

Pre-loved Fashion 🖤Ad So many of you are enjoying pre-loved fashion now. 
I’ve been buying and selling preloved pieces since my teens…. It makes up a good chunk of my wardrobe.

Here’s some of my Top Tips for finding great pre-loved finds with Resale Fashion Platform @relove 

Tip 1 

- Use Filters for sizing but remember brands can vary in size and I often filter to my usual size and the size above and below

- I do filter my favourite brands but also look at brands that are new to me.. This Lucky Chouette dress was a new brand to me that I found pre-loved.  It’s such a stunning find. 

- I’ve also been known to get items altered if too big but I really love the item.  This is where a good local tailor comes in handy. 

-Tailors are also good for re purposing items.  See my example of the Lanvin preloved dress I got made into a top with a simple adjustment of the hem. 

- be adventurous and try new styles and textures like my preloved vintage top in this video. 

- I’ve used preloved sites like @relove to buy pieces I couldn’t afford new like this Anna Mason jumpsuit. 

Any questions let me know ??
I’ll be selling some of my items through @relove soon so make sure you follow them if you’re interested. 

And they have an amazing £500 Gift-Card Giveaway to spend  @relove … follow and check the link in their BIO to enter 🖤

#slowfashionchallenge2023 today’s prompt is Fabric. I must confess I do have quite a collection of old fabrics, and most of my clothes are made from vintage or second hand fabrics. These generally come in the form of soft furnishings, mainly curtains but sometimes bed linen or tablecloths. I seldom buy fabric with a specific garment in mind, if I find something beautiful I buy it and then, depending on the amount, decide what to do with it. 
These pictures are garments that I have made from vintage curtains over the last few years. 
Using fabric that is already in the system is not only more sustainable than buying new, I personally think many of the patterns and colours are so delicious. This first fabric is one of my favourites, a 1960s Sanderson and the intensity of the colour is incredible.
Most of these fabrics are found at vintage and antique fairs and if I’m lucky in charity shops. There are also some good sellers on Instagram.

I’ve made a new frock, I bought this wonderful fabric from my friend @justjillrosalind last year and it seemed the right time of year to make it up. The fabric was quite narrow so I am assuming it is 1960s/1970s and I think it is a cotton twill.
The pattern, Cotton + Chalk Zoe dress really was designed for a wider fabric so I had to have an extra seam down the back, and the front is in four pieces. Unfortunately there was not sufficient fabric to Match the pattern but there was just enough to make two patch pockets…a girl always needs decent pockets. It has a nice drape which really suits the pattern well.
The coat is one I made about five years from a poly viscose mix using New Look 6514. This coat is so useful and washes beautifully.
The linen slacks, tea shirt and necklaces are thrifted.
Knitted cotton beret from @lordandtaft

@slowfashionchallenge prompt is latest SF purchase. As you have probably noticed it has been a bit wet recently and an umbrella currently comes in quite handy. I’ve recently bought this rather splendid new brolly which I am modelling outside my shop. The reason I made this purchase is that last Friday someone stole my lovely William Morris brolly from just inside the shop door where I’d left it to drip…I can’t deny I was a bit cross.
This beautiful new brolly is based on a Klimt painting and looks so pretty in the rain and hopefully will keep me dry for many years as long as I’m careful where I leave it! I was really pleased to be able to buy it from a wonderful local shop @loftandspires . I always try and buy locally if I can as I am passionate about keeping the High Street alive.
Today’s outfit is a thrifted fairisle sweater worn over a frock made from vintage Laura Ashley fabric. The winter petticoat is made from a couple of old flannelette pillowcases and a bit of lace.
#slowfashionchallenge2023 #umbrella #slowfashion #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #supportsmallbusinesses #supporttheindependents #supportthehighstreet #agepositivity #ageismisneverinstyle #sewover50 #sewover50october #styleatanyage

@slowfashionchallenge todays prompt is Slow Fashion Tip. I personally think the way to embrace slow fashion is to develop your personal style and not follow trends. 
I love seeing what is out there  but I think it is far more fun to adapt other styles to suit yourself and your lifestyle rather than just follow them. Wear what you love and what makes you feel good, this way you will love your wardrobe and not want to be constantly buying new. Fast fashion feeds on us wanting the latest trends which results in so much waste.
In the early 1980s I discovered a book called Finery by Maria Da Conceicao and it is really about clothes as art. She used old fabrics and so many different techniques to create beautiful clothes. The book cost me £7.95, which was a lot of money for me in those days but I still get so much pleasure from it and I have no doubt about the impact it had on my approach to dress.
This is a picture from last year. The frock is one of my patchwork numbers made from odd bits from my stash and the cardigan is a charity shop find from the 1980s and still going strong.
#slowfashionchallenge2023 #sewover50 #sewover50october #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #clothesasart #wearwhatyoulove #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #iwillwearwhatilike #patchworkdress

Today’s post is all about altering stuff so you will enjoy continuing to wear it. Earlier this year I was diagnosed as pre diabetic and as I really don’t want to go down that route I decided to change the way I eat, mainly cutting down on refined sugar and carbs. I am still eating quite a lot, just differently, but to my amazement I have lost quite a lot weight and feeling much better.  As a consequence of this my jeans are way to loose around the middle so I have done some reversible alterations to reduce the waist. Basically I measured across the inside back of the jeans, halved the number and cut that amount of 2cm wide elastic. I then pinned down either end and every 5 cms, I then zig zagged top and bottom of the elastic, stretching as I stitched. I am sure there are better ways to do this but it is quick, easy and reversible…I have included a picture.
I found this fairisle cardy in a charity shop recently, I love the pattern and the fit but probably because I am not very tall I feel better in a short cardy. I cut, zigzagged three times then stitched the hem using a herringbone stitch.
The pinafore I made several years ago from an old curtain.
The make of the thrifted shoes is Oxygen.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewoverseptember24 #makedoandmend #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #donttellmewhattowear #secondhandseptember #ilookmyage #grannychic #oldladystyle

Well then! Time to officially launch the Curtains to Couture account! Curtains to Couture is founded by 5 friends with a vision to save the planet one curtain at a time! Our aim is to nurture a community of like minded souls - connected by a love of soulful stitch using reclaimed fabrics. We invite you to slow down, stitch and create mindfully, and return to the values of using what you have or whatever already exists. Upcycling, recycling, mending and re-using, it’s all about breathing new life into old textiles. Tag us using #curtainstocouture @curtainstocouture to feature on our grid on Follower Fridays, starting next week. Don’t forget to follow the hashtag too! At the weekend, there will also be a regular feature of Sustainable Sunday, with top tips and facts. Guest posts and editors, lives and interviews also planned.
We are: 
Clare @clare.burnage 
Jill @justjillrosalind 
Lisa @vintage_dahling 
Sorrel @slowsewmo 
Marcia @marcialoisriddington 

Curtains to Couture artwork courtesy of the very talented @princeslikequinces

Today’s prompt from @slowfashionchallenge is upcycled which is right up my alley. 
I always try and use fabrics that are already in the system and I personally find old soft furnishings a very useful source of fabric. The frocks and slacks in these pictures are all made from old curtains. I think these are mainly vintage Sanderson and the colours and patterns are exquisite. Just for the record the slacks are also lined with an old flannelette sheet…makes them so cosy.
I think these fabrics demonstrate that if you choose good quality fabrics they will stand the test of time and look good for many years…plus sourcing them is such fun and you rarely bump into anyone else wearing the same frock. The downside is that you do get people telling you that their granny used to have curtains like your outfit!
#slowfashionchallenge2023 #upcycledtextiles #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #dressfortheworldyouwant #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #vintagefabrics #dopaminedressing #dopaminesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #vintagesandersonfabric

@slowfashionchallenge prompt today is oldest threads. If you knew how long it took me to knit this cardigan and how many ends I had to run in you can understand why I still have it. I knit this in the early 1980s, it was designed by Zoe Hunt from the 1982 “The Sweater Book”. It is many different types of yarn but all of DK weight with added silver lurex thread. I adore 1980s knitting books, they can be bold and exciting with amazing styling.
The top picture was taken on the train to Brighton about 1985 and as you will notice my hair do hasn’t really changed. The most amazing thing is that it still fits albeit a little more snug.
We had a lovely day in Cambridge yesterday and I’ve included a few pictures taken there, it’s such a beautiful city.
#slowfashionchallenge2023 #handknitting #handknitted #colourfulknitting #colourfulknits #1980sknitwear #zoehunt #slowfashion #sustainablefashion

As you may or may not know I am a huge Lovejoy fan and you would not believe how excited I was to pose in front of this house earlier. In the series it was Felsham Hall, home of Lady Jane…in reality it is Belchamp Hall in Belchamp Walter.
This is one of those pinafores I make when I find a small piece of fabric that I love and it is really not big enough to make anything else. This remnant was found for £1 in a charity shop and the binding is made from some vintage gingham. 
In support of #secondhandseptember the tee shirt, bag, jeans, shoes and scarf are also all secondhand.
#sewover50 #sewover50september #upcycledtextiles #upcycledfashion #sustainablestyle #sustainablesewing #dopaminedressing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic #ageismisneverinstyle #patternclashing

I was really excited to be able to work with @officialoxfamsudbury to celebrate #secondhandseptember this year. I donated clothes that I had made from second hand or vintage fabrics and they did such a wonderful job of displaying them and I understand most of them have sold…both raising money and raising awareness.
This reel shows my September wardrobe which is all thrifted or made from secondhand fabrics. The other pictures are taken in the Sudbury Oxfam shop. #secondhandisbest #dressfortheworldyouwant #oxfam #madebyhand #sewover50september #sewover50 #secondhandisnotsecondbest

Last week I was coordinating with beach huts, this week it’s a brick wall…albeit a very beautiful one in Ely.
Autumn is my favourite season, and I think the best autumn fabric has to be the 1974 Collier Campbell fabric, Cottage Garden, the colours and the design are just perfect…I was lucky enough to find a small pair of curtains. The pattern is the coat dress from #stylishwraps by #yoshikotsukiori , one of my favourite patterns. As much as I love this coat I have very few frocks to wear with it, something I will be rectifying this year. This frock is something I made out of vintage seersucker for the hot weather, but is just as useful as a layering piece.
#sewover50 #sewover50october #vintagefabric #sustainablestyle #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #autumncolors #autumncolours #handmadewardrobe #ageismisneverinstyle #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #japanesesewingbooks

Over the last year I’ve been collecting secondhand tartan fabrics and I’ve just started making my winter coat. I’ve also been gathering tartan ideas on Pinterest, which has thrown up some fun ideas.
This fabric is two tartan brushed cotton duvet covers and the pattern is from the 1960s. I’ve used this pattern before to make a raincoat and it’s exactly the big loose shape I wanted for the winter.
I am stitching the lining and main fabric together and using as one…I’ve done this before many times and it makes a lovely cosy fabric.
I think there should be just enough fabric to make the hood as well…watch this space 
#sewover50 #sewover50october #wintersewing #secondhandfabric #upcycledfabric #tartan #tartancoat #sewingplans #imakemyownclothes #sewoverageism

#slowfashionchallenge2023 day 3 prompt is favourite accessory. I’ve spent time thinking about this all day and I really can’t decide…I’m very fond of socks, jewellery, scarves and hats…and as it happened I am wearing all four today for a day in the shop.
Starting at the top is my autumn appliqué beret, a recent project.
The shawl is a secondhand crochet find in such a pretty colour.
I always wear necklace and earrings…I’m not a gold and diamonds kind of girl…more a bold plastic kind of girl. Todays are faux tortoiseshell.
Unless we have extreme heat I always wear socks, I adore socks, particularly stripes or spots.
Cardigan is a charity shop find and frock is made from an old curtain. The vest is a cut down hand me down sweater. The jeans are one of my embellished pairs.
The wildly impractical boots are Gabor, bought to cheer myself up as the second lockdown loomed!
@slowfashionchallenge #autumnvibes #autumncolours #secondhandstyle #sustainablefashion #slowfashion #repurpose #slowfashionmovement #ageismisneverinstyle #dopaminedressing #autumnlayers

Morning 👋 definitely wrapping up I’n warm woolys at the moment 🥶

My tips
Look for high content wool coats… above 60% preferably 
Buying a preloved vintage coat usually has a higher wool content than modern designs.  I have some of my favourite pre-loved online stores on my highlights! 

Or layer up with thermals and gilets under your coat.  I love a gilet over a coat too… adds texture and interest…

**Mini coat edit on stories or shop @shop.ltk page..

Stay cosy ♥️🥶

#slowfashionchallenge2023 day 2 Autumn Layers…what can I say…I love layers. 
I have some frocks that are seasonal, but many of my clothes remain in my wardrobe all year round.
This is probably my favourite and most worn frock. I made it in the spring of 2021 during a covid lockdown and wore it the day my shop reopened…so it’s a bit special. 
This frock is my own pattern and made from a pair of 1970s barkcloth curtains and some vintage gingham. 
As you can see I wear this all year long, either with a tee shirt for warm weather or layered up for colder days. The majority of the jackets and accessories I either made or are thrifted.
I’ve included 10 ways of wearing it including one on the beach at Sheringham with the lovely @justjillrosalind 
#sewover50 
#sewover50october #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #repurpose #reuse @slowfashionchallenge #slowfashionmovement #ageismisneverinstyle #dopaminedressing #dopaminesewing

I love hats so I am always excited when it cool enough to wear a beret…and this is my new one. This is a thrifted yellow beret that I appliquéd with felt oak leaves in autumnal hues…then added a big pompom…as you do. I found the little wooden leaves on the front at The Works and just stitched them on. 
The jacket I up cycled from a thrifted man’s needlecord shirt.  The frock is made from a vintage Collier Campbell curtain and the pattern is from the #sweetdressbook by #yoshikotsukiori worn with my recently repaired jeans.
With the cooler weather coming I’ve been making some infinity scarves from old tee shirts. These are proving to be really useful.
#sewover50 #sewover50october #beret #aplique #handembroidery #embroidery #upcycledclothing #upcycledtextiles #sustainablestyle #ilovehats #ageismisneverinstyle

Well it’s day 1 of #slowfashionchallenge2023 and the prompt is intro.
My name is Marcia and I now live in Bury St Edmunds. My entire working life I did administrative jobs I didn’t really enjoy so when I retired I decided to have fun. I did what I always wanted to do and started dealing in antiques…I am now the proud owner of Smoking Monkey Antiques…best job in the world.
My other passion is sewing, I make the majority of my clothes from second hand or vintage fabrics, a lot of my clothes have had a previous life as soft furnishings. 
I also have a wonderful collection of old doll houses which give me a great deal of pleasure.
As you can see my life revolves around old stuff!
I think it is so important to show that slow fashion is not only beneficial to the planet but actually far more fun than the alternatives.
Todays pictures are taken by the canal at Shardlow, lots of beautiful old buildings and peeling paint. 
@slowfashionchallenge 
#sewover50 #sewover50october #slowfashion #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashionmovement #ageismisneverinstyle

Another day another beach hut and look who I’m sharing it with today, only the lovely @judithrosalind 
We spent such a nice day with Judith and Robert and believe me there was plenty to talk about. 
Just in case you were wondering why we are so colour coordinated, Judith posted a picture earlier of her holiday wardrobe so I knew exactly what colours to wear…and we knew exactly which beach hut to use.
Although I regularly pose in front of beach huts today was the first time I have ever sat in one…it was surprisingly exciting…thank you Judith for letting me sit in yours.
My frock is one of my favourites, made from a 1970s curtain and some old brown gingham…it’s my own pattern. The tee shirt is thrifted and I made the petticoat from rust covered broderie anglaise. 
Judith’s frock was gorgeous, made from lovely striped linen.
#sewover50 #sewover50october #sewingfriends #sewingfriendsarethebest #sewoverageism2023 #memadeeveryday #dresslikeabeachhut #beachhut #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #sewoverageism

Marvellous Marcia has given us more lovely things to sell in the shop! It’s been lovely to hear such enthusiasm for the fabrics and finish that make up these unique items. If you know you know! #secondhandseptember #uniquestyle #comfortableclothing #layering

The most beautiful fabric made into a gorgeous smock top/jacket by Marcia. It’s all in the details - long sleeves, two patch pockets, perfect purple buttons to catch the light, a flattering Peter Pan style collar. Perfect on its own or worn open and layered over purple, pink, red, green or yellow. We all adore it here - we think you will too! ❤️🩷💛💚💛🧡#secondhandseptember #madebyhand #marvellousmarcia #autumncolours #summeroflove

Last week I rather foolishly tripped down the terrace steps at Ickworth House. Luckily just a grazed knee and a fair bit of bruising…however the up side of this fiasco was the opportunity to mend my jeans. The embroidery on this pair of thrifted jeans was a lockdown project and I decided to patch them with a smiley face sunshine. The rays are a circle of feather stitch extended with chain stitches. As I tend to fall over quite frequently I am already planning a moon for the other knee.
The pinafore is made from a 1970s barkcloth curtain. I knit the cardigan many years ago using a 1970s pattern. 
#secondhandseptember #embroideredjeans #handembroidery #mendingmatters #aplique #slowfashion #sustainablestyle #vintagefabric #grannychic #ageismisneverinstyle #sewover50september #sewover50 #mendingmatters

Seven years ago this weekend was the beginning of Smoking Monkey Antiques. We kicked off with a party on the Friday evening and had the official opening on the Saturday. What larks we have had over the last seven years!
I thought I’d go for a bit of mixing patterns today. The jacket is a recent reworking of a thrifted 1990s floral shirt. 
The pinafore is a reworking of the frock I made for Rosa’s wedding. It was such nice fabric it seemed a waste not to be wearing it. 
I made the slacks from yellow linen many years ago.
The shoes are Josef Seibel.
#sewover50 #sewover50august #so50reworn #upcycledclothing #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #dopaminedressing #dopaminesewing #ageismisneverinstyle #ageingwithattitude #summerdressing #sewingismytherapy #grannychic #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood

Back at the shop today after three wonderful days with Rosa and Rufus. 
Celebrating #secondhandseptember in all preloved items. I make the majority of my clothes from vintage or secondhand fabric and this frock is made from old cushion covers. I wanted a frock with a sort of nautical look so I made a pattern based on those 1980s sailor frocks. 
The red petticoat is made from cotton broderie anglaise.
The T-shirt, scarf, jewellery and shoes are all thrifted.
#sewover50 #sewover50september #so50reworn #secondhand #secondhandstyle #sustainablestyle #sustainablefashion #upcycledfashion #secondhandnotsecondbest #ageingwithattitude #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic

I’ve made a new winter pinafore. I’ve had this gorgeous piece of brushed cotton for a little while and it just seemed perfect for this time of year. 
I used my usual pinafore pattern and just managed to squeeze out the pieces but I did have to piece together the bodice pieces…absolutely nothing left! I lined the bodice with a piece of old curtain lining.
It’s now getting cooler so I’m able to indulge my love of layering. The sweater is a hand me down from him indoors, it just needed shortening. The coat is a #pilvicoat from the #lottajansdotter book, made from some 1970s cotton velvet, one of my most worn coats.
The petticoat is made from a piece of wide broderie anglaise. The black felt hat is an old M&S one I bought recently from a vintage shop
#sewover50 #sewover50november #sewoverageism #handmadenovember2023 #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #slowsewing #lagenlook #ilookmyage #sewover70 #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood

It will come as no surprise that I am a huge fan of second hand and vintage shopping so I am very excited to be working on a little #secondhandseptember project with @officialoxfamsudbury . More will be revealed soon. 
Back to today…we visited the totally weird Landguard Fort. Fascinating history and gorgeous flaky paintwork.
This is my autumnal coloured patchwork frock made from an old linen frock that no longer fit and scraps from my stash. The sweater is a thrifted piece of knitted fabric that I just managed to squeeze a top out of.
The Clark’s sandals were found on EBay and the accessories were all thrifted.
#sewover50 #sewover50august #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledfabric #secondhand #secondhandisnotsecondbest #oxfamshop

locationName: Castle Acre Castle and town walls
caption:
Firstly, thank you for all the good wishes when I wasn’t well…greatly appreciated. 
This is my entry for #magamscroungingseptember I didn’t exactly scrounge this fabric from my friend @justjillrosalind but I did pester a bit till she sold it to me! This was originally a loose cover that Jill painstakingly unpicked, then all I had to do is piece it together to make a pinafore. The pattern is one I took from a 1990s Gap pinafore. The bindings are made from a thrifted gingham shirt. The fabric is a vintage Sanderson and such a beautiful blue. There are lots of small bits left that I am hoping to piece together and make a little jacket. 
The jeans are thrifted which I recently appliquéd with blue flowers. 
The jacket is made from old mattress ticking and is one of my most worn garments.
Scarf, hat and bag are also thrifted. #secondhandseptember for me is all about making stuff from secondhand fabrics…which actually is such fun.
@suestoney @sewing_in_spain @anakiequilter 
#magamsewalong #secondhandisnotsecondbest #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #autumnvibes #autumnlayering #ageismisneverinstyle #grannychic #upcycledtextiles #patternmixing

Just to prove I’ve been to Great Malvern this is me next to one of their famous wells, this one is in the town centre. Malvern is a beautiful spa town, pretty buildings, nice vintage and charity shops and good cafes. We stayed in a very picturesque Airbnb and explored the area and went to an 80th birthday party…back to work today.
This frock is made from a really beautiful old Sanderson curtain. The pattern is from the Sweet Dress Book by #yoshikotsukiori . I lengthened this  one, dyed some cotton lace to match and added some hand embroidery.
Just in case you were wondering I did not take the waters, although I did see people filling their bottles here.

Oooh my #WomanCrushWednesday lives in a different hemisphere and is currently the joy of Spring to my cozy Autumn. This truly brought me happiness to put together. 

It’s @dreams.in.colour Based in Melbourne, Fran brings her radiant style to life by championing Australian & independent global brands and showcasing the art of dopamine dressing. Her feed is an explosion of vibrant outfits, playful patterns, and the perfect dose of whimsy-each post feels like a celebration of joy itself. Beyond her bold fashion choices, Fran also shares personal snippets and candid insights, making her account feel like catching up with a friend. Whether she’s layering unexpected prints or embracing bold accessories, Fran’s unique approach is all about lifting spirits, expressing herself, and connecting with her followers. Follow her for a daily dose of happiness and heartfelt style!

Oooh today’s #WomanCrushWednesday outfit inspo is a special one for me. I’ve been following this vintage icon for about 8 years on here and she is THE sweetest soul on this earth.

I am in awe of the beautiful @life_on_mars96 She is a celebration of timeless aesthetics, offering a nostalgic yet fresh take on classic fashion and culture. She beautifully blends a love for vintage fashion, nature, and art. Mars has a particular passion for 1930s and 1940s showcasing incredible outfits that capture the elegance of these eras. Her posts reflect a deep appreciation for creativity and her content is not only stylish but also filled with personality, making it a delightful space for vintage fashion enthusiasts and art lovers alike. A true icon 🌹

I loved creating these outfits based on Mars incredible aesthetic and couldn’t stop at one.

Wearing a “oh no I can’t wear them” item 3 ways 

I’ve always wanted a pair of suede shorts and I came up with nonsense reasons everytime to stop myself. I’m 45 and finally did it. I have no regrets. 

Which way do you like them styled best? What’s something you’ve always wanted to wear but haven’t the courage to yet? 

Style 1 
Vintage suede shorts, vintage Armani denim blazer, secondhand ‘94 Kurt cobain mtv crop tee, vintage over the knee cowboy boots, @scottsamuel.co.uk sunnies, vintage scarf, secondhand marni bag, secondhand cavalli belt and walking stick from @neowalksticks & tights worn inside for autism & I like the pattern this way.

Today wasn’t the day we’d planned as some outdoor antiques events were cancelled due to wet weather. However I managed some indoor foraging and later met friends in Aldeburgh…so a very pleasant Sunday.
Today’s picture is on the front at Aldeburgh where it was pretty gusty…but not raining.
This jacket is made from a 1960s Sanderson curtain. Sanderson took the William Morris design and dyed the fabric some amazing vivid colours including this bright green. I based the pattern on the coat dress from #stylishwraps by #yoshikotsukiori I lengthened the bodice, added a frill and then another frill to the collar.
The frock is my own pattern made in linen gingham I bought online during lockdown. 
#sewover50 #sewover50august #sewover50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledfashion #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #vintagesanderson #williammorrisfabric #imademyclothes #ageismisneverinstyle #ginghamdress #styleatanyage #grannychic #japanesesewingbooks #ageingwithattitude

To celebrate World Embroidery day I thought I’d show you the progress on my new embroidered jeans. The jeans were thrifted and the denim is beautifully soft and faded. I wanted to stick to a blue colour palette so I’m using up a lot of old Laura Ashley scraps I’ve had for years, with blue, green and yellow stranded thread. I’m keeping it simple with chain stitch, blanket stitch and French knots. At this stage I’m not entirely sure where it’s going yet but I’m having fun.
I thought I’d wear an embroidered frock today too with embroidered tucks and pockets. I think pockets really lend themselves to a little embroidery…a very manageable size and shape.
#sewover50 #sewover50july #worldembroideryday #embroidery #handembroidery #aplique #handstitching #slowfashion #slowstitching #slowfashionmovement #embroideredjeans

Is it vintage or modern? 

Ok so look at the shoes first! At first glance I thought they were antique but they are by irregular choice. A bargain £3 find. 

The patchwork kimono I bought at a vintage clothes fair and I think it’s at least 1970s and handmade but hard to tell and could be older. 

The silk bra looks very 1950s to me but is made by @juliemaylingerie_uk and honestly is the best bra in my life. 

Ruffle shorts - I’m seeing these everywhere right now. These are 1950s square dancing shorts. 

Pink sunnies are secondhand moschino they look like 90s/y2k era but I’m not sure. 

And ignore my tripod/phone shadow 🤣 I’m not a great photographer

Very excited to finish my appliqué jeans, probably a bit warm for them today…but I wanted to wear them.
I found these well worn jeans on a charity shop sale rail for £1, the denim is so soft and the fit is good…perfect for embellishment. I have been looking at a lot of appliqué clothes recently on Pinterest so I thought this might be fun. I backed the shapes with iron on interfacing and attached them with blanket stitch. The stems are three rows of chain stitch. When they start to wear I will add more patches in the same colour palette.
I taught myself to smock a few years ago and this frock is my first attempt. I made this up as I went along…there isn’t a pattern.
Socks from National Trust shop
Shoes are Camper from many years ago.
Sunglasses are from @ronitfursteyewear 
#sewover50 #sewover50august #sewoverageism #embelishedjeans #embroideredjeans #embroideredclothing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #ilookmyage #ageismisneverinstyle #aplique #handembroidery #secondhandisbest #sustainablestyle #sustainablesewing #donttellmewhattowear #grannychic

A lovely breezy day in Southwold today…and in spite of the clouds the rain held off.
We had a very bracing walk down the pier and enjoyed the Tim Hunkin slot machines and weird mirrors. Plenty of refreshment breaks and I bought a beautiful old felt hat from the vintage market.
Sadly the beach hut that matched today’s outfit was occupied,so it would have been embarrassing posing in front of them 😂
The pinafore was a remnant found in a charity shop. The jacket was a thrifted 1990s long cream linen frock that I shortened and dyed red. The slacks are from #lottajansdottereverydaystyle pattern made in striped linen.
#sewover50 #sewover50july #so50reworn #sewoverageism #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #secondhandisbest #dopaminesewing #dopaminedressing #ageismisneverinstyle #adayattheseaside #imakemyclothes #sewingismysuperpower #sewingismytherapy #grannychic

We’re getting very close to September now which is my favourite month, so I’m channeling my autumn vibes today…just love autumnal colours.
It’s still very warm so it’s just summer clothes in autumn colours.
Today’s frock is made from a piece of 1960s seersucker I found many years ago in a charity shop. It’s a simple bodice with full soft pleated skirt.
The tee shirt and shoes were thrifted.
The waist slip is made from some wide broderie anglaise I found on EBay.
The jacket is reworked from a thrifted linen shirt which I embroidered and appliquéd circles.
I am currently very excited about a few cold weather projects that I will share with you soon.
#fashiononthesofafriday #sewover50 
#sewover50august #so50reworn #dopaminedressing #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowsewing #handstitching #autumnvibes #autumncolours #kawaii #grannychic #ilookmyage #oldladystyle

It’s #dresslikeabeachhut time again and how lucky was I to find this hut a similar colour to my frock. We have had a lovely day in Southwold, meeting up with relatives from Doncaster, lots of fun finishing off with tea and cake at a beautiful cafe.
The pinafore was once a chair loose cover that I scrounged from @justjillrosalind , it is bound in blue gingham made from a thrifted shirt. The jeans are thrifted and covered in appliqué flowers…needless to say the tee shirt is also secondhand.
#sewover50 #sewover50october #dresslikeachameleon #secondhandisnotsecondbest #upcycledfabric #beachhut #ageismisneverinstyle #adayattheseaside #sustainablesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #grannychic #styleatanyage

What an evening! On Wed night we hosted a panel talk at @somersethouse on ‘Redesigning Your Wedding Dress’ with the most inspiring speakers @carolinearthurbridal @robertastylelee @studio.kuhu @what_chloe_thrifts 

It was such an insightful evening discussing all the things that you can do with your wedding dress - from a simple redesign to using natural dye (with the flowers from your bouquet!), transforming a family heirloom, knitting a jumper from the scraps or even turning the remnants into Christmas baubles which can be cherished forever! 

We will be uploading a full recording of the talk within the next week which we can’t wait to share with you. If you’d like to enquire about redesign your wedding dress, you can simply #PostYourProject via the link in bio or send us a DM #UpcycleWithLoom #SustainableBridal #BridalUpcycle #CircularFashion

Very excited to be featured in the latest edition of @prelovedmagazine the theme is a Nautical Summer. If you are into sustainable style and living you should really check out this publication beautifully put together by Sophie. 
The two frocks in the feature are my take on nautical fashion and sustainability. 
The red one with seagulls is an old bathroom curtain and the pattern is from the Sweet Dress Book by #yoshikotsukiori 
The check one is made out of old cushion covers and some plain fabrics from my stash. I drafted the pattern myself…I feel very 1980s in this frock.

I do love an herbaceous border and this one at Oxburgh House is no exception. 
Last year I acquired another wonderful Japanese sewing book #cottonfriendsewing , they are lovely basic patterns and beautifully styled. I really loved this simple pullover pattern, a nice relaxed shape. As I know my body shape is different to the model l made the pattern out of old curtain lining so it was easy to get the fit I wanted. The fabric was donated to the fabric swap at our recent get together…so if it was you, thank you. I also managed to get an infinity scarf out of the fabric as well.
I often pick up old fashioned knitted blankets in charity shops which I am intending to dye and make up using this pattern…they will be really useful layering pieces for the colder weather.
The frock is a big tiered shape made from vintage cotton.

I do miss wearing hats in warmer weather so I’ve decided to go for a bow again. Like most of us girls of a certain age a bow was compulsory when we were little , then I decided to resurrect the look in the 1990s. A bow also has the advantage of hiding your roots when this becomes necessary.
The pinafore was originally longer and cream linen, this was not practical for me so I dyed and shortened it. It is a pattern I took from an existing bought pinafore that was worn out. A few years back I was lucky enough to find a 1980s Clothkits jacket…I made this up earlier this year and I love it.
The petticoat l made from wide broderie anglaise. 
The sunglasses were a gift from @keyes_france

My self love journey has been a long one. Holidays are always a time when I reflect on my relationship with my body. 

Today I can rock a bikini showing cellulite, rolls, jiggly arms, stretch marks and still feel sexy. I can see myself from a side angle and not be horrified by the fact that I am not flat. Truth be told I am the most confident I have ever been!

At the end of the carousel I included some pics of 13 year old Amy. (10 WHOLE YEARS AGO.) So desperate to look as skinny as possible and not eating before taking photos to avoid any bloating. Saving posing ideas stolen from the Kardashian’s. All with the aim of making my waist as small as possible. 

Every day when I look in the mirror I am kind to my body. I point out all the things I love. And try to work on the areas I am learning to love. Your thoughts are so so powerful. 

I am perfect the way I am. 💙

Meet THE linen set of the summer 

(AD/PR) @second_stories__ has only gone and made the most beautiful linen shirt and skirt set I’ve ever laid eyes on. Meet the Penelope blouse and skirt 😍 this is  an absolute dream to wear, the embroidery, hand done cut out details and quality are unbelievable 👌 I love it worn as a set but it also works so well as separates and you can create lots of great summer outfits from these pieces. Here’s a few styling ideas and more info on the set below. 

Each piece is available to order as individuals so you can choose one or both, I personally would recommend them as a set though 😉 the skirt is made to measure (and has pockets of course!) and the shirt is one size 8-14 but likewise the fit can be adjusted to your measurements too! If you’d like it longer/shorter, a different colour or embroidered to create something unique let Nicci know and she and her team will create you a one of a kind piece you can wear year after year. 

That’s the joy of made to order, sustainable small brand purchases, the quality, the personal experience, the uniqueness of the final product. These sets take 4-6 weeks to receive from ordering so don’t sleep on it and best of all you can use the discount code KAT25 to get £25 off the skirt and/or the shirt so you can save a total of £50 until next Saturday ☺️

#summerstyle #sustainablefashion #linenlover #embroideredclothing #slowfashionstyle

Styling small brands with @adidasoriginals 

You know I’m a big fan of small brands but I do love a bit of Adidas sportswear and I’m an absolute sucker for that adidas originals aesthetic. Here’s a few summer outfits to inspire you featuring their famous three stripe Firebird joggers, Adibreak skirts and shorts. 

There’s plenty of small, independent and preloved details here too so there’s a little bit of something for everyone ☺️ and hopefully it shows you how you can style and combine the big brands with the small ones too 🤝

#adidasoriginals #adidasfirebird #adidasskirt #sportystyle #colourfulfashion

caption:
It was party time today, my dear friend Pat is 90 and we had a lovely party in her garden. Sadly I didn’t take any pictures!
Anyway, it seemed like a good excuse to make a new frock. This wonderful barkcloth was from my friend @justjillrosalind and you will not be surprised to know it was once a curtain. It is my usual bodice pattern, with a two tiered skirt and a sash…I do love a big bow. I bound the neck, armholes and pockets with red gingham. 
I generally do soft pleats as I don’t enjoy gathering. However, I persevered and I am actually quite pleased with my efforts.

We are in Rutland for a long weekend and currently staying in a beautiful cottage in Uppingham, such a beautiful little town.
Today’s excursion was to Kirby Hall, one of the most beautiful abandoned and derelict houses I have ever seen. The building was started in 1570 but was later abandoned. It is so picturesque with plenty of niches to pose for photos!
It was very warm today so I’m wearing one of my hot weather frocks. It’s my own pattern with cap sleeves, a full tiered skirt and a big bow at the back. The fabric is a vintage printed cotton.
#sewover50 #sewover50june #so50reworn #summerfrock #summerfrocks #sustainablesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #memadewardrobe #imakemyclothes #grannychic

I will admit to looking a bit folksy today which sort of leads me to a conversation I had earlier. A customer was wondering why I added hand stitching to my clothes as this could make them look homemade.
It’s actually a fair question but I think the point is do I want to look like I’m wearing shop bought clothes or am I happy for people to know I’ve made them myself. 
I make my own clothes for many reasons, the pleasure of sewing and the creativity, not having to wear what someone else thinks I should, plus it’s fun!
I know most of my clothes don’t look shop bought and this makes me very happy. I enjoy foraging for beautiful old textiles and turning them into folksy clothes it is definitely more fun than civilian shopping…and possibly more sustainable. 
I think why we make our own clothes is such a vast and varied topic and one that really interests me.
Todays frock is made from vintage brushed cotton and some dyed cotton lace, it is 1970s Butterick 4317 with added frills. It’s worn over a vintage white frilly skirt.
#sewover50 #sewover50july #so50sustainablesewing #so50reworn #imakemyclothes #handmadewardrobe #sustainablesewing #handstitching #handmadeclothing #grannychic #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood

Thought I’d just show you my reworked summer basket. I’ve had this many years, the lining was ripped and stained the straw handles were broken and it needed a bit of a facelift. So I raided my stash and made pompoms out of old sock yarn, relined it with a damaged vintage apron (even used the pocket), the straps were left from my Christmas bag making extravaganza and I added a few old buttons just for fun. This should now see me through a few more summers.
Todays frock is a vintage cotton made from a 1970s Butterick 4317 with two added frills. Worn over a thrifted tee shirt and red broderie anglaise waist slip #sewover50 #sewover50june #so50reworn #sustainablestyle #sustainablesewing #reducereuserecycle #summerbasket #makedoandmend #memadewardrobe #slowfashion #vintagepatterns #grannychic #pompoms #ilovepoms #stashbuster

Decluttering part 1 

My overconsumption strikes again. I've found myself holding onto those pieces that I probably won't wear again, either they're not my style anymore or they simply just do not fit, just for the 'what if' in the future - IT NEEDS TO STOP

I want to get better at curating instead of just buying because its cheap and because I want it, not because I need it. I'm stuck in an endless cycle with this and want to try and make changes ♻️

This is a really good exercise to participate in during secondhand September, selling on resale sites like Vinted, Ebay or through Facebook Marketplace, swapping with friends or at an event, or donating to charity shops 

#secondhandseptember #declutter #clearout #vinted

I am seeing a lot of talk around wearing VS styling. On an every day basis I feel like I just wear my clothes, throwing on whatever is clean and comfy. But I really am trying to get better, and wear outfits that make me feel confident every day. Adding on a pair of sunglasses and cute bag really do help the outfit feel more intentional and I am enjoying the results.

These added extras don’t have to cost a lot. My bag and sunglasses were only £1 each!! So next time you are in a charity shop be sure to check the baskets of glasses and shelf of handbags. 🕶️👜

Ever thought about redesigning your wedding dress…. 

…but not sure on how to get started? Don’t know where to go? 

We are incredibly excited to be hosting a panel talk on redesigning your wedding dress! This will take place from 6-9pm on Wednesday 25th September at @somersethouse. 

We will be joined by: 

⭐ @carolinearthurbridal - a bespoke wedding dress designer & dressmaker, speaker and author of Relovable - the new book about What to do with Your Old Wedding Dress.
⭐ @robertastylelee - The Sustainable Stylist: Style Expert, Speaker and founder of Ethical Brand Directory, proud outfit repeater & advocate of 100 + wears.
⭐ @studio.kuhu - Mexican natural dyer and textile artist, and circular process advocate.
⭐ @what_chloe_thrifts - sustainable fashion influencer who has recently completely redesigned her wedding dress through Loom! 

Tickets are £5 with funds being donated to the @fashionandtextilechildrentrust.

You can get your tickets via the link in bio! #CircularFashion #SustainableBridal #Upcycling

Carrying on from my previous post I’m hand stitching again…and lots of it!
I found a lovely pair of jeans in a charity shop for £1…beautifully soft and a perfect fit. The last two pairs l embroidered were just around the turn ups so I thought I would start going up the legs this time. This is just the start and I am not yet sure where it is going…I will post updates in my stories.
I have a lot of tiny pieces of printed cotton in my stash so I sorted out the bluish bits and some matching threads. I am backing the cotton pieces in lightweight iron on interfacing and attaching them with blanket stitch. I decided to undo the inside legs to make it easier to work with. I do love a big embroidery project.
#sewover50 #sewover50july #so50scrapbusting #sustainablesewingprojects #stashbuster #secondhandfashion #jeans #handembroidery #slowfashion #sewingastherapy

Ever thought about upcycling your wedding dress? A special item which often fails on cost-per-wear, reworking it is a brilliant way to give your piece a sustainable second life!

We can’t wait to share the full transformation soon… #Upcycling #SustainableFashion #SustainableWeddingDress
