Slow fashion and sunshine? ☀️✨ yes please! I stopped by @percy.langley before going on holiday and was impressed by how “trendless” the shop is - and that’s a great complement in my books!

Don’t get me wrong, everything there is gorgeous but it’s also very timeless and can navigate so well between seasons. When you compare it to the fast fashion model and their 52 seasons - which btw is absolutely dumb and unnecessary, you can see why you’d start buying less and start saving money, even with a higher price tag 🌿

Tee - @percy.langley in collaboration with Studio AK Threads, clothing made by communities of women who support a conscious, compassionate, and circular future in the textile industry.

Shorts - @saywood.studio Made in small volumes, from dead stock and eco-friendly fabrics, their emphasis is on quality designs that last, but leave as little mark as possible on our planet through all stages of their lifecycle.

Sunglasses - @zoedepass_eyewear Handmade from premium acetate with strong, unique lenses, Zoë de Pass frames are built to last.

Blouse - @the.wellworn made vintage and deadstock fabrics. The Well Worn also mends and upcycle vintage clothing and giving these garments a new lease of life, they help to keep them out of the landfill and contribute to a more sustainable future.

🌴🦀✨
#minimalstyle #slowfashion #slowfashionstyle #sustainableliving #capsulewardrobe #slowliving #sustainablefashion

Although I have many frocks that I wear all year, I have a few that only feel right on warm sunny days… and this is one of them. I made this a couple of years ago using a couple of old cotton tablecloths. It is based on the tunic dress pattern in the Japanese Sweet Dress sewing book, I altered the armholes, lengthened it and added embroidery to the tucks and pockets. 
The necklace is another of the crochet ones someone made for me a few years ago.
#sewover50june #sew50reworn #summerdresses #ginghamdress #upcycledfabrics #memadeeveryday #handmadewardrobe #sustainablesewing #sustainablefashion #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #embroidery #embroidereddress #grannychic #yoshikotsukiori #japanesesewingbooks

We had a lovely weekend celebrating Rufus’s first birthday followed by a trip to Wimpole Hall on the way home. The gardens were beautiful and the chapel was beautifully cool. This picture was taken in Richmond before we left…and before it got very hot!
This is one of the frocks I made last year for the very warm weather, basically it’s a long roomy frock made from vintage printed cotton, with cap sleeves and a big bow on the back…not even a petticoat! The jacket is based on the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps, it’s made from some old ticking.
#sewover50june #sewover50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #vintagefabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #japanesesewingbooks #yoshikotsukiori #grannychic #handmadewardrobe #memadeeveryday

Unsurprisingly I really enjoyed yesterday’s @britishsewingbee as I love sewing with upcycled fabrics. These days many people tend to change their interiors quite frequently so household linens such as curtains, bedding and tablecloths are frequently discarded and end up in charity shops. 
Today (middle picture) is a frock made from a discarded duvet cover, it’s a simple shape with buttons all the way down the back. There is so much fabric in a double duvet cover, and often the front and back are contrasting patterns which can be great fun to work with. 
I’ve included other recent pictures of clothes that have been made from household linens over the last few years.
It’s both fun and sustainable…what’s not to like.
#sewover50june #so50reworn #sewsustainable #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledtextiles #upcycledfabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #memadewardrobe #handmadewardrobe #grannychic #oldladiesrock #reducereuserecycle

We had a lovely day in Kings Lynn yesterday, such an ancient and interesting town. Apart from the obvious beautiful old buildings there are so many interesting and pretty little alleys…I love an alley! 
I am standing in front of an incredible steel sculpture on the South Quay. It represents the racks that were used for drying fish in parts of Norway.
Todays frock was made from a pair of 1970s barkcloth curtains, worn over a waist slip made from rust coloured broderie anglaise. I knit the cardigan several years ago from a 1970s pattern. #sewover50 #so50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #vintagefabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #upcycledfabric
Come look round @shelterkingscross with me ❤️ #shelter #charityshop #thriftshop #charityshopping

On IG recently I’ve noticed a lot of what my friend Sorrel @slowsewmo calls “walk away” frocks, so I thought I’d try making one. I love a pinafore and a big bow and as this combines them both I definitely thought it was worth a go. 
When we had the fabric swap table at our recent sewing get together Lucie @nelliefromthefarm left this gorgeous fabric…it was love at first sight…thank you Lucie.
I used my usual bodice pattern but added to the sides so it would wrap around. The ribbon is attached to the back, crossed over at the front then joins the ties to make a bow. I bound the armholes and neck and added some hand stitching. Obviously I also added some nice big pockets.
#sewover50june #sewover50 #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #memadewardrobe #pinaforedress #walkawaydress #fabricswap #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #slowfashion #slowsewing #grannychic

The more I learn about fashion and meet truly well dressed and chic women, more obvious it becomes that micro trends, “must haves” and overconsumption are the exact opposite of genuine style.

These characters main relationship with fashion was purely about glamourising shopping, selling us the myth that a wardrobe overflowing with new clothes is the key to looking stylish or loving fashion. They pushed the notion that fashion is exclusive to a certain type of person, and that somehow, buying more would solve all of life’s problems - cue the cringeworthy concept of “retail therapy.” 🫠

But let’s be real: constantly refreshing your wardrobe with the latest trends won’t give you true style. Trends are marketing tools, designed to drive sales and boost profits. When we chase after every new trend, we often prioritize consumerism over our own values and personal expression.

What’s your take - do you still have style icons and like to follow trends or prefer do trust and invest in your own personal style? ✨ #sustainablefashion #timelessfashion #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion

Starting @oxfamgb #SecondhandSeptember strong styling an outfit I made up on @whering__ 💚

Having a digitalised wardrobe means you can see what you've got without being overwhelmed with that 'I've got nothing to wear feeling' and wanting to add new items to your wardrobe. 

I'm an avid thrifter and even my overconsumption is terrible, but I'm trying to change that and having the option to style my items and have a record of what I've worn is so fun 

I can't promise I'll be doing an outfit each day this month because life is busy but I want to try and share some tips for any who may be wanting to make changes to their shopping habits while encouraging myself to do the same

The most important step we can take towards ditching fast fashion is rewiring the way we think about the constant barrage of trends and must haves force fed to us everyday. 

And no, these brands are not “cheap” - they’re fairly priced. You might have to save a little to buy some of their pieces, but you’re not supposed to be buying as many clothes as you are!  Wear what you already own, swap and buy secondhand first and foremost, but if you need a few new clothes, these are great brands to fall back into 🌿

Let’s stop making excuses for fast fashion giants. You can’t pay the same price for sustainable and ethical clothes, because you can only buy that cheap is through an exploitative system and this is what we’re fighting against 🖤

#ethicalfashion #sustainablefashion #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #fashionrevolution

Becoming a conscious shopper is a journey that starts with awareness and research. By dedicating some time to understand where to shop and which brands to support, you contribute to a more sustainable and ethical fashion industry. 

A general rule to apply when researching whether a brand is sustainable, is that if it’s difficult to find its credentials, chances are they aren’t as green as they claim to be.

Ask questions, learn, and gradually build a collection of trusted, sustainable brands. Remember, your choices matter, and every sustainable purchase is a step towards a greener planet! ✨ 🌿

#ethicalfashion #sustainablefashion #whomademyclothes #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #fashionrevolution

This one is for the girlies who say “some people can only afford fast fashion!” 😒 hun, @anthropologie @freepeople @andotherstories @arketofficial @oliverbonas and other boho coded brands are fast fashion!!! 

And I don’t know about you but these are are crazy expensive to me. If you have the budget to buy at any of these brands, you have no excuse to not shop from sustainable brands ✨ 🌿

#ethicalfashion #sustainablefashion #consumerism #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #fashionrevolution

This is an “us problem” 😔 We are always blaming companies for all the waste and impact of the industry, but each and every one of us has an equal responsibility to protect and preserve our planet and the people that inhabit it. Fast fashion companies thrive off our demand as consumers, so to address the problem we need to address our own addiction.
〰️

We as consumers need to remember that we all have a voice and we need to use it to demand immediate change. By changing perceptions on our wardrobes and on sustainable fashion, we can collectively make steps towards a circular economy, in which we keep resources in use for as long as possible 🖤•

caption:
Living a sustainable life is a journey and it’s about the small, consistent steps we take every day 🌍✨ It’s easy to feel like we need to be perfect in our efforts, but remember, it’s not all or nothing. The most sustainable habits are the ones that fit into our lives and make a lasting impact. 

Every small change counts, and together, they add up to a big difference 💚 Let’s celebrate the progress we make, no matter how imperfect it may seem. What sustainable habits are you most proud of?

#lessismore #slowliving #zerowaste  #ecofriendly  #naturalbeauty #sustainablefashion #sustainableliving

Book your space through our website

#sustfest24 #stalbansmuseums #clothesswap #sustainablefashion

In a world where fashion trends change faster than the seasons, our closets often overflow with barely worn items. The fast fashion industry has made it easy to over consume, creating a throwaway culture and leading to a significant environmental impact. 

A fun way and community-driven solution to combat this is hosting a clothing swap event. Not only does it help in reducing waste, but it also fosters a sense of community and promotes sustainable fashion practices. 

Continue reading at thefairedit.com 🌿 link in bio!

•
•

#ecomadesimple #sustainablefashion #zerowaste #sustainableliving #sustainability

Can we normalise borrowing clothes? We all have a friend who’s wardrobe we drool over and @crystal_nightingale_style is definitely one of mine ✨

On average, each Londoner buys 48 new items of clothing every year but also discards 44 items annually. This means we’re adding a 155,000 tonnes of new clothes to our wardrobes each year – that’s a pile of clothes more than 1 kilometre taller than the London Eye! At the same time, 142,000 tonnes of clothes are being thrown away, and sadly, less than 10% of the clothes we donate or put in recycling bins actually get reused in London. 

But here’s the easy fix: if each of us swapped out just 12 new items for second-hand instead and repaired only 5% of the garments already in our wardrobe, we could significantly cut down the city’s carbon footprint by an incredible 30%! 

Buying secondhand, renting, swapping and of course borrowing from stylish friends should be the main way we fill up our wardrobes to have a meaningful impact on the environment 🌿 
Would you lend or borrow clothes from friends or family? 

🌍💚 #SustainableFashion #EcoFriendly #ReduceReuseRecycle #LondonLife #SustainableLiving

Hhmm… I take the “friendly” back, y’all look the same and boring AF 😑💀 Not to mention all that polyester in the heat… not my jam. Why go for knockoff vintage when there’s so much of the real thing around? With much more personally, style and quality?✨ 

Make it make sense!

🌍💚
 #SustainableFashion #ecofriendly #sustainableliving #glastonbury #festivalstyle

I’ll probably get shouted at in the comments, but this is the hill I’ll die on because sustainable fashion IS within reach for everyone! It comes down to simple changes: repairing instead of replacing, swapping instead of shopping, and always thinking twice before buying.

Opt for quality over quantity, support brands that prioritize ethical practices, and of course, try secondhand first 💕 Each small decision contributes to a larger impact!

Even though I love shopping, I also enjoy the concept of shopping within our own wardrobes. Not only is it sustainable, but it’s also great for our wallets! 

While buying new clothes is fun, the truth is many new purchases are quite similar to what we already own. Rediscovering ways to style old clothes can be a great styling exercise. Trust me, one can “look” stylish if they’re mindless jumping from trend to trend and buying huge amounts of clothes ✨

#fashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #whomademyclothes

“But sustainable fashion is not size inclusive, blablabla, same old, defends fast fashion 🤪“ I’m a size UK 14-16 and I have larger hips, still I’ve not once had any issues finding secondhand clothes on my size. 

While it’s true that sustainable brands struggle to produce a wide range of sizes, buying new eco-friendly clothes is not the only way to have a sustainable wardrobe 🌿 Buy less, take care of the clothes you have, swap and shop secondhand… that’s how you can make fashion sustainable ❣️

#sustainablefashion #whomademyclothes #ethicalfashion #timelessfashion #thrifted

Would you like to learn more about making a difference with your fashion & style choices? Don’t know where to start as it all feels really overwhelming? (Hello greenwashing, and conflicting information!) 

So excited to announce our next Sustainable Style event for the St Albans Sustainability Expo will be an incredible Fashion Panel on Saturday 8th June at 11am at Alban Arena in St Albans. 

We have an amazing panel of experts lined up for you, and we’ll be discussing the topic of sustainability in the fashion industry. 

How do we make a difference as one person and what can we do to improve our consumption habits for a better future for people and planet? These are a couple of the questions that will be addressed with our expert panel spanning fashion industry experts, influencer, brand owner and charity expert. Topics will include fabrics, secondhand fashion, supply chains and psychology/buying behaviour.

Read on for information on our fabulous speakers:
Alex Standley Personal Stylist @luxeleopardlifestyle 

Katie Carr Sustainable Brand Founder @tommyandlottie 

Beatrice Turner Ethical Fashion Influencer @beatriceturner 

Gemma Metheringham Ex Creative Director Fashion @the_elephant_in_my_wardrobe

Emma Thompson Director of Marketing @rgphospice 

This is a FREE event organised as part of Sust Fest Expo supporting @sustainablesta. So mark your diaries and save the date to come and join us. 

Plus you can have a browse at the same time of all of the fabulous sustainable stalls and other events happening at the expo!

I see this comment a lot: “I can’t find cute clothes secondhand so I have to buy from ~ insert ultra fast fashion brand ~”

Hhmmm… WHAT? Are you ok?  The privilege of prioritizing personal style over the ethical treatment of garment workers is jarring.

Brands undoubtedly bear responsibility for their practices, from exploiting labour to environmental impact. However, consumers must also acknowledge their role. Every purchase fuels a system, either perpetuating unethical practices or supporting sustainable alternatives. It’s time to recognize the power in our choices and demand accountability from both brands and ourselves. 

Remember, every time you shop, you cast a vote for the kind of world you want to live in. Let’s make it one where human rights and sustainability aren’t compromised for the sake of fleeting trends 🖤

#fashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #whomademyclothes

Why do we donate our unwanted things? It could be out of altruism, or maybe it’s about easing our guilt (or perhaps a bit of both). Shockingly only between 10 and 30% of second-hand donations to charity shops are resold in store. The rest disappears into a vast sorting apparatus to be graded and sold on to commercial partners, often for export. 

I am NOT saying you should just send it all to landfill but instead of just dropping off items without thinking, let’s consider the impact of our choices. Investing in quality pieces for a capsule wardrobe means you’ll enjoy them for years to come. Plus, when you’re ready for a change, they can easily find new homes. Here are some more tips:

🌿 Repair and Mend: Instead of discarding items at the first sign of wear and tear, consider repairing them. Learning basic sewing skills or finding a local tailor can extend the life of your favorite pieces.

🌿 Clothes Swaps: Host or participate in clothing swap events with friends or in your community. It’s a fun way to refresh your wardrobe without spending a dime and gives your clothes a new home.

🌿 Upcycling: Unleash your creativity and transform unwanted clothes into something new and exciting! From adding unique touches to creating entirely new pieces, the possibilities are endless.

Don’t forget to hit that follow button for more tips and tricks on sustainable living! ♻️✨ 

#sustainablestyle #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #aestheticedit

Here are three simple steps to help you make the switch to a more sustainable wardrobe:

🌿 1: Unsubscribe from fast fashion newsletters and email lists. By cutting off the constant stream of tempting deals and promotions, you’ll be less tempted to make impulse purchases that contribute to the cycle of overconsumption and waste.

🌿 2: Take a critical look at the brands and influencers you follow on social media, and unfollow those that prioritise profit over ethical and sustainable practices. Instead, try to support companies that are transparent about their supply chain, use eco-friendly materials, and prioritize fair labour practices.

🌿 3: Embrace ethical and sustainable fashion choices by shopping mindfully. Invest in high-quality, timeless pieces that are made to last, rather than trendy items that quickly go out of style. Consider shopping second-hand or supporting independent designers who prioritize sustainability.

By taking these steps, you’ll not only reduce your environmental impact but also support a fashion industry that values people and the planet over profit.
#sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion

Yes, you read that correctly: $800 SHEIN Haul 🤯 The average fast fashion consumer is 35, earns over $65k and spends a minimum of $100 a month on clothes. Still, every single time I advocate for quitting fast fashion, I’m bombarded with the same tired excuse: “but some people can only afford fast fashion.” 

Fact: Some folks are barely scraping by, deciding between clothes and basic necessities like food. But if you’re buying consciously, opting for a few quality pieces you’ll wear repeatedly, you’re not the issue here! They are NOT the reason the fashion industry is one of the most unethical and pollutant on the planet.

My point is, no one needs a closet bursting with new clothes every season. If you can drop $800 on summer attire, you sure as hell can invest in sustainable options - it’s just a matter of priorities!

t’s time we stop glorifying wardrobes full of crappy clothing and influencers still pushing this toxic consumerism 🤮 #quitfastfashion #fashionrevolution #sustainablefashion

Thrifted homeware before anything else and I will die on that hill! 🌿 I love every single piece on this table. These are all little gems that I found and collected over the years, and you might think it’s silly but it makes me so happy! Trust me, ditch IKEA and start buying quality secondhand decor for your home, you’ll understand 😄 Happy Easter!

The sun has been shining and Spring is definitely in the air and thoughts are turning to possible additions to our Summer wardrobes. I actually went to work without a coat yesterday although there were times when I did regret it!
This patchwork pinafore is one I made a couple of years ago and is one I wear all year round, either with a tee shirt or fairisle sweater…but always with a petticoat. This is my usual pattern but I decided I wanted a wrap over top and side button fastenings. 
The bodice and pockets were made from an old linen frock that no longer fit, and all of the squares are pieces from my stash…some of which I have had for many years. 
As for Summer sewing I am experimenting with some little linen tops to wear over my pinafores in the warmer weather…watch this space.
Something else I find useful for this inbetween weather are the little cotton jersey circle scarves, I made these from old tee shirts, so quick to make and so easy to wear.

How can we shop more consciously and choose fashion items that match our values? 

Want to shop with a conscience and align your fashion choices with your values? Start by digging into brands’ backgrounds, staying alert to subtle cues, and actively seeking answers, even if they’re not readily available. Here are some tips for your next shopping spree:

🌿 Do your homework: Before hitting that buy button, check out the brand’s website or peruse their corporate responsibility report to learn about their social and environmental commitments.

🌿 Check the label: Take a peek at what your clothes are made of. Different materials have different impacts, and items made with a single material are generally easier to recycle. Look for certifications like Cradle to Cradle Certified™, Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS), Fairtrade®, OEKO-TEX®, and others for better practices.

🌿 Opt for organic: When it comes to cotton or natural fibers, go organic. They’re gentler on biodiversity since they don’t involve toxic chemicals in their production.

🌿 Speak up: Can’t find the sustainability info you’re after? Don’t hesitate to ask a salesperson or reach out to the brand via email or social media. Your inquiry could spark some serious internal reflection.

What other steps are you taking to make your shopping habits more sustainable? Drop your tips in the comments below! 🌱 

#sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion

The comments and lack of empathy I get on some of my posts are scary but not surprising. Too many people completely miss the point, even though it doesn’t take two neurones to understand that the work conditions in those videos are horrific regardless of the circumstances. Trying to justify the unethical practices and the way fashion is currently produced is unacceptable.

The reality is that money talks. If you stop buying from brands that produce their clothes this way, they will most definitely get the message! They will ensure factories are providing safe working conditions, fair wages and environmentally responsible practices. 

So I repeat: IT’S TIME TO QUIT FAST FASHION! Period, end of story. 🌿💚 #sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage

When was the last time you considered the impact of your purchases on the planet and society? 🌿Sustainability goes beyond buying sustainable items. Here’s a few steps to become a more mindful shopper:

1️⃣ Think Before You Buy: Pause before adding to your cart. Ask yourself if the item truly adds value to your life beyond the initial excitement. 

2️⃣ Shop Consciously: Support brands committed to sustainability and slow fashion. Look for quality materials, zero waste policies, and efforts to reduce environmental impact.

3️⃣ Shop Less, But Better: Resist the allure of fast fashion bargains. Invest in pieces that align with your values and will last beyond a single season. 

4️⃣ Take Good Care of Your Clothes: Extend the lifespan of your wardrobe staples through proper care. Learn how to maintain different fabrics and consider repair services when needed. 

5️⃣ Think Circular: Embrace a circular economy by shopping secondhand, upcycling, or repairing items instead of discarding them. Reduce waste and minimize resource consumption. 

6️⃣ Donate or Resell: Give your pre-loved items a new life by donating to charity or selling them through resale platforms. ♻️

Remember, cheap often means unethical. Be mindful of the human and environmental costs behind steep discounts. Choose ethical brands that prioritize fair labor practices and sustainability. 🌍 

📸 Aaron Weiss

#MindfulShopping #SustainableFashion #ConsciousConsumerism

#EcoChicDecor #GreenLivingSpaces #SustainableStyle #UpcycledHome  #ConsciousInteriors

Hey! This post is for anyone who buys more clothing than they need. If you rarely buy clothes and can only do so on a very small budget, keep scrolling. I’m not telling low-income folks, struggling to make ends meet, to purchase from a sustainable brand if fast fashion is the only thing they can afford. 

However, these are some of the fast fashion brands that thrives on overconsumption, relying on our excessive purchasing habits. And it’s clear that many of us own more clothing than we truly need. These brands also consistently receive the lowest ratings on @goodonyou_app, which meticulously assesses companies’ environmental and social impact.

We are buying more clothes than ever, but we’re wearing them a lot less. By being mindful of our purchasing decisions and opting for quality over quantity, we can contribute to a more sustainable and equitable fashion industry

If you want to shop more sustainably and stop supporting brands like these, make sure to follow me and check my previous posts for more tips 💚✨🌿

#sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #aestheticedit

Ditching fast fashion may seem daunting initially, but trust me, it’s a decision that pays off. The best part? As well as making a difference for garment workers and the planet, you will experience positive changes in your life, too. 

✨ You’ll find and embrace your own style ✨ 
Fast fashion keeps churning out new clothes to follow the ephemeral and quite frankly, boring trends. Gaslighting you into buying random clothes on an impulse. Well, I said goodbye to that chaos and hello to finding a style that’s truly me. 

💰You’ll save money in the long run 💰
Okay, so sustainable clothes might cost a bit more upfront, but in the long run, they’re actually cheaper. Still, the average fast fashion consumer spends at least £100 a month in clothes and only wear each item 7 times! When you break free from that vicious cycle, you can invest in fewer but higher-quality garments that are actually made to last (yes, planned obsolescence is a thing in fast fashion). 

💃🏻 You’ll become even more creative 💃🏻
Bid farewell to the notion that an outfit can only be worn once for the ‘gram. Embracing ethical fashion empowers you to explore the art of mixing and matching, breathing new life into your wardrobe with each innovative combination

🌿 You’ll open your eyes to more sustainable options, beyond your wardrobe 🌿
Breaking up with fast fashion isn’t just about clothes—it’s a lifestyle change. I’ve started paying more attention to the little things, like using reusable stuff and cooking with seasonal ingredients. Every little swap adds up, and it feels pretty awesome to know I’m making a difference

So yeah, breaking up with fast fashion has been one of the best decisions I’ve ever made. If you’re thinking about doing the same, trust me, you won’t regret it! ✌️ #BreakUpWithFastFashion #SustainableAF #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion

Wearing “trends” doesn’t have to mean sacrificing sustainability. Instead of contributing to the fast fashion industry’s harmful practices, why not opt for secondhand pieces? 🌱 Not only does this approach reduces waste, our carbon footprint and saves clothes from landfill, but it also adds a unique flair to your wardrobe.

By choosing pre-loved items, you’re making a statement about conscious consumption and supporting a circular economy. Whether it’s repairing and repurposing old favorites or exploring eco-friendly materials, there are countless ways to express your style while reducing your environmental impact.

Let’s redefine what it means to be trendy and let’s prioritise sustainability and creativity. 💚 
#SustainableStyle #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #SustainableFashion #thrifthaul #MindfulConsumption 🌱

Hi! I’m Bea and I’m here to de-influence you, so hop on if you’re into making your wardrobe more sustainable 💚 Whether it’s repairing, reusing, swapping, embracing secondhand and vintage finds or buying from ethical brands, sustainable fashion encourages us to tread lightly on the Earth while expressing our individuality.

Let’s consider the impact of our choices, not just on ourselves but on the broader ecosystem of fashion. Let’s support brands that champion quality, ethics, and longevity, and let’s redefine our relationship with fashion, one reel at a time. 

#SustainableStyle #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #SustainableFashion #EthicalChoices #MindfulConsumption 🌱

Image description: rue sitting in a power wheelchair wearing a white tulle dress and berry flower crown with red heels looking all festive.

Seriously, what’s stopping you from ditching fast fashion? 💫  I promise it’s easier than you think. Here are some of the reasons why I’m head over heels for hitting up secondhand stores:

🌿 Saving money is just the beginning of the thrifting magic. Sure, this full outfit might have cost less than £100, but snagging a linen trench that’s Brand New With Tags for a fraction of the retail price? Best feeling! Plus, thrifted gems are typically way more budget-friendly than buying new stuff and you can’t convince me otherwise.

🌿 Let’s talk sustainability! Thrifting isn’t just about revamping your wardrobe; it’s about giving a second life to pre-loved pieces. By opting for thrifted finds, you’re not only reducing waste but also minimizing the environmental footprint that comes with producing new clothes. It’s a win-win for Mother Earth and your style game!

🌿 Embrace your uniqueness! The thrill of finding that one-of-a-kind piece is unparalleled. Thrifting isn’t just about following trends; it’s about curating a style that’s uniquely yours. Each thrifted treasure tells a story and adds a dash of personality to your wardrobe. 

#ThriftLove #SustainableStyle #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #streetstylelondon

Supporting small and ethical brands is amazing and important but sustainable fashion is not about buying eco-friendly clothing - it’s about reducing overall consumption and waste. By making intentional choices about what you buy and how you wear it, you can make a big impact on both your wallet and the environment 🌿✨🤍

#sustainablefashion #consciousconsumerism #zara #fashionrevolution

Minimalist outfit inspiration 🖤 as always our outfits are mostly secondhand but I did get this new bag from @fableengland, a British made, vegan brand 🐰 and I love this colour!

I found this amazing 100% wool jacket at a charity shop a couple of years ago and worn it dozens of time. It would’ve been a very expensive piece new, due to the natural materials and quality finish but I paid £25 🤩  Hope this will inspire you to go thrift shopping this weekend! 

#minimalstyle #slowfashion #slowfashionstyle #ecofriendlyfashion #sustainableliving #fashionrevolution #capsulewardrobe #slowliving #sustainablefashion #secondhand #thrifted #thriftedstyle

UNPOPULAR OPINION? 😏 ok, let’s get real… Fast fashion operates on a model built for speed and disposability. Garments are made at lightning speed, at the expense of worker rights and fair wages. The race to keep up with demand leads to unsafe sweatshop labor and exploitation in many parts of the world, including the UK.

And let’s not forget the environmental toll. From toxic chemicals used in production to the massive carbon footprint of transportation and disposal, fast fashion is a major contributor to pollution and climate change. 

The truth is, fast fashion can never be sustainable or ethical. So, let’s rethink our approach to buying clothes. Let’s prioritize secondhand and choose quality over quantity, investing in timeless pieces that are ethically made and built to last. Let’s support brands that value transparency, fair labor practices, and sustainability. And let’s reject the notion that following trends blindly is cool. True style isn’t about what’s hot this season — it’s about expressing yourself authentically and responsibly. 🌿💚 

#SlowFashion #EthicalChoices #FashionRevolution #minimalstyle #slowfashion #sustainableliving #capsulewardrobe #slowliving #sustainablefashion #secondhand #thrifted #thriftedstyle

Seriously, I’m SO happy to have you here! Despite what you might think, having a timeless and mindful wardrobe is not hard at all. It just takes a little more thought and a perspective shift, but I’m here to help with that 🥰 

What is stopping you from having a more sustainable wardrobe? Let me know in the comments below. 

#SlowFashion #EthicalChoices #FashionRevolution #minimalstyle #slowfashion #sustainableliving #capsulewardrobe #slowliving #sustainablefashion #secondhand #thrifted #thriftedstyle

I try to avoid buying fast fashion secondhand simply because the quality is very often 💩, but I got this trench coat on the @reliked sale (with 75% off), and I actually really love it. It’s made from cotton and linen and is pretty well put together considering it’s made by Asos.

The jumpsuit is old from the sustainable brand @thoughtthebrand, and the shoes are also pre-loved from @oxfamgb 🖤 Let me know in the comments if you’ve found any secondhand gems lately!

Enjoy my Crip Moves 🔥🔥🔥
The closest I get to dancing these days

This cape came from The Glastonbury festival in the 70s, how cool is that. I actually saw @theprodigyofficial there in 1995 and I think they’d have added this into clip into an mtv music video back in the day 🤣 I did have to run off from their gig after a bit tho because Oasis were headlining. I was 1 16 and they were life at the time. Did you know I’m a chav? If you’ve met me you know. I’m not ashamed 😁

I miss going to gigs. That was a huge part of my younger life. Weirdly tho as my illnesses got worse I started getting vertigo and puking at gigs. I think the noise messing with PoTs. Anyone else ever get this?

Some tips on how to declutter consciously 👗🪑🏠

***

I'm starting the process of moving to a new flat and so I've been doing some decluttering. Here's some tips on what you can do with some of your unwanted stuff!

if you're downsizing your wardrobe, consider if you could make a few pennies from it. My preferred resale platform for high street fashion is @vinted because there's zero selling fees and shipping options like Evri are integrated within the app. If you're not running a business from it, I'd generally recommend listing stuff for max £10 per item, but I often go much lower as its just more likely to be bought faster.

For odd bits and bobs, I give away stuff to local residents for free using the @olio.app. It never fails to amaze me how quick things that I don't want anymore are reclaimed by other people, from old tea towels, to spare sandpaper and empty jars.

Finally, for furniture that's still in good shape, I list @facebookmarketplace

For all of the above, obviously keep your local charity shops and donation points in mind for good quality bits.

#slowfashion #alowfashionblogger #slowfashionstyle #slow-moving #springclean #springcleaning #decluttering #minimalism #minimalist #vintage #secondhand

Whilst clearing out a drawer in my sewing room I discovered this lovely red aran weight yarn, no idea what kind it is as I bought it in a charity shop a few years ago. 
This sweater is a good example of how simple knitting a sweater can be, very few shapings and fairly big needles (6.5mm). I am confident that if you can knit a scarf you could knit this sweater. It is based on a pattern I first knit in the late 1970s but didn’t bother with the lace pattern. 
I decided to finish it off with an appliqué heart…a you do.
The pinafore is my winter weight tartan flannel patchwork frock, it’s also lined with red flannel so it’s very cosy.
You may also notice I’m standing by my Christmas tree!

It feels like autumn has finally arrived today, much cooler and very damp, so it was very timely to complete my latest knitting project. This tank top is my own pattern and knit from thrifted double knitting. This is my second one in this pattern, they are so comfortable and great layering pieces. I am toying with the idea of knitting a fair isle style one using up balls of yarn from my stash.
The frock is a recent make,  made from an up cycled loose cover. My recent appliqué jeans are peeping out from under the frock.

Have you ever thought about redesigning your wedding dress? Or know someone who might?

@theloomapp reached out to me and connected me with a local designer to completely revamp my wedding dress into something that I can now wear over and over.

The process has been so wonderful, it's got me excited to upcycle in the future! Any project whether it's an old shirt, a pair of ripped jeans, dying something stained or wanting to change the colour of a garment that no longer fits your colour pallette,  or a complete redesign like mine, @theloomapp will take care of everything 💜

Thank you so much to @recondition.mcr for creating this beautiful set for me, I'm already planning so many different looks ✨️

You can get 10% discounted off your first upcycle project with @theloomapp using code 'CHLOETHRIFTS'

Let's keep our clothes in circulation and not be afraid to try something new with what we already have hung up in our wardrobes ♻️ 

#gifted #upcycling #upcycle #weddingdress #secondhandseptember

This is another of my patchwork frocks, this time it’s the rust and yellow toned bits of fabric. The bodice is made from a frock I made several years ago…which became a bit snug…but there was plenty to make the bodice and the pockets. This is my usual bodice pattern but I fancied a wrap over bodice and side opening which is very good for flaunting your petticoat. 
There are some lovely bits of old Laura Ashley fabric in the skirt that I must have had for about 40 years!
As you will see I also had fun decorating the pockets.

caption:
We had a little trip to Wells Next The Sea yesterday which was delightful, lovely walk and a picnic on the beach.
Continuing the #secondhandseptember theme, this is a frock I made from a secondhand duvet cover. There wasn’t enough of the border print to make the back bodice so to add some back interest I added buttons. If you’re looking to make clothes out of secondhand fabrics, duvet covers can be a good choice as they are often made of two contrasting fabrics…and if it’s king size there is a lot of fabric. Spent a lovely morning with my friend Sorrel @slowsewmo foraging at a little vintage fair followed by lunch in Lavenham. 
I made this frock recently from some thrifted pink striped seersucker. I used my usual pattern from the Sweet Dress Book by #yoshikotsukiori I lengthened it, added a tuck at the back, then added embroidery to the tucks and pockets…I used green feather stitch and pink lady daisy stitch. 
The jacket is a thrifted 1980s shirt. I removed the shoulder pads, shortened it and added a little peplum with the surplus fabric. I really love this fabric.
I believe Sorrel’s gorgeous attire is also made from old fabrics.

Slow fashion goals for the upcoming year ✨️

I hope everyone's year is off to a slow and steady start! The new year marks an opportunity for many (like me) to reflect on the year before and think about setting new resolutions or intentions for the year ahead. This year I've decided to go for goals over resolutions, the difference being that goals can carry a fixed, achievable target rather than a less measurable mindset shift. Like last year, I'm also keeping it pretty easygoing and simple by setting myself a couple of goals that can be put in a diary to look forward to ticking off.

With that in mind, here are some slow fashion themed 'goals' in case helpful to guide the expert slow fashionistas or first time thrifters that want a couple of ideas to guide the start to the new year. 

My slow fashion goals for 2023 are to ✨️ plan a flight-free trip abroad, ✨️ book onto a sewing machine course and ✨️ give away a couple of bits I'm not using in my flat on my local buy nothing group, Olio or FB marketplace, like old uni textbooks and soft furnishings. 

If you're a goal, resolution or intention setter, share yours below! ✨️

I was very excited yesterday when this rather cool pair of sandals arrived at the shop. They were made for me by the lovely @a.m.y.noblemcclure of @nobleandwylie shoe makers. I understand from Amy that this style was based on a pair of Guatemalan sandals made by Guat Shoes in 1978. They are pretty and comfy…what more can you ask for.
Todays frock is my own pattern made from an old ticking curtain appliquéd with budgerigars from a remnant of old Cath Kidston fabric. It’s worn over a red broderie anglaise petticoat and red tee shirt.
#sewover50 #sewover50june #soover50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledfashion #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #aplique #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #handmadeshoes #nobleandwylie #grannychic

How I chop wood as fabulously disabled person

I don’t! I ask someone else to do it. Because it’s perfectly A OK that there is stuff I can’t do. 

Wearing someone else’s wedding dress, 70s Coca Cola trapper hat, vintage boots, secondhand buffalo check shirt & sunnies. 

Video description: rue sitting in her wheelchair twirling an axe then being handed a chainsaw by her beautiful assistant who then takes it away again. Jason then sits in the wheelchair pretending he’s gonna chop wood sitting down but chickens out, cuts to rue complaining the axe is super heavy then a final pic of rue looking powerful af standing at her meadow  using a walking stick and leaning on an axe in her epic outfit.

A (sort of) sustainable guide to Oslo! 

I've shared below a non-exhaustive list of small, local and/or sustainable leaning spots that I visited in Oslo. Whilst the way I travel is by no means sustainable (which I'd like to explore more in future!! trains > planes etc.) I always like to focus my itinerary towards places like these:

1) Places to visit: @oslobadstuforening is a non-profit association that runs saunas in Oslo. We visited the Sukkerbiten sauna one morning and had a couple of dips in the fjord. It was a fun experience made even better by the friendly staff and views of the Opera House. It's also next to @fotografihuset an outdoor photography exhibition in its pilot phase. Another highlight was wandering round Frogner Park, home to 212 sculptures (including one very angry granite baby). It evoked some interesting reactions and I've since seen the sculptures described as reflecting "the cycle of human life".

2) Things to eat: @vippaoslo is a colourful food court on the edge of the fjord. It started as a space to bring together farmers, producers, chefs and people from around the world. Elsewhere, I found a new favourite snack in pølse topped with potato salad. We visited @syverkiosken which is one of the last wooden hotdog kiosks in Oslo (but also enjoyed the convenience store version too). A special mention for all the waffles with raspberry jam eaten without catching a name.

3) Spots to drink: Oslo is spoilt for coffee and pastry fixes, especially on the fjord around Bjørvika. We also visited the @timwendelboe shop for some award winning coffee. The main drink of choice however was beer and we enjoy a few flights from some excellent taprooms, highlights being @grunerlokkabrygghus and @roor_oslo .

4) Where to thrift: A special moment was chancing upon the Sonsdagmarked whilst walking along the river, where I bought some wool mittens from the makers' market. Grunerlokka is a cool area home to the Birkelundenmarked which had more of a flea market vibe. Thanks to @welldresseddad for letting me know that (amongst other great tips) Uff and Fretex are the popular vintage / secondhand stores in the city. Whilst I didn't visit one, they were everywhere!

Name a better Sunday morning activity… 🥰

As a disabled autistic middle-aged woman, I often encounter expectations about how I should dress or behave, shaped by societal stereotypes. 

People expect conformity, especially when disability is involved, but fashion allows me to break those molds. With so little visible representation in the fashion world for people like me, I decided to create my own space. By embracing my personal style, I challenge the assumptions others hold about disability, age, and gender, demonstrating that individuality and creativity can thrive beyond society’s limited expectations. 
And I do all my own stunts, if you saw the skateboard ramp reel then you’ll know not well 😉

Wearing head to toe secondhand pieces for #secondhandseptember

Being a 45-year-old physically disabled autistic woman with chronic illnesses, l often find myself struggling to figure out where I fit in. 

Navigating the online world has been challenging, as I feel caught between spaces that don’t fully embrace me. In mainstream spaces, l’m often seen as “too much”—my experiences and complexities too far from the norm. Yet, even within the disabled community, I sometimes feel like an outsider, too “weird” or unconventional.

Where I do find acceptance, though, is among the neurodivergent crew, the fashion lovers, who seem to understand my quirks, my joy in self-expression, and my love for vintage sustainable fashion. It’s in these circles that I feel celebrated for my uniqueness, but the journey to truly feel at home online has been anything but straightforward.

Who else can relate?

Don’t call me 🤣

As an autistic person, I’m obsessed with old plastic rotary phones and the satisfying clunky sounds they make. The weight of the receiver, the tactile feeling of turning the dial, and the distinct clicks create a sensory experience that brings me comfort. However, despite my love for these vintage phones, I can’t actually answer one. The unpredictability of real-time conversations and the anxiety that comes with it is overwhelming for me, making phone calls something I avoid entirely. For me, it’s not about using the phone to talk, but about the sensory joy it provides.

Went on a vintage side quest today now I’m in bed at 4pm on a Saturday. Worth it! 

Went to @thebigfleamarket in Liverpool & it was so worth it for all the fab midcentury goodies. Found a new fave vintage seller @cherimoorevintage. Lots of love for the pink fluffy heart bag today 💖 worn with a secondhand pink floral satin dress, 40s pink quilted bed jacket & beloved secondhand pink miu miu shoes.

I took my other not so good wheelchair with me and was reminded why I rarely take it out, battery dies quick, despite being a new battery and it’s terrible in slight incline, bumps and curves. Had a cheeky pub lunch. Took an accessible bathroom selfie in a car park in a cathedral, someone played a fancy church organ while I pee’d. 

I pushed myself too far getting in & out my chair to reach racks, look through the clothes at stalls & wobble about without a stick because there was nowhere to put it on that chair & I thought I’d be fine. I wasn’t. Then home to bed, back in an old t shirt, wiped out but admiring all my new to me pretties hanging in a row where I can see them. I need this view to get through the hell that now ensues with pain & fatigue. But I’ll distract myself with fashion week glorious ness & plan how to wear my new goodies.

Read for an obscure thrift tip 🌱

I've given this dress enough appreciation posts, so today I'm using it as the medium through which to pass on a slightly obscure thrift tip: when your online thrift find arrives and your tear the pack open to try it on and it doesn't feel quite right - give it a proper chance. Always stick some shoes on and walk about for a while!! Trying on this dress standing static in my room like 🧍‍♀️did not make me mad about this dress. But once I put my sandals on, added a bag and wafted about for a bit, it quickly became a firm favourite for sunny weather and I might as well apply to become an ambassador for knitted dresses 🌱

Secondhand September 🗣 Tips for both the first timers and the expert thrifters ☑️

Secondhand September was launched by @oxfamgb back in 2019. It's a campaign that seeks to encourage people to buy only secondhand items for one month. It's a great opportunity to try out secondhand for the first time or refocus your efforts and reflect on your existing shopping habits. Whether you pledge to take part for the whole month or give secondhand a go just once, you'd become part of a growing movement of people shopping preloved over new. 

Buying secondhand keeps clothes out of landfill (according to Oxfam, this stands at 11 million garments per week in the UK) and decreases demand for new clothes, reducing the impact of the fashion industry on the lives of garment workers and on the planet. 

I'll be sharing tips all month, but here's some ideas to get started for the first time thrifters and the experts among us! 

Please do share your ideas in the comments too and let me know if you're planning to take part!

A secondhand era is here ‼️

People have been shopping secondhand for years - way before I did, way before it was 'cool', but to see it go big in mainstream media is huge!

 I started my ig page around 3 years ago and over that time I've been an on and off @loveisland fan. I don't think I'd have believed it if 3 years ago someone told me that the islanders would be styled in clothes from @ebay let alone that one of the finalists @tashaghouri would become a preloved ambassador for one of the biggest resale sites. To see this play out alongside @ekinsuofficial signing one of the biggest deals that Love Island has seen with Oh Polly only makes this news more interesting - we're seeing secondhand and new playing on the same field, which to me is one of the best ways to reach those that haven't considered it yet. 

The secondhand clothing market is expected to grow to twice the size of fast fashion by 2030 (thredup) and it's moments like this that make this sound realistic. Meanwhile Pimp My Ride Uk is coming back with @imladyleshurr and in partnership with @wrenchstudios and @ebay_uk, putting upcycling and secondhand at the centre. Preloved is popping up all over, with Bella Hadid in vintage Versace at Cannes and Olivia Rodrigo on the red carpet in vintage Jean Paul Gaultier. It's in our museums and galleries, with @toast partnering with @somersethouse at the Eternally Yours exhibition, celebrating creative reuse and repair. The @britishsewingbee has featured reduce, reuse, recycle episodes. I wonder what will be next -  Home Reno shows using secondhand, more style departments on film sets sourcing preloved? It's exciting times for secondhand and slow fashion and lifestyle!!

Secondhand forever > Secondhand September 🤠

Secondhand September is the best time of year to celebrate and try out shopping secondhand (thanks to @oxfamgb !), but as the month draws to a close I wanted to share some facts that keep me shopping #secondhandfirst beyond this month: 

▪️ Buying one cotton shirt produces the same emissions as driving a car 35 miles (WRAP)
▪️ Garments are the second highest at-risk product for modern slavery (Fashion Revolution's Impact Report, 2019)
▪️ The average consumer now buys 60% more clothing than they did 15 years ago (The UN Alliance for Sustsinable Fashion)
▪️ Less than 1% of textiles and clothes are genuinley recycled into new textiles and clothes (The Ellen MacArthur Foundation)
▪️Extending the life of clothes by just 9 months would save £5 billion in resources used to supply, launder and dispose of clothing (WRAP) 

I say #secondhandfirst because whilst I don't shop 100% secondhand, any purchase I make I consider first and wait to see if I could buy it secondhand. It's facts like these that make me realise how significant the small switches can make when done by more people 💚

#DifferentAidsForDifferentDays

As a fabulously disabled person, I use different mobility aids depending on the situation and my physical needs at the time. 

Around the house & on flat surfaces, I might walk unaided if I feel stable and comfortable, but on uneven terrain or during periods of fatigue, a walking stick or rollator offers extra support and safety. In more challenging environments or for longer distances, a wheelchair helps conserve energy, prevents pain & injury. I also use crutches around the house when I’m unable to weight bear but these can be tough on my shoulder joints. And I use my beloved stair lift daily. 

Each aid allows me to navigate the world more independently and adjust to the varying demands of my body and surroundings. Mobility aids give me freedom! 

Outfit: vintage 60s bb blue lace shift dress & pink turban. Second hand sunnies & pink metallic flat shoes. No heels for actual walking in 🤣

Slow fashion is not just about *what* you buy, but *how* you take care of the clothes you already own 🧵🪡

It's easier to say than put into practise, but your clothes, wallet and the planet will thank you for doing so. 

My @yesterdaysbabevintage blazer bought a while back needed a spruce up after lots of wears, so I dropped it in my local dry cleaners for a clean, press and a small mend and as if by magic, I immediately starting wearing it again when it returned home 💟

Here's to hopefully not buying another swimsuit for a good few years ⛱️

I've not got any statistics to share on how wasteful the leisure swimwear industry is, but from my own experience it's not been great. For every beach holiday I've had as an adult I've been scrabbling to find swimwear that is fit to last and that I find flattering. I think the key is to find something that you will use year after year, particularly for those based in the UK who I assume (like me) don't often find the opportunity to wear a swimsuit. That could be buying new, buying custom-made (thinking @slowgarments) or even secondhand (looking at @one_scoop_store that has loads in stock!) 

For me, I've settled on @you.swim. Not an ad, but thought I'd share some thoughts if they're on your list too!

@you.swim has been on my radar for a while - I like the colour ways of the swim suits and seeing a more diverse representation of models on the website. I was initially put off by the slightly steeper price than I'd usually look to pay and the fact the swimsuits are 'one size', which if Brandy Melville is anything to go off, is never really 'one size fits all' and more 'one size only'. I found a few people online that had similar dimensions to me that rated it, so I went ahead and ordered one - its genuinely the best bikini I've ever bought for fit and quality and I've just ordered a second for an upcoming beach holiday.

I can't speak for all on the 'one size' piece - YouSwim's FAQs say they fit UK size 6-18, which doesn't represent all sizes (I understand YouSwim acknowledge this and are working on extending sizing, but I haven't seen anything further just yet). For me, the 'one size' point is more compelling in a longevity sense - the bikinis are marketed as being able to adapt and change with your body throughout fluctuations in life, which aligns with my desire to buy a bikini that sees multiple holidays over several years and not just the one. 

Any other swimwear brands you rate? Let me know ⛱️

Elizabeth Taylor is one of my idols. I’m in love with that woman. Always so glamorous, those lilac eyes, a force to be reckoned with, she got what she wanted, married 8 times and left what she didn’t. I love every single movie she made. Her endless campaigning at her aids foundations meant that kids like me in the 80s were educated, PROPERLY & not by the fear mongering & hate that was being put out there. Elizabeth Taylor is an autistic specialist interest of mine. She is my autistic joy. This dress flooded my senses with so many good memories.

Designated relaxation space 🧡

Chronic illness is 💩 and I often can’t do much. This chair is my designated space for relaxing. I’m watching the birds at the feeder from my window whilst I lie down. Very #pots friendly. Wash doesn’t like to be left out and we often sit here together listening to audio books. He’s a good chilling buddy. Likes to lie in bed and nap too. But will abandon me when Jason gets home and won’t even look at me if I call his name 🤣

Image description: rue lies in a big orange chair in a pine bay window area wearing a secondhand white babydoll dress and blue velvet over the knee boots, holding a blue walking stick. Then wash the out turns up & I stuck my tongue out at him. Then make space for him next to me on our chair.

Shopping vintage alongside new - thoughts? 

This jumper has been in heavy circulation in my wardrobe recently, and I picked it up from @reformation Shoreditch. I knew Reformation as a brand that sold vintage style classic pieces and that took a more sustainable approach to business. I've read that the clothing has a focus on natural materials and Reformation seek to make their products and stores carbon neutral. I'd never actually been to one of the stores or bought the clothes, until a couple of week's ago when I popped into the Shoreditch branch to browse an interesting looking collection near the window. Reformation began as a brand selling vintage clothes in LA in 2009, and the collection I saw in the Shoreditch store was a vintage collection sat alongside the new Reformation pieces. 

I'm seeing more and more brands offering preloved and vintage collections alongside new too. From the @theofficialselfridges edits to the curated collection in @reformation, I think it's a great way to present secondhand as a legitimate option against new. It also might reach some shoppers who are otherwise put off by the more grungey reputation of preloved fashion. 

But not all brands have received praise for introducing preloved resale into their model - Pretty Little Thing launched its reGain app, allowing shoppers to 'turn unwanted clothes into discounts' off your next PLT purchase with the aim of reducing the number of clothes that end up in landfill. It's not clear where the clothes go once you send them in, and it's arguable that the model ultimately feeds the same problem by encouraging people to go and buy more clothes. Perhaps if PLT reserved the new app only for peer to peer resale on PLT items and not in return for discounts off new, the model might go some way towards reducing waste. 

So, what are your thoughts on resale alongside new? Is it all greenwashing, or is it a welcome extension of the preloved market into the spaces so far reserved for new?

caption:
Buying less is much easier to crack once you work out what to buy in the first place 🤷‍♀️

Whether you buy new (and get presented with countless micro-trend cycles throughout the year) or buy second hand (and have affordable fashion at your fingertips) it's just so easy to buy too many clothes. 

When I started shopping almost entirely secondhand three years ago, my clothing consumption slowly went up as I found myself surrounded by endless options in new places, in charity shops and resell apps. Secondhand fashion is a great way to experiment with style, but it led to my wardrobe becoming overfilled and underworn. In the last six months I've slowed it right down, practicing my own tips I post on here and thinking hard about the difference between admiring clothes (and putting the card away) to actually buying and adding something to my wardrobe.

 I'm now only buying the clothes that fit my personal style, which means often scrolling past things I like, but wouldn't wear that often. The past three months in particular I've had the same few pieces on a loop. I'm less interested in buying more when the clothes I'm wearing tick the style boxes.

I find it hard to describe personal style, but for me it often looks like:

1. Boxy fits (wide leg trousers, high neck tops) 2. natural colours (blues, greens, browns) 3. and some good checks and leopard prints. 

Spend some time thinking critically about what you actually want to wear, and follow that through to what you actually buy. It'll make buying less and repeating more so much easier !!

No greenwashing bulls**t here 

I’ve always been a lover of small fashion brands for so many reasons and even more so when their products are sustainably sourced and ethically made. Recently I’ve seen a lot about brands greenwashing, especially high street ones - misinforming their buyers to make them believe that they are making environmentally friendly fashion choices by shopping with them and that just feels so wrong. So it felt like a great idea to share some of my favourite small brands who do slow sustainable fashion so well. 

I adore all of these brands and their makers so much and I’ve been lucky enough to meet some of these lovely ladies too. They all use existing, deadstock, recycled, generally unloved materials and bring them to life as new pieces of really special, and often one of a kind, clothing. 

A quick round up: I love this new concept from @lydiabolton_ where all her creations this year are rental instead of purchase plus she also does amazing scrunchie/bow making workshops which I would highly recommend. Laura's handmade @themarconcourtproject dress designs are so iconic and they have pockets 🙌 and I love Emily’s @medley_vintage Lily blouses so much I own two (you can see both here, the second one is a bespoke design we created together). SJ brought my tartan/giant collar/satin bow blouse vision to life with this one of a kind @madebysjp piece and Nicci @second_stories__ has the best range of slogan caps ever as well as an amazing curation of vintage and reworked clothing too. She has just started a line of made to order linen pieces which are perfect for summer. 

Are you already a sustainable fashion lover? If not hopefully this convinces you, look how many incredible brands and beautiful pieces there are out there ♻️ 

Ciao cap previously gifted, I have purchased my own from @second_stories__ too and all other clothing shown here are my own purchases. 

Jeans are @citizensofhumanity via @thedressingroomsocial 
.

#sustainablefashion #recycledfashion #slowfashion #upcycledclothing #nogreenwashing #ethicalstyle

More cake than clothes pictures this Christmas break, which sets the tone for some 2022 intentions:

1. buy less and track buys, including secondhand - secondhand over-consumption is still over- consumption

2. spend (and make the time for) at least 30 minutes of free time a day doing something screen free that I enjoy - I took up a bit of knitting this week and whilst I'm pretty bad at it, it's enjoyable nonetheless 

3. learn a few new things outside of work - I've so far signed up to a weekend language class 

Some people prefer intentions over resolutions, the difference being that a resolution is a goal that is either achievable or non-achievable. On the other hand, an  intention focuses instead on a shift in mindset, however small. Have you set any for the new year, or completely rejected goal setting this time round? Would love to hear yours ⬇️

slow fashion resolutions 🗓

 Whether you see it as a time to set goals, resolutions or try out new habits, for many, including me, the new year is a good opportunity to reset and plan for the year ahead. I prefer to see it as a time to make small, positive changes, rather than subject myself to an unmanageable total rebrand. With that in mind, I thought i'd share a few ideas for slow fashion resolutions to try out for those that buy new, those that buy secondhand, and those that buy slowly and sustainably

Micro-trends: What are they, and how can we quit them? 

We buy on average 60% more clothes than we did in the early 2000s, but we're not necessarily wearing them more. The number of clothes that end up in landfill is shocking.

The problem is perpetuated further by the growth of micro-trends, and our exposure to them on social media. Whilst once trends spanned whole decades, they now last a matter of months or a couple of years.

Swipe to learn more about micro-trends, and for four tips on how to quit>

Fabulously disabled 🎀

I hope when you see me and recognise I am a disabled person that you don’t automatically feel sorry for me. We’ve been conditioned as a society to fear it. We kept disabled people locked away until our recent past so we didn’t see it. We ignored it. But I’m here to tell you my life is amazing. It’s also hard the same as everyone else for multitudes of different reasons. 

I’m physically disabled, autistic and I am fabulously living & loving my life. 

Entire outfit second hand 🎀

How to find your personal style 🌻 

Did you know that between 2013 and 2018, clothing utilisation (the average time you wear a garment before it is no longer used) decreased by 36%? Swipe for some quick tips on how to counteract this!

I partly blame this on the increase of micro-trends - the quirky styles that fill up the "new-in" section for a couple of weeks before disappearing and hitting the re-sell sites. They become like collector's items for no good reason, and it's certainly something I've bought into before, without even wanting to wear. Avoiding trends and wearing (and understanding) what truly makes you feel great helps to build a long-lasting wardrobe that you want to outfit repeat every season. This dress makes me feel like it, and it's how all clothes should - but i'm still working on it!

Send me your tips on how you find and build your personal style below 🙋‍♀️

Autism & loneliness 

I spend a lot of time alone. I live rural with closest friends & family hours away, I can’t drive nor leave the house on my own. My husband travels often and during these periods I often go days without even talking to anyone irl.  And I know you are provably thinking “oh no Rue that’s terrible”. But I’m not lonely and for most of my life I felt broken for feeling this way.  But I’m not. I just do life differently. 

I like doing my own thing. These fashion outfits I share with yall are my autistic hyper fixation. My specialist interest. It’s what I think about every day for large parts of my day. Researching, planning, buying/selling and just obsessing about clothing. Vintage, secondhand & sustainable in particular. It takes up a lot of my time and if I don’t get time/energy to indulge in this it has a negative impact on my mental health. Being autistic is complicated. Being physically disabled is complicated. Being chronically ill sucks. But fashion opens up the world for me to enjoy it all more and participate socially at a level that doesn’t stress me out. I have enough in my plate already. So this disability pride let’s celebrate the differences we might not like for ourselves but that work for others 🤣 there is no right way to live life. 

Image description: rue in a series of colourful vintage 69s or vintage style outfits having a wee pose to her self and loving every second of her alone time.

3 outfit changes later, it was always going to end up being a puff sleeve top and blazer situation 🔆

My go-to evening-out outfit has been a bit of sleeve and flare *drama* for a couple of years now. In a way, it feels like one of my style uniforms. In "A Life Less Thowaway", Tara Button talks about dressing up for the roles you play in life. She highlights that feeling of having nothing to wear, and suggests it might stem from not already having the 'costumes' in your wardrobe you need to play those roles. Button suggests making a list of all the roles you play, from the obvious to the obscure, and thinking about how you want to feel and be perceived in those roles. It's important to have your costumes ready, and the whole exercise is ultimately intended to help you buy less, choose well, and avoid the pressures exerted by trends. 

 Whilst I've cracked my 'goes for dinner and maybe a few drinks' uniform (lol), I'm still working on some of my others, especially post pandemic office wear!

I scored sooo many great gems this weekend and can’t wait to share my Easter decor ideas filled with pre-loved items! 🌿🐣 You’re going to love it! 

Do you also shop for secondhand homeware?

You might be thinking: “Bea, what do you mean? I know that. I know I’m not an influencer.” But do you, though? Because the only way to “keep up” with every trend or new aesthetic that shows up on this app is if you do it for a living.

Here’s the thing about most influencers: Most of what they show you is gifted, and everything they buy is to make money. They wear it in a video, convince you that it’s “viral” and the first place our brains go is, OK, if I want to be like her, I need to go out and buy everything she has.

But listen, sis: There is no serum. There’s no shake. There’s no green juice. There’s no handbag or pair of shoes that is ever going to turn you into another person. Going to their Amazon storefronts and LTK pages, and buying everything there to create a carbon copy of someone else’s life isn’t going to make you them. There’s only one of them and there’s one of me and there’s one of you. And we all have to start realizing that no matter how much money we spend and how much stuff we buy, it’s never going to turn us into someone that we’re ultimately not.

Here’s what we’re going to do: We’re going to get a grip. We’re going to close out all of our tabs. We’re going to empty out all of our carts. We’re going to stop trying to buy things that ultimately can’t be bought. We’re going to stop trying to be someone that we’re ultimately not 💚🌿

#thrifted #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #sustainablefashion 🌱

What are we going to wear? Something we already have! 💚

Replacing that worry of "What am I going to wear for X event" with the feeling of knowing you can just outfit repeat, is pretty liberating. Swipe to see when I've worn this outfit before. 

It clicked for me around 2 years ago when I was looking forward to another festival. Around a week before, I got the outfit panic, so headed down to Westfield to scrabble something together with my part time job wages and absolutely no creative direction. After about 50 laps of the shopping centre, hunger and stress setting in, and no outfits I liked, I knew it was the last straw. No more Westfield laps, no more new clothes for the sake of newness. I'd spend 10 minutes going through what I already had, or asking a friend to borrow, and would spend more time getting excited for a day in the sun with my friends. Once you give up scrolling the "New in" sections of fashion stores, there's no going back! 

Have you had a similar penny drop moment? 

For what we have left of this summer, try outfit repeating for your next event 💚

Adjusted these trousers and then wore them 4/5 days this week 🌥

I found these tailored balloon leg trousers on @depop in my size, but when they arrived, they didn't quite fit how I wanted on the waist. A couple of YouTube videos later, I learnt how to take them in slightly by pulling in the back seam. I wanted to retain the volume in the leg, so I tapered the adjustment from the waist down to the crotch seam. Swipe to see the process!

Learning some simple hacks on how to adjust and tailor clothes of your size to better fit you is a great way to make your clothes more wearable, and for me, ultimately encourages less new purchases 🌥

N.B I wouldn't advocate for thrifting clothes outside your size range and adjusting them to fit you. Unless in a clearance area and saving from landfill, this could limit availability of second hand clothes for other people. I'd always stick to my sizes, and would only adjust from there.

Let me know if you've learnt any adjustment hacks!

It's an uncomfortable fact that new clothes from this season are being bought and sold on second hand pretty quickly. But whilst it does, I'll be waiting for the second hand goods over on the re-sell sites 👩‍💻

Slow fashion evening wear ✨

Some recent evening wear looks put together with second hand, old and sustainable fashion. Which is your favourite - 1, 2 or 3? ✨

Two years ago I'd stress about what to wear when I had an evening out coming up. In fact, the green top in picture 2 was one of those buys! I was in that mindset of needing something 'new' to wear to enjoy my night. In the end it'd just be an expensive and unpleasant way to shop and get dressed up, usually ending up with something I wouldn't wear much again. Now, I still love find a 'new to me' second hand piece for the odd occasion, but for most of my evenings out, I try to reinvent something I've already got - It's pretty liberating!

Postcards from a sunny weekend 🔆

I was up in sunny Merseyside this weekend catching up with an old friend where I grew up. This friend introduced me to charity shopping way back, and she definitely trained me up into the thrifter I am today! 

She showed me round some local spots I hadn't been to before, including the Green Community Shop & Centre in Oxton. It's a non-profit community shop run by local volunteers, and one volunteer kindly invited us into the back yard for tea and pastries mid shop (explaining the absolute joy in pic 1). It's a great initiative, focusing on sustainability, co-operation and local participation. More places like this! I'd love to get involved in something similar in East London.

These shorts used to be jeans ✂️

Clothes should serve a purpose to take up in space in your wardrobe, or they might be better used by someone else. I bought these jeans last summer, and the fit had always been a bit too relaxed in the leg for me. When I found some better fitting white jeans this summer, they had to find a new place.

City style shorts have become more popular this year, and rather than buying new shorts to try it, I upcycled my old jeans. Using another favourite pair of shorts as a guide, I cut across with scissors and distressed the hem by pulling out a few threads. I then dropped off the remaining fabric at a local textile recycling box, and my #newtome shorts were ready to go.

These shorts are a great length and fit for hot summer days strolling or cycling around the city. Before you get rid of clothes, think first if they could serve you in a different way.

Have you upcycled something recently? Tell me below!

How well do you know the origin of your clothes? 🌱

Knowing where my clothes have come from is important to me, particularly when buying new. 

Sustainability is on very much on the agenda for consumers and retailers alike. Whilst I'm pleased to see it, the reality is that this becomes a trend, and an obvious way to attract customers. As a consumer, it's hard to wade through and distinguish what is and isn't legitimately sustainable. With a lack of universal standards and regulation, it all becomes a bit of a maze to shop new and know for sure that there's no evidence of unethical practices anywhere on the supply chain.

That's why I'm so thrilled to find shops which do the work for you. A couple of week's ago I stopped at the @knowtheorigin pop-up in Islington. Quite quickly I noticed that the shop stocked some of my favourite ethical brands, from @ilkandernie to @girlfriendcollective, as well as plastic free beauty and sustainable homewares. I'd been looking for a summer jacket, and picked up this white organic cotton one from @thinkingmu. The team at the store were eager to chat about @knowtheorigin' s story, and about the brands they stocked. On the website, I can see what product standards this jacket meets, exactly where in the world the jacket was cut, sewn, and the materials supplied, and what the jacket is made from. It should always be that easy!

@knowtheorigin launched in 2016 with the aim of building a new supply chain in the fashion industry. A few years later, the brand is home to a collection of certified brands, setting high standards for sustainability. In a world of greenwashing, it's a great place to buy clothes that meet a set of clear ethical standards 🌱 (Not an ad - just love to see it!)

Less is more? 🌾

When I think "Less is more", it's not in the detail of an outfit, or how many accessories should be put on (sorry Chanel). It's more about how many clothes, and how much choice, we have in our wardrobes.

Last week I was away from London on a staycation with a suitcase of clothes. Having a smaller selection of my wardrobe that I'd curated in advance, meant that I had less choice, but  was more creative in how I put my outfits together. This is something you can practice at home too. By encouraging yourself to choose from less clothes to make an outfit, makes you realise how far each individual piece can go. It certainly makes me feel less inclined to reach for my phone to search for new clothes online. 

Here's how I'd emulate the same experience at home:

1. Set aside a rail or section of your wardrobe with a selection of clothes you want to wear and style that week. Treat it like a capsule wardrobe.

2. When you've worn an item in your wardrobe recently, turn the coat hanger hook backwards. Next time you go in, reach for the clothes on the hangers facing you, that you've not worn recently.

3. Store away the clothes that are out of season, or you aren't feeling at the moment. Having smaller choice to select from might make you feel more decisive in your outfit decision making.

4. Change up and rewear your outfits by adding different layers and accessories. Here I changed up my dress with a vintage blazer and some new sunnies.

Let me know if you have any tips to emulate that capsule wardrobe experience!

Dress: @depop
Sunglasses: @mattandnat via @noodboutique
